Sir,

I have your letter of the 22nd instant in which you state that if the Bishop of Mackenzie River will say that the pupils at the Hay River school for whom the full grant was not paid were in residence the full quarter, although sick, the payment will be made on a supplementary return covering the time deducted by the Department. May I suggest that the requirement of the supplementary return be dispensed with, and that payment of the shortage be made upon the returns already in the possession of the Department? Hay River is quite a distance, and is beyond mail communication. Letters have to await the carriage of Hudson's Bay people or other traders. The requirement of a supplementary return would mean that payment could not be made until the first mail is received from Hay River next Summer. His Lordship has already stated, as you will observe on reference to the copy of his letter of the 29th ultimo which the Commissioner enclosed to you on the 10th instant, that the children were all at the school and had to be fed and cared for just the same as if they were attending the classes. It is quite evident from the returns and the correspondence that in this school the returns are made up from the registers kept in the class-room, in which failure to attend the class is noted as absence.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
would be very difficult in a country so circumstanced as Hay River to return the pupils to their homes when ill, indeed their illness would be an additional cause for keeping them in the institution where they can be properly cared for. I trust the Department will be able to concur in my suggestion and promptly meet the shortage in the payment to the Hay River school.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Indian Commissioner.

Hon. David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.:
Dear Sir,

I am sending off to the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs the Annual Report from School for the year ending June 30th/06, which has been waiting a chance to mail for some time since. I trust it will reach the Department in safety and be of interest. There is no regular mail going south from here after the 30th of June until December and as I know it would be too late for last year's publication I have taken my leisure and am sending it in time for this year. Owing to work at Midsummer, quite prevents my having it ready to send back with Mr. Courvoisier after treaty payment and that especially our only chance with winter.

I received a circular in January from the Assistant Secretary dated October 25th/06, saying that a Cash Book and forms had been sent me and requesting that I shall keep a strict account of all receipts and expenditures in connection with our Mission. The Book and forms...
can hardly reach here before the 8th or 10th of July next when the new regular mail passes our door. I have to say that owing to the facts that there is but little cash in circulation in this locality, our being on the most Northern border of the Treaty Limit, and that all the settlements for goods bought, freight charges, for white help, children's passage etc., etc., are made by the Bishop of the Diocese, who resides at Athabasca Landing, which is more than nine hundred miles south of us, I am unable to give you even an approximate fair estimate of our expenses, which I know runs up somewhere between four and six thousand dollars annually. I have already written the Bishop on the matter and trust you will get some statement from him in the near future.

I have been led to believe that the Government is likely to take over this work from the Mission Society. If such is the case I feel sure that the change will be for the good of the work which to my mind is a most promising one and well worth the expenditure if rightly directed.

We have always been cramped for want of sufficient means to fit up buildings and carry on the work as it really needs. We also bear under special disadvantages in having to secure all our necessary imported provisions in quantities large enough to meet all chance requirements of a whole year as there is no place within
three hundred miles from where we could possibly secure any considerable quantity of flour, bacon, beans, rice or any staple food, at any price, and the selling price in the country here is always well up to and beyond the high water mark of ordinary profits. In another particular we are peculiarly situated; to receive our goods in September we must order them previous December and anticipate every need for a year from the time when they are delivered. To be safe we have also to anticipate how many new scholars we can secure in the ensuing summer between the time that we write out our order and receive our goods. Some seasons we can only secure two or three and last summer we might have secured thirty had we been able to accommodate them, as it was we could only take eleven. Again our great isolation makes it very difficult to secure suitable men and women for moderate remuneration who are willing to endure the privations and lack of social enjoyments for years at a time. Our Missionary term holds us for five years unless in cases of broken health which is a long period to be bound to a ceaseless round of tedious toil with little or no diversion other than we can make for ourselves.

I have taken the liberty of drawing your attention to these facts for your information and consideration in case the work is taken over by your Department. These are some of the things that are likely to be
IV

outlooked in the first instance and which are amongst the drawbacks with which we have yearly to contend and for which we have to prepare. For my part I am expecting to withdraw from the work this coming July after fifteen years service, owing chiefly to my wife's broken health which has been brought out to a very great extent by overwork and the anxious care of nine years in this Institute.

Hoping that the statement of these few facts may be of interest as well as some small value to your Department in planning for the future, in case you take the work over.

Believe me, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

(Principal)

March 4/08.

The Indian Commissioner,
Ottawa.

My Dear Sir,

Will you kindly inform me

(1) The amount of the last payment made for the school at St. Peter's Mission, Hay River, Mackenzie River; and to whom paid, and when.

(2) Why the full grant has not been paid of late.

(3) Whether anything has been done with regard to my application for a per capita grant for the school at Whitefish Lake, Athabasca.

This application was made in 1906 or early in 1907. The receipt of it was acknowledged, and I was told that it would be brought forward in due course; but I have heard nothing more about it.

I shall be thankful to hear from you re the above as soon as possible, and am

very sincerely yours,

W. B. Reeve,
Bishop.
Ottawa, March 13, 1906.

Right Reverend Sirs,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 4th inst., and in reply I beg to say that the last payment to the Hay River Boarding School was for the quarter ended December 31, 1906. The cheque was for $354.00 and was sent on September 24, 1907, to Mr. George Griswold, Synod Office, Winnipeg, Man., to whom all cheques for this school have been sent.

The reason that the grant has not been paid since the above date is that the quarterly returns have not been received from this school. Upon receipt of the returns the grant will be promptly paid, but the Department can make no payment till the returns are received.

The matter of a grant for a school at Whitefish Lake will be dealt with in another letter.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sirs,

Your obedient Servant,

J. D. McLean

The Right Rev. W.D. Reeve, D.D.,
The Alexandria,
University Ave.,
Toronto.

Right Reverend Sir—

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 16th ult., in reference to the non-receipt of the quarterly returns from the Hay River Boarding school since December 31, 1906, and in reply I beg to inform you that, for the reasons stated in your letter, an advance on the grant due for the year 1907 is being sent you.

I have to request that Your Lordship will be good enough to instruct the Principal to have the quarterly returns of this school from December 31, 1906, to March 31, 1908, forwarded to the Department at the earliest possible opportunity, so that any further amount of grant due can be paid. A supply of blank forms is sent you herewith to forward to the school, in order that the Principal can make out the returns in the manner called for by the Department.

I beg also to forward you a return received for the September quarter, last, made out on a wrong form, on account of which the amount of grant due

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the attached letter from Bishop Reeves asking for some assistance for the Hay River Church of England School, I have to say that in our redistribution of funds we allowed the Hay River School an increase to $100.00 per capita for its estimated pupilage, that is 20 pupils at $100.00 = $2000.00. At present this is all that we can do for this School. When the Rev. Mr. O'Meara was here he brought to my attention the case of the Hay River School. It appears that the work of this Diocese has been divided; the northerly portion being administered by the Bishop of the Yukon and the southerly portion by the Bishop of Moosonee. I told Mr. O'Meara at that time that the Department would not be able to consider the case of this school specially and apart from the general question.

Chief Accountant.

During the year 1909 I visited Mackenzie River District as far North as the Arctic Coast, crossing over the mountains from Fort McPherson and going down the Porcupine River by way of Rampart House and Fort Yukon to Dawson.

On the way I was able in the month of July to visit Hay River School, and since that time I have had several reports from the Principal, Rev. A.J. Vale. I now desire to give the following brief report concerning the Indian Boarding School at Hay River:

During 1908 - 1909 there were 35 children in attendance at the school, 15 boys and 20 girls. In addition there were 9 day pupils.

In 1909 - 1910 there were 38 boarders, 16 boys and 22 girls.

The health of the pupils has been uniformly good with the exception of a few minor ailments. No deaths have occurred in the school during the last two years - up to March 1910 which is the date of the latest news received. The management and discipline of the school seem good.

The children were taught with a view of their returning to their former homes in most cases. The practical side was therefore emphasized. The boys were given ample instruction in gardening and fishing. They were also given opportunities to learn properly the use of an axe and other tools used in carpentering.
The girls received practical instruction in cooking, sewing, housekeeping etc.

One of the teachers also gave instructions in wood carving, and several of the children made good progress in this art. The ordinary school work has of course been carried on regularly.

I had occasion to notice the marked improvement shown in the cases of a number of children.

One young man who left the school last summer accompanied me on a winter journey from Fort McPherson to Rampart House. I observed that he had made good use of his term of schooling. He was moreover persevering in his endeavours to teach others.

The Hay River School has done good work, and under its present management continues to exert a beneficent influence, not only directly amongst the children, but also through them among the tribes to which they belong.

Isaac O. Stringer
Bishop of Yukon

June 4, 1910.
Mr. Frank Pedley,
Deputy Sup't General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:-

I wish to ask if the grant of $2000.00 towards Hay River Indian School, Mackenzie River District, was paid last year. If not would you please have it paid to the Imperial Bank, Athabasca Landing, to be placed to the credit of the account of the Diocese of Mackenzie River, which is held in the name of Archdeacon J.R. Lucas. I shall be glad if you will send me notice of the payment, and also notify Archdeacon Lucas at Fort Smith, Mackenzie River District.

I enclose you herewith a short report of Hay River School which I visited last Summer. When in Ottawa about a year ago you asked me to send in a report concerning the school. Up to a short time ago I have been travelling ever since I was in Ottawa, and only now am I able to send you this statement.

Last year you kindly gave a grant of $100.00 each for 20 pupils, or $2000.00 for the school. I wish to make application for a grant for 30 children at $100.00 per
capita, or $3000.00 in all.

You can readily understand that the expense of carrying on a school in a place like Hay River is great. We have to keep continually begging from friends to make ends meet. I think the school is well worthy of further support, and it would be a great relief if your department could increase the grant to at least $3000.00 per annum.

I expect Bishop Holmes will visit Hay River this summer, and if you desire it he will be able to give further information concerning the progress of the school. I expect he will be back at Athabasca Landing by August.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Bishop of Yukon.
Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 4th instant in reference to the grant earned by the Hay River Boarding School during the past fiscal year.

In reply I beg to say that at the time of Your Lordship's visit to Ottawa last spring the question of an increased grant to boarding schools in the West was under consideration. The proposal then was to close the Elkhorn Industrial school and distribute the funds expended annually in its maintenance among the different boarding schools under the auspices of the Church of England. In this redistribution provision was made to pay a per capita grant for 20 pupils at the rate of $100.00 each at the Hay River school.

The Department was unable, however, to carry out the proposal to close the Elkhorn school and consequently the funds to increase the grant at Hay River and other schools were not available.

A reference to official letter of May 4th, 1909, will show that the Department had in view the redistribution referred to above when Your Lordship was advised that an increased grant would be paid the Hay River school.

It is regretted very much that Your Lordship's

Right Rev. I. O. Stringer,
Bishop of Yukon,
Whitehorse, Yukon.
request could not under the circumstances be complied with, but you will readily recognize the impossibility of making an exception in the case of the Hay River school when there are other institutions operating under similar conditions.

The total earnings of this school for the nine months ended December 31st, 1959 were $1020.00. The grant for the June quarter was paid direct to the Principal, who acknowledged the same, while that for the September and December quarters was paid to His Lordship the Bishop of Athabasca. The earnings for the March quarter will be paid upon receipt of the usual quarterly return and the cheque will be sent, as directed, to the Ven. Archdeacon J. R. Lucas.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.
Ottawa, March 3rd., 1921.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith an Agreement, in duplicate, between Your Lordship and His Majesty the King, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, for the future maintenance and management of the Hay River Boarding School, and I have to request that you will be good enough to sign this document in the presence of a subscribing witness and affix your official seal, returning same to the Department at your earliest convenience, as this Agreement goes into effect on the 1st. of April next.

On the return of this document the signature of the Deputy Superintendent General will be affixed and one copy will then be returned to you. Certain alterations and improvements may be necessary at Hay River to bring the buildings up to the required standard. The Inspector of Treaty No. Eight when at Hay River during the coming summer making treaty payments will be instructed to inspect and report on the improvements needed. A reasonable time will be granted by the Department to allow you to have these improvements made, and in the meantime the increased per capita grant will be paid for 35 pupils at $126.00 from April 1st. next, provided this Agreement is completed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Right Rev. L. O. Stringer, D.D.,
Bishop of Yukon,
Dawson, Yukon.

August 18, 1913

The Hon. Frank Oliver,
Sept. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Acting upon your kind suggestion to no when we had the pleasure of meeting you, I am venturing to approach you regarding the grant allowed by the Indian Department to the Hay River Protestant Boarding School.

Hitherto the Department has given a grant of $75.00 for 20 pupils. This year, the grant was increased to $100.00 per capita.

The Pupilage has for some years reached a total of from 55 to 60. Taking the minimum number of children actually in residence the whole year round as Thirty-five (35), I would respectfully urge that the Grant from your Department should be so increased as to cover that number. This would involve a total outlay of $3500.00.

The children are drawn from the Chipewyan, Slave, Hare, & Tukudh, (or Loucheux) tribes.

The cost of the upkeep of this School is very great in consequence of the heavy freight charges on imported goods.

Your Honor was pleased to warmly commend the farming operations undertaken by the staff at Hay River, assisted by the boys of the school.

Hoping your Department will extend its grant so as to cover a pupilage of Thirty-five (35) Boarders,

I have the honor to be,

Yours respectfully,

J. R. Lucead
Archdeacon & Diocesan Sec., Trois.

This seems to be met by the charge made in the School report. Since this letter was written.

George Athabasca.

Ottawa, March 7th, 1911.

EX'D.

Right Reverend Sir,

In reply to the enquiry of Archdeacon Lucas with reference to the Hay River School, I have to state that Your Lordship is correct in supposing that this School will benefit by the recent increase in the per capita grants. It was understood however that the Bishop of the Yukon had this school under his charge and the Contract for the Hay River School was forwarded to him for execution. I trust that this action was correct. If not, the mistake can be rectified. In the meantime the Hay River School will receive the increased grant from the 1st. of April under the prescribed conditions.

It is noticed that the attendance has been from 35 to 40 pupils, and if the building can accommodate that number under the new regulations I think we would be disposed to pay for the increased number, but it should be distinctly understood that there must be no overcrowding and that more pupils are not in the building than it can accommodate with a proper care for sanitation. Inspector Conroy will be asked to report on this phase of the subject when he is at Hay River next summer.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Right Revd Geo. Holmes, D.D.,
Bishop of Athabasca,
Athabasca Landing, Alta.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge yours of March 3rd which reached Dawson during my absence on a visit to a distant tribe of Indians. I wish to acknowledge also your enclosure of two copies of a Form of Agreement regarding Hay River Boarding School. Bishop Holmes is this year visiting Hay River and other places along the Mackenzie River route, and he has the oversight of Hay River for the time being, he and I having the supervision of Mackenzie River Diocese between us. However it is impossible to reach him till the Autumn, and in order that the matter may not be delayed, I am signing the two Forms of Agreement on his behalf as well as for myself, and herewith enclose them to you.

In signing this agreement I wish to bring to your notice several points in which some alteration seems to be required, or at any rate a liberal interpretation in the practical application of the rules.

Firstly, in Section One, Sub-Section One in order that a per capita fee be obtained for twenty-five children, only one pupil for every twenty or fraction of twenty, is allowed to remain in the school at any one time. This would mean that only two extra could remain in the school at one time, or in other words, twenty seven is the maximum limit. You are probably aware that the children are received from many different points in the Northern District, and practically the only time that they can be brought to the school is for a short period in the Summer. Supposing twenty-seven are taken in during the Summer, and through an epidemic of illness or for any other reason, a number of them either die or have to be sent home, it may be practically impossible to procure other children till the following Summer. In the meantime the cost of the school is going on at almost the same rate as if the full number of children were in school, and the management is handicapped for lack of funds. The only remedy I can suggest, that in a remote school like Hay River the number of pupils allowed to remain at one time in excess of twenty-five should be increased.

Secondly—Under Section One, Sub-section Two (a) The rule regarding the school age of seven or over, if rigidly enforced, may be sometimes a hardship. It is our experience
that sometimes we are asked to take orphans, or children who have no one to care for them, and sometimes these may be under the age of seven, and yet it might be an advantage all around to receive them into the school. The maximum limit of twenty-seven children, however, might forbid this. If the management were permitted to receive children of five or at any rate six years of age, under exceptional circumstances, or were even allowed to receive such, without being counted in the matter of the excess number of pupils, it would I think be a reasonable relief.

Thirdly—Section One, Sub-Section Four (a) requires that no child shall be admitted unless he or she be a duly enrolled member of Hay River band of Indians residing at Hay River and vicinity, Indians now under the supervision of H.A. Conroy Inspector Treaty No. 8. I am not sure how far North Mr. Conroy's inspector-ship extends. When I passed down the Mackenzie River in 1909, a number of Indians at Simpson, Wrigley, McPherson, Norman and other places, requested me to have their children taken to the school. The same is, I believe, true every year. The Boarding School was established for the purpose of providing the Indians connected with the Church of England in the whole of the Mackenzie River Diocese or District, and I thought that was the understanding with the Department. I think it is reasonable that the Northern Indians should have the advantage of the school even though not under a formal treaty. I trust you will find some way to overcome this disability.

Fourthly—Section One, Sub-section four (b) states that no half-breed child shall be admitted unless permitted by the Supt. General, and that in any case, no grant shall be allowed for such child. It would seem reasonable that in a remote region like Mackenzie District, some latitude should be allowed the management in admitting such children as it is impossible as a rule to consult your Department beforehand. The Bishop or Archdeacon Lucas in the Annual Summer visits to the Coast, may be asked to take such children. Often there is no way of finding out beforehand what children are available, and at least a year would have to elapse if the consent of your Department must be first obtained. Then again some half-breed children are practically Indians, and in some cases also it might be a difficult task to prove whether a child were Indian or half-breed. I presume this rule would apply only to half-breed children, whose white parent is providing for his or her support.
Fifthly—In Section Two Subsection One, certified returns are required for each quarter before the grant is paid. This regulation in the case of Hay River will cause a long delay especially at certain seasons of the year. I would suggest that the payments be made at least one quarter in advance. They could be based on the returns of the preceding quarter if it be found that these returns can reach Ottawa in a reasonable time.

I can assure you that the management of the school will endeavor as far as possible to carry out the instructions of the Department. But I know you will recognize the difficulties with the Hay River school. I hope you will be able to give the matter special consideration, and that you will endeavor to give such relief from the strict reading of the general regulations as the circumstances require.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Isaac A. Stringer
Bishop of Yukon.

P.S.—When you return me a signed copy of this agreement, will you also please send the blank copy to Bishop Holmes, addressed to Athabasca Landing, Alberta, so that he may receive it on his return from Mackenzie River in August. I expect to meet Bishop Holmes in London, Ontario, on the 6th of September. In the meantime, I shall be glad to hear from you regarding the above suggestions.

Sir:

I have the honor to report upon the condition of the Indian (Anglican) Boarding School at Hay River, Great Slave Lake, which I visited on September 6th and 7th, also upon September 9th and 10th, accompanied by Dr A.McDonald, the Department's Medical Officer.

This School is under the immediate charge of the Rev. A. J. Vale, with Miss Page as Matron.

Buildings

The Buildings, which are of Log, are situated upon the river bank at the mouth of Hay River, and are surrounded by a large garden, in which a variety of vegetables and flowers are successfully grown, showing no signs of frost at the date of my visit.

Pupils

There are 25 pupils receiving the Government Grant.

Accommodation

The accommodation appears to be somewhat cramped, but is sufficient for the needs of the above stated number; there are, however, a staff of older boys and girls, who are retained as house and farm helpers, who should have more accommodation provided for them.

The children all look healthy and bright; I examined their handwriting, which is excellent and asked them, individually, a number of
questions; their replies were most intelligent and they have evidently been well taught.

**Health and Sanitation**

There was one child ill; Dr Macdonald, who examined her, stated that there was nothing serious the matter.

The water supply is not as good in the fall as it should be; the samples observed contained Anamolae in large numbers. The river from which it is taken is very sluggish at this point and vegetable matter appears to accumulate in it. I would recommend that the drinking water for the establishment be brought from Great Slave Lake, which is a comparatively short distance from the School, this should at least be done during the summer months.

**General**

I am informed by the Rev. Mr Vale that arrangements are being made for the erection of additional accommodation. The building at present occupied as his dwelling and the staff mess-house has a portion, which, when completed, can be used for isolation purposes in case of contagious disease occurring.

Much outdoor relief appears to be given to the Indians by Mr Vale in the way of medicines etc., and both he and Miss Page and Miss LeRoy, who constitute the present staff are doing excellent work.

An additional teacher is required as the male teacher employed left this summer.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A.J. Bell

Dear Sir,

There is a matter I wish to bring to your notice concerning the conveyance of Indian children to the Hay River Boarding School.

The above school serves the whole of the Anglican Diocese of Mackenzie River, and the children attending it are brought from their homes by steamer at distances ranging from 250 to 1200 miles. This involves the Mission in a very heavy expenditure yearly for fares. I venture to approach your Department therefore with the view of obtaining help towards meeting this heavy and inevitable outlay, and would respectfully call your attention to the following:

These children are in several cases, orphans, and even when such is not the case, their parents are unable to defray the expense of sending them to the school.

The children are all promised to the school for periods ranging from five years and upwards, so that the expense incurred would not be asked for in any particular case under that time.

No child has been taken to the school for many years past without having been thoroughly inspected and examined by the Government Doctor. This precaution, I consider, is of the utmost importance, and as a consequence we have enjoyed a perfectly complete bill of health, and immunity from death.

Dear Mr. Bury:

In reply to your request that you be furnished with a list of some of our pupils who have left the School in the past, I have much pleasure in submitting the following:

1. Arthur Hardisty (Slave Indian). - Returned to his father, worked on the Steamer as deck-hand, was interpreter for the R.N.W.M. Police at Simpson, and now has returned to hunting and trapping.

2. Daniel Bompa (Slave Indian). - Worked for several years on the Hudson Bay Company's Steamer as a deck hand. Later married and settled at Hay River. Wife died last winter. He is now assisting in the building of our new school.

3. Jessie McSwain (Half-Breed). - Married to Wm. Morasi a fellow pupil of our school. He was hired for a time as a helper at our Mission. Later, he desired to return to his own people at Norman; After about 3 years' sojourn there he died. Widow is still living at Fort Norman.

4. Rosie McSwain. - Became a domestic for a White Woman in the country, and later married a white man and lives at the present somewhere in the Peace River District.

5. Nellie McSwain. - Served as Domestic to Bishop Reeve; later married to Hudson Bay Company's former District accountant. Died in Edmonton.

6. Thomas Wm. McSwain(Half-Breed). - Engaged for a time after leaving school as a Mission helper; is now for the 4th year interpreter for the Hudson Bay Co. in this place.
7. Charles Horn (Half-Breed) - Hired as Interpreter and Fisherman for our Mission; has been here now for upwards of 20 years. Is married and has a son at school. Acts as the Official Interpreter for the Treaty Party and sometimes for the Police. Leads an exemplary life in every way.

8. Josephine Lamalise (Slave Indian) - Left school to keep house for her father after the death of her mother.

9. John Richard Berens - Hired for a time as outdoor worker on Mission Staff. Left to work on the H.B. Co.'s steamer, has done so for 4 seasons and is at present so engaged. We are trying to secure him now as an outdoor helper again.

10. Harriet Morasi - Indian girl from Norman; returned to her home, was married this summer to Albert Grostite who also was a former pupil of our school. Spent a year in Ontario with Rev. and Mrs. T.J. Marsh.

11. Edward Moron - Son of H.B. Co's Fort Master; a very bright and clever scholar, returned home, hired as clerk for H.B. Co., and has for the last 6 years been in charge of a Trading Post for the Company. Is married to one of our old girl pupils and has a family. Lives at Fort Nelson, B.C.

12. John Francis Moron (brother of Edward) - Is now interpreter for a fur trader at Fort Resolution, N.W.T.

13. William Moron (another brother) - Is cook at the H.B. Co's District Headquarters, Fort Smith, N.W.T.

14. Louise Redsetiya - Returned home to Simpson; is a hunch-back; hired as Domestic to H.B. Clerk, and later was taken by the family to Edmonton - no further news of her.

15. Emily Alice Berens - A clever and neat scholar, hired as domestic to Indian Agent, A.J. Roll, at Fort Smith, N.W.T., and went with them to Waskatoon. Later returned to Athabasca and married last year.

16 & 17. John & Stirling McKinley (1/4 Breeds) - Sons of H.B. Co's clerk, now living in Athabasca; last heard of them one in printing office; other a carter with his own teams.

18. Jacob Njootli (Piel River Indians) - Returned home as elder brother had died; he had to take charge of the home. Built a house and taught a small school of children.
voluntarily in his home during evenings. Later went to Choutia Indian School, Barcross, Yukon, to prepare for the ministry; is at present in Dawson; has spoken of volunteering for active service in defence of the Empire.

19. Sarah Njootli (sister of Jacob) - Left school last year (1915) and is engaged as Domestic in Bishop Lucas' home at Chipewyan, Alta.

20. Jane Enoch (Peel River Half-Breed) - Left school 1915 - is married to Hudson Bay clerk trading in the Mackenzie River Delta.

21. Donald Isaac (Peel River Indian) - Hired as Mission helper for two years and then joined Hudson Bay Company's steamer; this season (1916) is in full charge of the deck hands on steamer.

22. Nadeline Etenaishi (Hay River Slaski Indian) - Last year hired as domestic to H. B. Co.'s Fort Master at Fort Resolution. The latter went to Edmonton on leave. Nadeline returned here and now has been engaged as domestic to the Protestant Minister, Rev. G. W. Bowring at Fort Simpson.

23. Douglas Rae Hope - Returned home and is engaged on the SS. "Northland Trader" owned and operated by the Northern Trading Company.

Most of the others have returned to their homes; some, I regret to say, go back to their old mode of living; others, I am pleased to say, have married Indian men and are keeping their houses and families beautifully clean and tidy. One is known as the model housekeeper at Fort Simpson.

I trust these details may be what you desire and will prove of use to you.

Yours sincerely,

HAY RIVER BOARDING SCHOOL. (Anglican.)

At the time of my visit to Hay River the new school building was in process of erection. As will be seen by the photograph it is a commodious structure and compared with the old building is a great improvement. It is expected that the new school will be ready for occupancy about the month of June next.

Up to the present time the school work has been considerably handicapped owing to the lack of accommodation.

The measurements of the school are 94 ft. x 30 ft. and it will be two storeys in height.

The usual classes were held during my stay at Hay River and I was especially struck with the proficiency of the pupils in reading and writing. Several Eskimo children receive tuition here and exhibit great aptitude for learning.

The class work was generally well up to the standard and the boys appeared to thoroughly enjoy their outside work. The pupils, both boys and girls, appear singularly healthy and vigorous.

I was able to secure from the school principal a Mr. A. J. Vale, a statement or record of the doings of ex-pupils of the school. This statement is attached.

Dear Sir,

It is with much pleasure I have to report that the new Indian Boarding School at Hay River, Great Slave Lake, N.W.T., is now completed, and was formally opened by me on June 28th, last.

It has since been visited by Inspector H.A. Conroy of Ottawa and G. Card, Esq., the Indian Agent living at Fort Smith, and in whose district the school is situated. They have probably presented their reports to your Department. I beg to enclose three photos of the building but hope to obtain better ones for you during my next visit.

I am also enclosing a list of children at present in the school, who are eligible for the Indian Department's Per Capita Grant as from July 1st, 1917. All these children have been medically examined, and the list itself scrutinized by Mr. Conroy with the one exception of Oso, Elsie Edward, who arrived at the school by a later trip.

In addition to the 42 names of children thus given, there are three others under six years of age, concerning whom Mr. Conroy has promised to report to you. I trust your Department will consent to give the per capita Grant for these also, as they are orphans, and on account of their tender age require more care and attention than those who are older.

May I be allowed to express my gratitude to your Department
for the ready and generous help it has given in connection with the supply of equipment for the new school, and the hope that all may result in an increase of usefulness and benefit to the Indian Children who may be sheltered within its walls.

Dear Sir,

Health & Sanitation:

This year the health of the children is good. In July we received by SS "Mackenzie River" a little girl from Arctic Red River who was reported to be suffering from Diphtheria - the whole of the new pupils were isolated in the Isolation Hospital (built last summer) - the little girl placed in a tent with a nurse. The new pupils, however, were infected and had to stay in the hospital six weeks. They were cleaned up - all things burned - and moved over to the large school. One week later it was found that the Indian girl that had been helping Mrs. Hunter (nurse) had the disease - the school was quarantined - no one being allowed to visit from the village. In all forty-three (43) boys and girls had the complaint. Through the faithful work of Mrs. Hunter and the Matrons, assisted by Mrs. Bowring (a trained nurse) no deaths occurred from the disease, though all were worn out by the tremendous strain.

Dr. MacDonald visited us, but could not stay as requested.

I have to report the death of one pupil from Laryngitis. At present all the pupils are exceptionally well. The strict quarantine regulations kept the disease from spreading to the village. The rooms are splendidly ventilated - the furnaces are a great success - each boy and each girl has a separate bed - and all are cheerful and happy.

Water is supplied from Hay River and the Great Slave Lake.

George W. Bowring.
Dear Mr. Scott,

Your letter of April 13th received June 2nd. Re the outbreak of diphtheria at Hay River Mission. I beg to enclose the following extract of the latter from my report to the department dated Aug 18, 1917.

The "hasty party" arrived at Hay River on the 18th July and met the S.S. Mungo River on her way back from Fort McPherson. She had on board several children for the mission school at Hay River, and one of the children, a little girl, had been isolated on board the boat for diphtheria. She was in charge of Dr. Doyle of the R.M.W.M.C. at Fort McPherson, and Mrs. Hunter, one of the staffs of the Hay River Mission, who was on board took charge of the patient as nurse. On their arrival here the patient seemed quite recovered from the disease, but as a precaution I advised that all the children should be isolated from the children at Hay River, and as they have an isolation building separated from the school and the immediate surrounding buildings, it suited the purpose well as an isolation hospital. Mrs Hunter undertook to look after the case of the patient and the whole number until past time as all danger of the disease was over. All precautions were taken, and instructions given as to the care of treatment of the patients in case it should break out again. The patient at no time had...
been seriously sick, although the wound showed quite a patch of false membrane at first.

Mr. Inspector Conroy, who was also on board, instructed me to proceed down to Fort Simpson as there was an Indian brought up from Fort Norman to the hospital at Simpson suffering from a diseased foot; which in his opinion required to be amputated to save his life, he however had to return to Fort Resolution to finish up paying treaty to a portion of the Indians who were not present when treaty was paid them a few days ago. They were delayed by ice so could not get into the fort in time.

Board the H.M.S. Northland at Resolution the night of July 24th and arrived at Hay River on the 26th. Two more patients had developed the disease (two more of the children which were brought up from the lower Mackenzie district.) The cases were of a mild form but distinctly diphtheritic in character. They were responding favourably to the treatment ordered except not suffering very much.

Proceeded to Simpson & arrived there on July 30th where I found the Indians on Blythe Francis aged 65 years suffering from cancer of the foot. Amputated the foot returned to Hay River arriving there on Aug 6th Mr. Hunter informed me that already 14 of the children had died of diphtheria, up to that date out of the 17 annuals there were now only three more which had not been affected so far. They were all recovering nicely. No complications following they were all to be kept in isolation until all danger
communication of the disease was ever before they will be allowed among the other children in the school. Most of their clothing will be destroyed and they will be thoroughly disinfected and all precautions taken to confine the disease.

There were no deaths following the outbreak, and I know nothing that I could do further than what was done. I trust the above explanation will be satisfactory.

I remain

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Donalds,
M.D.

Dear Sir,

I have pleasure in acknowledging the receipt of your letter of March 14, informing me that your Department had forwarded a cheque to the Bank for $218.25, to cover the cost of the transportation of children from Fort McPherson to the Hay River School.

In reply to your observation that the Department considers there should be sufficient children available without going to such remote points for recruits, I would respectfully say, that after very careful consideration, the school has been established in the only place where fish and potatoes can be procured in sufficient quantities to ensure an adequate supply of food for a large number of children. Also, that if a School were established further North, the increase of freight charges on all imported food and material would throw a much heavier burden of expense upon the Department and Mission for equipment and maintenance.

I might add that the Roman Catholics who have a larger number of children to consider, have no School further North than Providence which is only 80 miles from Hay River, and they gather recruits from Arctic Red River only 35 miles distant from Fort McPherson, whence our children were drawn.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Mr. Moran, of the Northwest Territories Branch, Department of the Interior, has shown me their files with reference to hospital wings in the Fort Resolution and Hay River Indian Residential Schools. That Department has refused to designate these schools as hospitals; the Department of Health having advised them that it would be "an extremely dangerous situation to set up. Children are potential subjects of all of the infectious diseases, and having such a focus near a school seems to me to be contrary to all the recognized principles of health protection. I certainly think a hospital (separate building) is required and should be insisted upon." On these grounds, the Interior Department are not paying grants for the hospitalization of patients being treated at the Fort Resolution or Hay River Indian Residential Schools.

Our Department is allowing grants for patients at both schools (Files Nos. 74-139 and 50-139). The Department has written to Dr. Bourget, the Indian agent, regarding the advisability of keeping a patient with an infectious disease at the Hay River School. As a matter of policy, should we allow hospital patients in our residential schools? There is no question but what the authorities of the school were prompted solely by charity, as they have kept this patient for 24 years without grant.

I presume that the Interior Department will probably cooperate with us in the provision of funds and in the erection of hospitals which may be found necessary in the Northwest Territories. The present discussion leads me to believe that a hospital, to be conducted either under Protestant or State auspices, should be established at Hay River, where the land is suitable for gardening. Further, it appears that Fort Resolution requires a hospital and this fact was brought to our attention by His Lordship Bishop Breynat in October, 1923 (134-4-5). There is a physician at Resolution but not at Hay River. Bishop Breynat's scheme was a combined residential school and hospital, which was changed eventually and which would certainly not be a proper arrangement.

If funds are provided by either the Department of the Interior or this Department, or by both, the Department of Health would submit plans for suitable buildings.

This memorandum has been written, following Mr. Moran's visit, in the interests of the health of the Indian children in residential schools and in the interests of all members of communities who require hospital treatment.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, June 1, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that this Department and the Department of the Interior have compared reports which have been received from the Bay River Indian Residential School and I regret to state that there has been duplication of the grants.

The Department of the Interior has been paying a grant of $400 per annum for the conduct of a day school for children that are not wards of the Indian Department. This grant is conditional upon the regular attendance of such children, and it is my duty to point out that on the list of names directed to the Interior Department there are not ten who are not enrolled as pupils of the Bay River Indian Residential School.

More serious than this has been the duplication of maintenance grants in the case of three Stockerson children. The Department of the Interior has been allowing maintenance grants since April 1st, 1923, and their names have also been included on the returns to this Department and our grant has been allowed for the June and September quarters, 1923. These three names were included on all subsequent quarterly returns showing the enrolment at the Indian residential school; but, as the average attendance was more than 50 in each quarter - and grant paid for only 50 - it cannot be said that there was duplication of grants since October first, 1923.

I feel that an explanation for this action is due to the Department. The geographical situation of this school makes it difficult for us to refuse to admit children when applied for by the Rev. Principal on the grounds that they are not wards of this Department and therefore ineligible. We have to rely on the school management to deal fairly, and the facts mentioned in this letter are such that I feel our confidence has been misplaced.

Dear Sir:-

Your letter of the last instant (No 139-2-1) relative to (1) the payment of a grant by the Department of the Interior for the tuition of non-treaty pupils at our Society's Hay River School on condition that there should be not less than ten such pupils receiving tuition, and (2) the duplication of maintenance grants from your Department and the Department of the Interior for the three Sterkersen children for the June and September Quarters 1923, has been delivered to me, and in reply I beg to state as follows:-

(1) With regard to the grant paid by the Department of the Interior for the tuition of non-treaty children on condition that not less than ten children of this class should receive tuition, I have to inform you that the first intimation which I received of this grant being subject to this condition was derived from your letter now before me. It is possible, of course, that when the Department of the Interior undertook to make this grant to the Diocese of Mackenzie River, this condition was imposed, and that our Society was not informed of its existence at the time that the school was transferred to its control. I have examined all available correspondence in this connection, but having failed to locate any mention of this condition, I am writing to the Diocesan authorities, and also to the Department of the Interior for further information in this connection.
When this information has come to hand I will communicate with you again.

In the meantime I beg to state that as this grant was payable by the Department of the Interior upon receipt of their own official forms which contained full information from the Principal about the pupils who were receiving this tuition, I am at present unable to understand how those responsible for the management of the School could be thought to have acted unfairly.

(2) With regard to the receipt of a maintenance grant from both your Department and the Department of the Interior for the Storkersen children for the June and September quarter of 1923, I have to inform you that no maintenance grant was received by our Society in this connection from the Department of the Interior before April of the present year. That grant did indeed cover maintenance for these children as from April 1st 1923, but as it has so recently been sanctioned and received, I am unable to understand how it could be thought that those responsible for the management of this School have been acting unfairly.

This School, as you are no doubt aware, did not come under the control of our Society until January 1st, 1923, and as the instruction which has been given to the Principals of all of our Society's Schools, to furnish me with a copy of their quarterly returns to your Department, did not come into operation at the Hay River School until after my visit to that institution in July and August of 1923. I am not in possession of the information which those forms contained for the March, June and September quarters of that year. The grants paid by you, however, and the number of children on the returns forwarded to you for the June Quarter 1923, and up to the end of the December Quarter 1924, so far as I have received them, are as follows:

| Quarter | Year | Average attendance for which grant was paid | No of pupils on Register |
|---------|------|--------------------------------------------|--------------------------|
| June    | 1923 | 48.82                                      | (not available)          |
| Sept.   | 1923 | 46.53                                      | (not available)          |
| Dec.    | 1923 | 50.                                        | 57                       |
| March   | 1924 | 50.                                        | 57                       |
| June    | 1924 | 50.                                        | 56                       |
| Sept.   | 1924 | 50.                                        | 63                       |
| Dec.    | 1924 | 50.                                        | 58                       |

From these figures it is quite clear that your Department was not providing our Society with a maintenance grant for any pupils over the sanctioned number of 50 for the period mentioned, and as the grant from the Department of the Interior has but recently been sanctioned and paid, it is obvious that the maintenance expenses of all pupils above that
number, were being met from another source, namely from the funds of our Society.

Had our Society been receiving a regular quarterly maintenance grant from your Department for more than 50 pupils for the period in question, and at the same time another regular quarterly maintenance grant from the Department of the Interior for any pupils over this number, our integrity might justly have been questioned. In the light, however, of the information which I have set forth in this letter, and it is the only information which I have available at present, I see no reason why it should be questioned, and the facts as I have given them will, I believe, fully vindicate it.

Since receiving your letter I have written to the Principal of the Hay River School requesting him to furnish me with copies of the returns he forwarded to your Department for the March, June and September Quarters 1923, and when these have come to hand I will communicate with you again.

In the meantime, and before closing this letter, I should like to state that if there is any further information which you desire, and which you think I may be able to furnish, I shall gladly forward the same on receipt of your request.

I should also like to state that, in a work such as this in which we are engaged, where so many numerous details have to be attended to, and where distances between our respective centres are so vast as to prohibit more frequent meetings for conference and counsel, misunderstandings such as this one now before us, are very liable to arise. But these should not, I think, be allowed to affect our confidence in each other, and I very much hope that the explanations which have been set forth in this letter may furnish you with an assurance that your confidence in those responsible for the management of the Hay River School has not been misplaced.

Believe me Sir,

With very good wishes,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Finnie:

As the time we may have together during your visit to Hay River may be very limited, I have written down in brief statement an answer to your letter of enquiry.

According to a letter received from the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs Ottawa, there appears to be some confusion regarding the names sent in our reports to your Department and to his.

I have in each case reported all the names on the Register in the Class Room. That was done according to the instructions given me by Bishop Lucas.

While in your Office in March 1924 you very kindly told me arrangements had been made to pay for the Half Breed and other destitute children in this part. I then informed you we were already in receipt of such from the Department of Indian Affairs. You expressed pleasure that such was the case. On my arrival in Winnipeg May 1924 I told Dr. Westgate of the application for a grant for the Storkerson Children in addition to the Grant allowed for 50 children in our school as we had more than that number in residence at the time. This led to considerable correspondence, as there appeared to be some difficulty to locate certain Blank Forms to be filled in before such a grant could be made. Unfortunately some part of this correspondence took place during my absence on furlough and I could not get the necessary Blanks in time to forward same to you and to Dr. Westgate at Winnipeg.

During the interval consumed by this correspondence under our limited Mail Service much time...
went bye. Our School met with a serious loss of six pupils by death and in one of my letters to Rev. Dr. Westgate I advised him, the number now would not total the number allowed by the Indian Department namely 50 pupils, and in order that the full number might be retained I told him of my action in putting the names of the Sterkerson Children again on the list for the Grant from the Department of Indian Affairs. This I think was in the Spring of 1925 or late winter. Up till that time the only information I had was to the effect they could not receive the Grant from the North West Territory until the Blanks had been filled out and been received in Ottawa.

In the meantime a letter was sent to me saying the Grant had, through the kindness of your Office, been allowed on the Understanding such Blank would be forth coming in due time. The Blanks have since been sent and I understand a grant was made.

I sincerely regret any confusion my action may have led to, and at the same time desire to assure you I have faithfully tried to carry out to the best of my ability the instructions received from all Parties concerned both in Ottawa and Dr. Westgate in Winnipeg.

I am dear Sir,

Yours sincerely,

(signed) Alfred J. Vale

The total cash receipts, therefore, during 1927 may be reckoned at $7804.25 or in round figures, say, $8000.00

For the same period the cash disbursements made by our Society, as set forth in the Report of our Commission's auditor, amounted to $12,152.67, leaving a cash balance of over $4000, which our Society had to provide.

The capacity of enrollment is fixed by your Department at 50 pupils, and consequently, the per capita rate should be $240, to meet an annual expenditure of $12,000.

As the greater number of the children in residence are recruited from districts around the lower parts of the MacKenzie River, it would appear to be a safe and wise policy to have the Hay River School transferred to a suitable location somewhere in that part. So long, however, as it remains where it is, our Society will be faced with an annual heavy deficit unless a capacity enrollment is maintained and the per capita rate substantially increased.

Dear Sir:

I very deeply regret to have to report that during my recent visit to the Hay River School I learned of the death by drowning of the boy pupil Benjamin Martin. This took place on July 3rd, just one day before my arrival, when Benjamin, along with about 19 or 20 other boys from the school, and under the supervision of Mrs. Singleton, wife of the Principal, were bathing in their customary bathing place. The water rested on a sandy bottom, and was not over three feet deep. As the pupils had used this spot for bathing for many years, and had previously bathed there this year, not even the slightest accident or misadventure was anticipated. The boys were all in the water at the same time, and Benjamin was not missed until they were dressing to return to the School. As soon as his absence was discovered, a search was made for him among the bushes along the shore, but failing to find him, the supervisor sent one of the bigger boys to call the Principal and men agents, and also to notify the local detachment of Mounted Police. Shortly after these arrived Mr. Boxer, General Assistant on the school staff, discovered the body lying in the water face downwards, and only about 30 feet from the shore. A determined effort was made to restore respiration but without effect. As there was no mark of any kind on the body the conclusion formed by those present was that death was due to "either cramps or heart failure". Corporal Cook who is in charge of the local detachment of the R.M.P., conducted an investigation, and informed the Principal that he did not attach any blame to the school management. The loss of this promising pupil is the more deeply to be regretted as it was the fond hope of his father that he should be prepared for the sacred Ministry of the Church, and arrangements were being made to accomplish this end.

During my visit I arranged with the Principal that in future he himself should accompany the boys when they went bathing. Messages of very deep sympathy were sent by me and the Principal of the School to the bereaved father, and I also arranged for Bishop
who was at Hay River at the same time on his way North, to furnish him with a detailed account of his son's death. The School management were deeply grieved over the whole affair, but after receiving the information set forth above, I reached the same conclusion as the head of the local Mounted Police detachment, and feel that no blame can be attached to the School management.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Statement of Mr Eric Calrow.

Begins.

I, Eric Calrow, am employed by the Anglican Mission at Ray River N.W.T., as Farm Instructor.

Last Wednesday Afternoon, July 3rd 1929, I was working in the field when Miss Sowden, the Matron-in-charge came to me at about 5.30 P.M., and told me that one of the Boys, Ben Martin, was missing. The rest of the boys had come out of the water where they were and commenced to dress, when they discovered that there was a set of clothes without an owner, and on looking them over found that they belonged to the boy Ben Martin. I ran over to the beach and saw Mr Boxer, our evangelist, in the water searching, and Mrs Singleton searching along the shore; the boys were still dressing by the smudge. I found that the boy must have been missing for almost half an hour, so decided to get a canoe, as neither Boxer or myself can swim.

I returned quickly to the school, passing Mr Singleton, the Principal running to the beach. I returned with the canoe, but found that Boxer had recovered the body out of the lake at a distance of about 25 or 30 feet from the shore. Corp. Cook was then sent for, and in the meantime artificial respiration was tried, but was of no avail. The body must have been in the water well over ½ of an hour, so Corp. Cook and Const. Salkeld decided that the body should be taken to the Mission.

The wind was blowing on shore and the water felt cold to me, but the day was mild, and I have known the boys to go in to swim on days very much worse than last Wednesday. They never go alone. Mrs Singleton, the Principal's wife was in charge that day, and some of the older boys are quite good swimmers.

Eric Calrow.

Statement of Mrs W.B. Singleton.

Begins,

Martha Singleton, wife of the Reverend Principal Rev. W.B. Singleton, of the Anglican Residential School, Hay River N.W.T., was in charge of the older boys of this school on Wednesday July 3rd 1929. I took them for their usual afternoon swim on the lake shore, a distance across the portage from the school of about three quarters of a mile.

I then ran to the Mission to give the alarm, and returned quickly to the beach with Mr. Boxer, the engineer, having sent word to Mr. Singleton who was in the village, and to Mr. Calrow working in the field. He and Mr. Boxer searched in the water but did not find the boy. I returned to the school with three boys for a canoe and met Mr. Singleton coming to the beach. I returned again to the beach with the boys and found that Mr. Boxer had found the body of Ben Martin in the water and he and Mr. Singleton and Mr. Calrow were giving first aid. I returned again to the school for the horse and brandy.

Statement of Miss Helena Sowden.

Begins.

I, Helena Sowden, am the Matron-in-Charge at the Anglican Residential School at Hay River N.W.T.

For almost the whole of the past six years I have been in charge of the Boys of the school, and it is custom each day, between the hours of 4 and 6 P.M., for the boys to engage in some kind of recreation.

Every Wednesday I take relief duty in the kitchen, and on these days some other member of the Staff takes charge of the boys for their recreation.

Last Wednesday afternoon it was arranged for the Principal's wife, Mrs W.B. Singleton, to take the boys bathing at the usual place on the lake shore. Before they left I handed each boy his towel and bathing suit, and watched them leave the school grounds about 4.30 P.M. in Mrs Singleton's charge.

About three quarters of an hour later Mrs Singleton returned and said that she could not find the boy Ben Martin and requested me gather the men at once, and send them over to the beach. I did this, and all our three men were over in a very short while, and soon after received the very sad news that Ben Martin's body had been recovered from the lake drowned.

Ben Martin is a Treaty Indian boy, aged eleven years, and his parents live at Moherson.

The practice of the boys bathing in the lake each summer has always been carried on whilst I have been on the Staff of the Mission, and no thought of danger ever occurred, as the beach is very shallow, and has been considered quite safe even for the smallest children.

Ends

Helena Sowden

I, W.B. Singleton, Principal of the Anglican Indian Residential School, Hey River N.W.T., have been in charge of this school for the past twenty-two months. I have followed the usual routine and customs which were in effect at the time of my assumption of duty.

I hurried to the beach, and a few minutes after my arrival there, our engineer Mr. Boxer found the body and carried it ashore. During the next half hour we employed the method of artificial respiration, but without avail as the boy had already been in the water for at least half an hour. Our Staff Nurse, Miss M. MacKett was at the shore rendering and doing the First Aid attempted.

I was aware that the boys were going to bathe at the beach that afternoon. Knowing however, that the boys had often bathed there before, I did not think that there could be any danger on such a shallow beach.

This boy came to the school with his brother Robert a little over two years ago. He is a Treaty Indian of the Tukudh Band and a son of the Rev. John Martin, Anglican Missionary at Morhosen. He is eleven years and has always enjoyed good health while at the school.

REPORT.

Re-Benjamin Anglican Indian Residential School
Ray River R.S.P.
Accidentally drowned

On July 3rd 1929 at 6.15 P.M., one of the boys from the above school came to the detachment and told me that I was wanted at the lake shores. Ben Martin's school boy had been drowned whilst bathing. Accompanied by Reggio Cook N.E. Balkeld I left immediately for the boys bathing beach, and found that the body had been recovered from the lake.

First aid was being tried by the nurse stationed here and Mr. Bozner, the engineer from the mission, but without any result. Investigating I found that the boy had been in the water for almost an hour, so it was useless to carry on with artificial respiration. Cook Balkeld and I took the body over to the mission and washed it, and examined it very thoroughly with the Nurse for any marks or bruises, but there were none. Cook Balkeld and I made a coffin and got it ready for burial, which took place here the next day, July 4th 1929.

I have taken statement from all the persons concerned, which I attach herewith.

The bathing beach is quite safe under all ordinary conditions, as there is only 3 feet of water at a distance of 500 yards out. It slopes gradually and there are no holes, the danger arises when the sea is breaking on the shore, and in a ground swell coming. At the time this accident occurred the wind was from the east, but had died down considerably since the morning. Mr. Singleton, the principal of the school, had no idea that there could be the least danger in allowing the boys to bathe that day; they have apparently gone into the water when the sea has been quite as bad as on Wednesday last. The boys were in the care of Mrs. Singleton, and though she cannot swim, several of the older boys are quite good. I think the boy drowned was simply swept off his feet and the back wash kept him down, no call was heard by Mrs. Singleton or any of the boys, and twenty out of the twenty-one in the group were in the water; he was not missed at all until his clothing was not claimed.

Due to the rush of work here during each summer and fall and also to shortage of help, we are unable to clear and break more than one half acre of new land each year. This summer the amount will be even less as our men are to be responsible for the erection of our new hospital building.

I quite agree with our Indian Agent, Dr Bourget, that this school needs a much larger supply of vegetables, and accordingly much more garden space. Dear Dr. McGill:

In my letter of October 22nd last, I laid before the Secretary of your Department all the information in my possession about the pupilage at our Hay River School, and the per capita grant for the same. This school has an official capacity of 50 pupils, and there are 53 Treaty pupils in residence at present and 5 Non-Treaty, but the Secretary when replying to my letter on November 10th (No. 139-2-10) stated that "at the present time it is not possible for the Department to allow grant for more than thirty (30) pupils".

This decision has given me and our Commission one of the severest shocks we have had for some years, as we are charged with the heavy responsibility of keeping our expenditure within the sanctioned appropriation, and this is absolutely impossible of achievement if the grant for the Hay River pupilage is reduced from fifty to thirty pupils. As the Bank overdraft of our Society on account of our Indian Residential Schools, stood, on May 31st last at $26,960.81, you will realize the critical nature of the situation which will confront us at the close of the current calendar year, and I most sincerely trust your Department may yet be able to afford some help in relieving us of the heavy load of anxiety which rests upon us at the present time.

In making this request I am not unmindful of the difficulty your Department may have before April 1st of next year of providing the full per capita grant for fifty pupils, but as five of the pupils are Non-Treaty and the grant for them should be paid by the N.W.T. Branch of the Department of the Interior, our Commission will endeavour to carry 50% of the cost of the remaining 15 pupils. If your Department will agree to provide a like amount, this arrangement to stand until the end of March next only, when it is expected provision will be made in your estimates for the year.
1935-36, and for all subsequent years for the per capita grant to be paid for fifty pupils.

If you will kindly give this urgent and important matter your own personal attention, and arrange with the Honourable the Minister of the Interior to provide the grant for the five Non-Treaty pupils from the mid-summer holidays 1934, and for your Department to provide the grant for the same period for half of the fifteen Treaty pupils, our Commission and our Society will be duly grateful.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

A request has been received from Reverend Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary, Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, Winnipeg, Man., that grant be provided for an increase of 20 in the pupilage at the Hay River Indian Residential School, North West Territories. At present, grant is allowed for 30 pupils at $200 per capita, less 15%. During the past summer, the Anglican missionaries at Aklavik and northern posts recruited some 23 additional children and sent them to Hay River. Dr. Westgate now urges that per capita grant be provided for 20 additional pupils.

Failure to receive from your Department any grant for twenty of the pupils in our Hay River School, has inflicted a very severe hardship on our Society; and our concern is all the more acute when we find that approximately $16,000.00 has been paid to the Roman Catholic Schools for the services of watchmen and no proportionate grant was made to our Society's schools for the same purpose.

While dealing with matters pertaining to this school, I desire to direct your attention to the statement made at the top of page 9 of my letter of the 19th ultimo, namely, "Failure to receive from your Department any grant for twenty of the pupils in our Hay River School has inflicted a very severe hardship on our Society..........."

During my visit to your Department on December 20th, last, I discussed this matter with the Deputy Superintendent General; and also with the Acting Superintendent of Indian Education, and received the impression that it would receive consideration. Previous to my visit I find from our records that I had placed the whole situation before the Deputy Superintendent General in my letter of December 7th of last year, and he replied to the same on December 19th, No. 139-2-1, stating that he had placed my request before the Honourable, the Superintendent General, and would advise me later of his direction. On January 8th of this year I wired the Deputy Superintendent General again in this connection, and he replied by wire on the same date stating the Minister was withholding his decision pending approval of estimates which were then before the Treasury Board.

From all the facts of the case so far as they have reached our Commission, the members are unable to see any substantial reason why the grant for these twenty pupils should not be paid in full, but they are prepared to adhere to the generous offer made in the third paragraph of my letter to the Deputy Superintendent General on December 7th last, namely, to carry half the cost of tuition and maintenance of the fifteen Treaty children, if your Department will carry the cost of the remaining fifteen and the North West Territories Branch of the Department of the Interior will carry the cost of the five non-treaties.

I cannot refrain from repeating, Sir, that failure to receive any grant for these children has inflicted a very severe hardship on our Society, and I earnestly hope the matter may now receive the sympathetic consideration it deserves, and that our generous offer may be immediately accepted.

Dear Canon Gould:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, setting forth your understanding of an interview with myself on the 7th instant, regarding the situation brought about through the erection, by your Society, of a residential school at Aklavik, North West Territories, to accommodate the Indian and Eskimo children from the lower Mackenzie Valley.

As agreed in my letter to you of May 14th, 1935, grant is being provided for a total of 50 pupils at Hay River, as from April first, 1937. In the event of the residential school at Hay River being continued for approximately 15 children from that neighbourhood, the Indian pupilage that can be provided for at the new school at Aklavik will be 35 children, or, the total number for which grant can be provided at both schools is 50 pupils. Payment of the grant to Aklavik could begin as from the time the pupils now at Hay River have been transferred to that school.

The Department would favourably consider continuing the residential school at Hay River for the benefit of the Anglican Indian children in that neighbourhood and provide grant for approximately 15 pupils - it being understood, however, as all the buildings in question at this point are owned by your Society, that the Society will be responsible for the entire cost of any reconstruction or repairs.

Jan. 20, 1936

Dear Dr. McGill:

Re: Residential School at Hay River, N.W.T.

May I express to you my sincere thanks and the deep gratitude of the Diocese of Athabasca in planning to continue the School and Hospital at Hay River on Great Slave Lake. The closing of this school would have left the Protestant Indians from the Arctic Circle to Fort Chipewyan without a school for their children. I know how delighted our missionaries and the Indians will be to hear the good news that it will not be closed. I trust that its continuation will be justified by the use which will be made of it, and that it will continue to be a great blessing to man, children, in mind and body and soul.

As Bishop of the Diocese of Athabasca and as one trying to help the Indians of the Mackenzie Valley in every way, I wish to thank you sincerely. May I assure you of my loyal co-operation in every way.

With every good wish to you in this new year of 1936.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

[A.W. Sovereign]
Bishop

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on a visit to the Church of England School at Hay River.

I found that most of the children attending this institution are from the McPherson reserve. Of course school was not on when I was there, but I saw a great many of the children that were still there, and was informed that on the last boat 26 children are being sent North, 6 of whom are leaving school and 20 are going to the school at Aklavik when it is opened. The Principal informed me that he was more or less in the dark as to what would take place, as when the McPherson children were taken to Aklavik they would not have enough children to keep the present school going, and he thought His Lordship, the Bishop, intended making different arrangements so that the children remaining there would receive some training.

I saw all the children that were in residence there, and was very well pleased with their appearance and also with their work. I believe these children have been getting a very good training, as they have been taught only what would be of

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
HAY RIVER C. E. SCHOOL (Continued).—
use to them when they left school. The boys have been allowed to do a certain amount of hunting and fishing, which is, in my opinion, a very good idea.

The school has maintained a good garden, and have sown 11 acres to oats and hay. They have 5 cows and calves and two horses and some chickens. I walked over the garden, and found it to be well cared for.

They have a small hospital in conjunction with the school, and I believe the nurse is paid by the Department, although I was not advised of this.

There are two crippled women there who will no doubt remain there until they die, and I am glad to know that we have a place for people in such a state, who cannot help themselves, and would be left to die unless they were taken care of by someone.

The staff at the school consists of three ladies and three men, including the Principal and his wife.

I know the Department have often felt that it was a waste of money to maintain this institution but after seeing it and learning what I did on this trip, I believe the effort and money expended have been justified. I would refer you to my report on the work carried on by the Church at Aklavik.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,
