Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 28th instant and also copies of telegraphic communications that have passed between you and the Reverend H. G. Cook, of Fort Simpson, enclosed therewith.

I note that it is your intention to operate an Indian day school, rather than a residential school, at Hay River, on the understanding that the Department will pay per capita grant on an enrolment of 50 pupils at the Aklavik Residential School. This is the first intimation we have had of this change. We would like to have a letter indicating the exact date on which this change will take place.

I can see no serious objection to the payment of a per capita grant for 50 pupils at Aklavik, if the school at Hay River is operated as a day school and if the pupils in attendance at Aklavik are drawn from the immediate neighbourhood of the school. I cannot convince myself that the practice of transporting Indian children hundreds of miles to a residential school is a wise one. In addition to this, I am not at all satisfied with the course of instruction provided at Indian residential schools in the North West Territories. F. W. Head, M.D., Indian Agent, Fort Norman, in a letter to the Department dated July 9th, states:

"The one complaint of the Indians that I have to draw to the attention of the Department is the question of school instruction. They claim their children are taught nothing useful to them in their mode of living and that when they come home they are useless for work in the bush. Some even go so far as to state that they will not let their children return to school."

Rev. T.H.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.B.C.C.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave., Winnipeg, Man.
It is my understanding that certain church authorities have given this matter a great deal of study and hope to submit to the Department for consideration a revised curriculum for their northern schools in the immediate future.

In view of these comments, I can only express regret that it was considered necessary to send the Grossetete children to Aklavik. I do not know that there is anything we can do about it now that they have been sent, other than ask that these children be returned to Fort Simpson at the end of the school year.

The records indicate that we are making a contribution of approximately $600.00 to the salary of a teacher at Fort Simpson.

The mother of these children, it is true, may experience considerable difficulty in providing them with the food and clothing necessary to enable them to take advantage of the local day school facilities. In this respect, however, the children do not differ from hundreds of other children throughout the Dominion. The appeal of an Indian agent for relief allowances for a family such as this is always sympathetically considered by the Department.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Heey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of the 31st ultimo has come to hand, and I am forwarding a copy of the same to the Rev. Canon S. Gould, General Secretary of our Society, in order that he may communicate with you direct in the matter of the operation of an Indian Day School at Hay River instead of the Residential School which closed on August 31st last. Your statement that you had not received any indication of this change until you received my letter of August 26th last, came as a surprise to me, as I had concluded from the following information embodied in Canon Gould's letter to me on March 23rd last that the proposed change had been mentioned and approved. His letter reads in part, as follows:-

"When in Ottawa a few days ago, I talked over the situation with Dr. McGill, Director of Indian Affairs; he agreed that, under the circumstances, we would be justified in sending at our expense the few pupils at Hay River, whose parents might not be satisfied with a Day School, down to the Alkivak Institution."

As Anglican Indian Day Schools do not come within the jurisdiction of our Commission, but are operated by the Diocese in which they are located, in collaboration with your Department, the Rt. Rev. Dr. A. H. Sovereign, Lord Bishop of Athabasca, proposed calling on you on his way to and from the recent meetings of our General Synod in Halifax. Through his visit and the further information you will receive from our General Secretary, any oversight on our part or misunderstanding in the matter, will, I feel sure, be fully and satisfactorily cleared up.

Your opinion that it is not wise to transport Indian children hundreds of miles to a Residential School, is shared by our Commission, and this is the chief reason why our Society
I have noted the complaint of the Indians, as reported by Dr. Head in his letter to your Department on July 9th, and beg to state that I am quite unable to accept their statement that, "their children are taught nothing useful to them in their mode of living, and that when they came home they were useless for work in the bush." The question is one of "vocational training" to which our Commission has given a great deal of attention, and while some progress has already been achieved in this direction, the facilities required have not, for lack of funds, been provided. Similar criticism to that embodied in Dr. Head's report was investigated by our Commission some years ago, more particularly with regard to the Indians in the northern areas of the country, and we were emphatically informed at that time, that the biggest catches of furs brought to the trading posts were brought by boys who had graduated from our Society's Schools. In the light of the information we received at the time of our investigation of this matter, we are unable to attach any great significance to the complaint Dr. Head reported.

On March 14th, 1925, your Department in a letter of that date, No. 1-1-10, advised us of four regulations recently adopted by the N.W.T. Council regarding the age limit for the discharge of pupils from Residential Schools in that part, and in those regulations provision was made for boys, 12 years of age, and in good physical condition, to be granted leave of absence during the hunting and trapping season. This regulation was made known to the principals of our Schools concerned, and has not, I feel sure been ignored, and any further regulations your Department may see fit to adopt along the same line will likewise be carefully observed.

I have noted your request that the two Grosstete children recently sent from Fort Simpson to Aklavik, be returned next year, and will submit the same to the members of our Commission at their next meeting.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Many thanks for your letter of August 3rd just received re Hay River Indian School.

I feel that Rev. S. E. Richards must have written those lines when he was badly discouraged. I do not agree with him at all in regard to these statements. As a matter of fact, as you are well aware, it is the policy of the Indian Department more and more to emphasize the policy of Day Schools. It is true that so many of these Indian families are nomadic during the winter but it is also true that more and more, families are remaining at central points. I still feel that the Residential School is the ideal but I also know that Day Schools also may do effective work.

You and I know quite well that the Indian children of today will be forced to go out into the world to compete with their white brothers as they grow to maturity. The fur-bearing animals will be forced further and further north and trapping will not be the source of sustenance for our Indian Wards. It is therefore the responsibility of the Government and of every citizen in Canada to do his and her part to see that these children receive an education according to their capacity,—reading, writing and arithmetic. They cannot be good citizens without it.

I am writing to Mr. Richards at Hay River and have asked him to give greater attention to this Day School. I have tried to point out to him its importance and I feel quite sure that he will do his utmost to see that this School is kept up to a high standard. I have even suggested that he should in the mornings go to the Indian huts and wake up the families and literally take the children to school. I know that has frequently
been done in other parts of the North. The Indian parents do not realize how important education will be to their children in days to come. I will await an answer to my letter from Rev. S. E. Richards and will report to you at once on receipt of his letter.

May I ask for my own information if your Department will allow the half-breeds and white pupils to attend the School at the same time. Will your Department make any special grant towards this school work on behalf of the whites and half-breeds? Our Government, which includes us all, surely should be responsible for the education of children, whether white, half-breed or Indian, within the Northwest Territories. For example, at Fort Smith a grant of $500.00 per year was given to our Church towards the salary of a qualified teacher who would teach the white children as well. Would not this come under a similar plan?

May I thank you for writing to me in regard to the above School.

With every good wish and with many thanks,

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

As a matter of fact, the children do what they wish and come and go as they please. There is practically no discipline whatever in the Indian homes. However the fact that seventeen children have been reached is most commendable. As the wave of development moves Northward, more and more these children have need of education; otherwise the results will be disastrous. They should be taught to read and write and do common arithmetic and should also have a knowledge of Canadian geography and democratic institutions.

You are quite right in your statement that Nurse Neville is in charge of the little outpost Nursing Home at this point and serves these people faithfully in time of sickness and accident. Might I humbly suggest to your Department that an honorarium might be paid to Nurse Neville of one-half of that which was paid to Rev. S. J. Richards.

I heartily approve of her plan and gladly confirm the plan.

With every good wish and with many thanks, believe me,

Yours faithfully,

Re: Day-school at Hay River

I am submitting herewith copy of a letter from a resident of Hay River requesting the establishment of a day-school and enclosing the results of a survey of school-age children in the area.

On October 7th I inspected the facilities with respect to education at Hay River, and found the residents very desirous for a school. Later en route to Providence I again visited Hay River and made a further investigation. On this occasion the mission priest assured me that if a day school was established he would co-operate fully in seeing that the children of his faith attended, provided that provision was made for religious instruction. I informed him that such provision would be made.

Mr. Rogers, manager of the airport, offered to assist in setting up a school by supervising the repair of one large room in the existing unused vacant school building and wiring same for electricity. This room is approximately 36 feet by 24 feet, and has six large windows on the south side. It also is equipped with a large blackboard on two sides, and there are some desks available.

In view of the religious factor involved, it would be advisable for the Government to either purchase the existing school building from the Anglican authorities, or lease the building and install a teacher of the Roman Catholic faith.

As there are approximately forty children who...
are potential attenders, the proposed school-room can readily be partitioned into two rooms, if required. Provision has been made in the 1947-48 estimates for the employment of two teachers and the supplying of necessary classroom requirements.

It is emphasized that the above is to be regarded only as a temporary expedient to meet the immediate requirements of the residents and until the situation has clarified.

Encl.

Hay River Day School

The following proposals were made concerning the above school at a recent meeting of educational officials of the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs and the Indian Affairs Branch,

(a) that the Indian Affairs Branch operate this school,

(b) that whites and half-breeds also attend with the payment of a per capita grant being made for them by the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs,

(c) that whilst this is a one-room school the teacher's position should be alternated between one of Church of England belief and Roman Catholic belief (the limit of such tenure of office being three years),

(d) that if this becomes a two-room school, one teacher shall be Church of England and the other Roman Catholic,

(e) that religious instruction can be conducted by a Church of England minister or a Roman Catholic priest or by any person duly authorized by such clergyman or by a teacher when so authorized during the last thirty minutes of the teaching day,

(f) that if school accommodation does not permit of the pupils being placed in separate rooms for the purpose of religious teaching, provision shall be made by the

Inspector of Schools whereby the time allotted for religious teaching of Church of England children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days in each month, and the religious teaching of the Roman Catholic children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days of each month,

(e) that no separation of pupils by religious denominations shall take place during the secular school work,

(h) that no pupils shall be permitted to be present at any religious teaching unless the parents or guardians of such pupils desire it. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Thanks so much for your letter of February 14th just received in relation to the Day School at Hay River. Your outline of the plans is most concise and clear, and I think the whole plan is feasible and fair to all concerned.

There is certainly a great need for a well-operated school at Hay River, N.W.T. We have now left behind us the earlier stages of life along the Mackenzie Valley. We have passed the period in which our Missionaries were called upon to take charge of the School and perform all of their other duties. Moreover, Hay River will immediately become a very important settlement beginning this year. It is the terminus of the Great North Road, and already a community of white people is unfolding there. We are receiving requests for land and Lots continually. I venture to say it will become the most important settlement north of Fort Smith, with the exception of Yellowknife. Already several white families are living there, and their children, along with the Metis and native children, should be adequately cared for. I may add that apart from the aeroplane service from Edmonton via Fort Smith, there is a regular plane service from Peace River to Lower Hay three times per week through the C.F.A.

There is just one point which does not seem to be clear, and that is the question as to whether the Indian Affairs Branch will erect the school, or will this be left to someone else.

May I thank you and the Indian Affairs Branch for your letter and for this information in reference to a definite step forward in the adequate provision for the education of the children at Hay River.

With every good wish, believe me,

Yours faithfully,

Hay River Day School

There formerly existed at Hay River a residential school, operated by the Church of England. This school has now been closed for some years and it is now our intention to re-open it as a day school. Mr. J. W. McKinnon, Inspector of Schools for the Northwest Territories, recently visited this school. After discussing the situation with Bishop Sovereign, of the Church of England, and Bishop Trocellier, of the Roman Catholic Church, the following proposals were sent to each of these gentlemen as the basis for the operation of this school:

(a) That the Indian Affairs Branch operate this school.

(b) That whites and half-breeds also attend with the payment of a per capita grant being made for them by the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs.

(c) That whilst this is a one-room school, the teacher should be chosen on the basis of qualifications and experience, the school to be conducted along non-denominational lines.

(d) That if this becomes a two-room school, it might be advisable to choose a second teacher from the other religious denomination.

(e) That religious instruction can be conducted by a Church of England minister or a Roman Catholic priest or by any person duly authorized by such
clergyman or by a teacher when so authorized during the last thirty minutes of the teaching day.

(f) That if school accommodation does not permit of the pupils being placed in separate rooms for the purpose of religious teaching, provision shall be made by the Inspector of Schools whereby the time allotted for religious teaching of Church of England children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days in each month, and the religious teaching of the Roman Catholic children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days of each month.

(g) That no separation of pupils by religious denominations shall take place during the secular school work.

(h) That no pupils shall be permitted to be present at any religious teaching unless the parents or guardians of such pupils desire it. If the parents or guardians do not desire the attendance of pupils during such religious teaching, then such pupils shall be dismissed before the religious teaching is begun, or shall remain in another room.

(i) That Bishop Sovereign of the Diocese of Athabasca be approached regarding these proposals and the amount of rent he would wish for use of the former Hay River Residential School.

(j) That Bishop Trocellier, Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie, be approached regarding the above proposals.

Both Bishop Sovereign and Bishop Trocellier were written in this regard and I attach for your information copies of the answers which have been received from both these Bishops.

It is now our intention to proceed with the opening of this school. From Mr. McKinnon we have the information that Mr. Roger of Hay River is willing to have the necessary repairs...
and alterations made as soon as possible. We are informed that Mr. Roger is a Department of Transport employee at Hay River and that he is anxious to co-operate in every way with the operation of this school.

It is intended that the Indian Affairs Branch will operate and pay for this school. This is because of the fact that the majority of the pupils will be Indians. However, we intend to put in qualified teachers and good equipment and will expect that White and half-breed children will attend.

I have tried to give you as complete a picture as possible for your files, so that you will be fully aware of our policy in regard to the maintenance and operation of this school. Therefore, will you kindly contact Mr. Roger and let us have an estimate of (a) the cost of the labour and (b) the cost of the materials required for the opening of this school.

Sir:

I have been in receipt of your letter of the 25th February for some time now and it has been my intention to write to you earlier but this has been impossible for reasons I shall outline below.

The four copies enclosed with your letter of the St. Johns Ambulance magazine have been forwarded to the school and should prove quite useful.

Now for a short report on the school and its progress. The school opened immediately all the lesson plans and texts were received from the Dept. of Education, Alberta. These, I wish to point out, came via C.P. airlines very promptly and additional lesson plans and texts have been received since from time to time.

The last two weeks of January saw the school in operation and it has been steadily maintained since five days weekly from one to four o'clock P.M., giving the pupils a 15 hour school week plus their home study assignments. To date I have supervised the work and the marking of all test papers and very satisfactory progress has been made. Only seven (7) pupils are attending as it has been impossible to consider a larger number due to the limited accommodation and the absolute lack of fuel.

Mr. Camsell of the Dept. of Mines and Resources, whom I understand you met whilst you were here, has loaned one room of his house for the school and provides the fuel for heating purposes.

For the last five weeks I have been unable to carry on with the work due to pressure of my own work. A new radio station building was shipped in over the winter road and erected at the end of February. This has necessitated the move of the complete station, plus redecorating, etc., and has been a great drain on my available time.
In this connection I was very fortunate in securing the services of Mrs. Amy Kraus, a housewife of this settlement, who has carried on in a very satisfactory manner for this last mentioned period. She is a woman of about forty years of age and has, herself, a reasonably good education which she has apparently supplemented with reading and discussion. She has shown a natural flair for teaching work and is well liked by all the children. She has good control of the classes and is especially capable with the younger children.

Mrs. Kraus has asked me to approach you with regard to her opportunity to secure a permanent teaching position with the Department when the school is erected here this coming fall. Or, should a school not be erected, (which would be very unfortunate in view of the groundwork we have both put in), she would be willing to carry on this same type of school next year at a salary.

She is so interested in the work that she is willing to go "outside" this summer and take a course in teaching methods in Edmonton. I would be very pleased if you would write to me suggesting any such course that may exist. Mrs. Kraus is willing to undertake such a course entirely at her own expense if given any encouragement with reference to teaching employment here in the future. I have no hesitation whatsoever in fully recommending this offer for full consideration.

The seven children attending the school have set up an attendance record which rivals that of any school I have ever seen. Only about two absentee days have been recorded both due to sickness.

It has been quite a problem grading these children as some are of Grade 6 standing in Reading and Writing and only Grade 3 standard in Arithmetic. The next will be an exactly opposite case. However, we have now succeeded in grading them all and they are progressing quickly since, due to the small number involved, instruction almost amounts to personal, private instruction. The teacher appointed to teach school here should find his or her work much easier for this.

Any suggestions you may have to offer will always be appreciated and I would like to hear what you think of the offer made by Mrs. Kraus so that I may pass the information along to her. We are both going to carry on when I get back to the school shortly until the end of June. However, due to construction work and the installation of new equipment planned for this radio station in the coming year,
it will be impossible for me to carry on the school work on any basis other than supervision next year.

I hope that this interim report of how this venture is going will prove both interesting and informative to you and that you will take the trouble to reply to my questions in the near future. In the meantime, I remain,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of March 10th, regarding the opening of an Indian School at Hay River, I discussed the matter with Mr. Roger on my last trip to Hay River and also with Mr. Dean and several other residents of that post. All were of the opinion that the present building which was used as residential school is entirely beyond repair, and that it would cost more to fix it up than it would to erect a new building.

I have heard that a very serviceable school has been built at Fort McPherson, based on the modern style, with adequate lighting and other facilities. I am of the opinion that Hay River should now merit such a school, in view of the fact that possible tourists and others of the general public from the provinces will visit the settlement and a modern school would show them the interest taken by the government in the welfare of the children in this new community.

Another factor which I would like to draw to your attention is the widely scattered plan of the settlement, which should receive some consideration when choosing the site of the school in order to have a central location, so that the children will not have to
walk long distances during severe winter weather.

The prospects of a day school has been met with enthusiasm by all residents, Indians, whites and half-breeds, and I would appreciate your comments on the foregoing, and after receipt of same further investigation into the matter will be made as the facts warrant.

Hay River School

"I have wired Ottawa indicating that there are about 70 children of school age at Hay River and a school is greatly needed. I indicated that Mr. Peter Mattson, head foreman of the new Yellowknife Hotel, was at Hay River and said he would provide the materials to build a 4-roomed school and residence at a cost of $50,000. The reply from Colonel Neary was that a supplementary estimate of $50,000 had been approved.

"The plans arrived at Yellowknife on Friday, July 18th, and were discussed with Mr. McNiven and Mr. Lindstrom. Mr. McNiven had a little time to spare, hoping to scan the plans, and he expressed the opinion that Mr. Mattson should not get a cent more than $35,000. Following this, I spent five or six hours with Mr. William Lindstrom, engineer and superintendent of the new Yellowknife Hotel, and, in Mr. McNiven's opinion, the finest and keenest builder in the country.

"There are approximately 300,000 cubic feet in the new Yellowknife School, which means that it is costing about 50¢ per cubic foot. We expect to follow the plans as submitted, but to eliminate the basement, as has been done with the new Yellowknife school. The building will be placed on cement pillars sunk to permanent frost level. The building will be lowered 12 inches off grading, and the stairs and halls will be eliminated from the basement.

"The capacity of the school is about 36,000 cubic feet, which at 50¢ per cubic foot would approximate $18,000. The residence is about 16,000 cubic feet, which would approximate $8,000; thus the total cost would be about $27,000. However, Mr. Lindstrom felt that, should the building cost $51,000 or $32,000, we would be getting it done reasonably and that at that price the following features should be included in the contract:

1. School placed on cement pillars at least 9' down in the ground and 18" above ground;
2. Eliminate the fireplace in the residence;"
3. Place accordion doors and false studding between the two rooms, making them convertible into an auditorium or community hall;

4. Put in a pressure system, i.e., a well under the building with a 2,000 gallon tank and feed water to the school for flush toilets, sinks and hot water system;

5. Supply Delco light plant - 32 volt D.C. and 110 volt A.C.;

6. Install cess-pool and two inside toilets;

7. Put built-in cupboards in each room and supply table for each;

8. There should be maple flooring in the rooms.

"Peter Mattson will be sending me in tomorrow's mail, I expect, a letter promising to do the above at $32,000. We have agreed that this is fair.

"He has also promised at that price to install sand boxes and ice-slide, swings, testers, etc.

"It is imperative that this school get under way as the people at Hay River were ready to rebel when I landed - they thought the plans had fallen through.

"We must speed it along and get Mattson going this next week, if possible. He could have the school opened by September.

Fort Rae School

"On Thursday, July 17th, I visited Fort Rae to discuss the proposition suggested in Colonel Neary's wire regarding renting the Buffam property at $50 per month with the option to buy. This Mr. Buffam agrees to, providing the government guarantees to purchase the property by the 1st May. This should be done."
"The residence alone is worth $8,000 today. The store would make an ideal classroom. The Roman Catholic priest intimated that hospital space could be used as dormitory facilities for perhaps twelve children during the first year. George Burfam is honest and promised to hold the property for a week or so. If the property is leased, the government should take the 55 cords of wood, which would heat all the buildings for the first winter. Oil cannot be had. The school supplies and equipment for about thirty children should be forwarded, together with a 45-gallon drum of naphtha oil, as the wind charger is not always sufficient for the lights. Radio batteries are also required."

Mr. Meikle

Res: Hay River.

I visited Hay River on June 9th and discussed educational needs with the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company, the Roman Catholic priest, Miss Neville of the Anglican Mission, representatives of the R.C.G.S., and many others. In the evening I was invited to attend a meeting of all the Indians at this settlement. They requested that they be provided with a government-operated day school, informed me that there were over 70 children of school age in the vicinity, and stated that it was possible there would be over 100 by the fall of the year.

I visited the homes of the community which, in many instances, left much to be desired. There is need of a housing programme at this settlement, together with considerable adult education.

As Hay River is in a good farming area I am of the opinion that considerable emphasis should be placed on agriculture. The Indians here are trying to make gardens by means of dog power which is not any too suitable. If a small gasoline tractor could in some manner be made available for their use, it would materially assist them in their efforts.

MEMORANDUM TO MR. R.A. HOEY

Re - Conversation with Bishop Trocellier and Father Plourde

This morning I talked with these two gentlemen for an hour and a quarter, chiefly about conditions in the Northwest Territories.

At a suitable moment in the conversation I brought up the question of the Hay River school. They expressed the opinion that there are really not enough children in the Hay River district to justify the building of a two-roomed school. They said that most of the Indian children who constitute the greater majority would be with their parents forty or fifty miles down the highway during the winter. On being pressed about the proposed arrangement for a single school with a Catholic and a Protestant teacher and with a period assigned at the end of each day for religious instruction they said:

(a) That this is contrary to the policy of the church, but

(b) That they would be willing to accept it as a temporary expedient on the understanding that the senior teacher would be a Catholic. They base their argument on the assertion that three-quarters of the children would be Catholic. They did not insist that the children be divided vertically into two classes.

It seems to me that the necessity for building a school should be re-considered, but if it is deemed that such a necessity exists, then we should go ahead with the plan as at present envisaged, with the understanding that an effort will be made to find a senior teacher of the Catholic faith to act as principal.

In the course of the discussion Bishop Trocellier asked that a new residential school be built at Fort Resolution, or if this should be impossible, that a four-roomed class-room building be erected. He asked for a second fire escape on the school at Providence. (This in my opinion should be provided at once). He also asked for a new four-roomed class-room building at Aklavik.

Dear Sir,

After mature consideration, I must rectify the position which I took during the interview which you gave Reverend Father Plourde and myself regarding the proposed establishment of a school for Catholic white and Indian children at Hay River. I did not then intend to discuss that question and I may have left you under a misconception as regards the elementary requirements concerning the education of Catholic children.

It must be understood that all Catholic children are to be under the exclusive care or direction of Catholic teachers and placed in separate class-rooms. All text books in use in all schools must be approved by the Catholic Church authorities. Therefore, it now appears clear to me that your project cannot be implemented.

It has always been and will always be the policy of the Catholic Church to provide special and separate schools for the children under her care, and I see no other way of safeguarding the principles of the Catholic Church in matters of education. She has never abandoned any of her rights in this sphere.

Therefore, Catholic schools having been guaranteed by law for the Northwest Territories I cannot accept any substitute for them for the children under my spiritual guidance and I hereby ask the Northwest Territory Council to provide such schools whenever they are needed. The combination which you suggested cannot be thought of and must not be implemented in any part of the Northwest Territories.

Hoping that the above statement will clarify my position in the matter of Catholic education, I remain, dear sir,

Keenleyside,

Very truly yours,

Hay River

It is expected that the village of Hay River will, on the completion of the highway from Grimshaw, become an important community. Fishing at Hay River is exceptionally good, the people always have sufficient to eat. Because of the good fishing several companies offer employment to Indians during the winter months. Up to the present additional employment with highway construction gangs has been available but I understand that since the Indian is not a reliable worker, there is a growing tendency to import white labour.

The Indians at Hay River have called for less action on my part than those in any other settlement. Miss Neville of the Anglican Mission attends to most of their medical problems, although she can do nothing about the Tuberculosis situation. There is a need, however, for a new modern nursing station at this community. Constable D. Allan of the R.C.M. Police handles the distribution of Indian welfare rations; his assistance is greatly appreciated.

Although the Indians at Hay River are better off financially than those of Fort Resolution since they have a greater opportunity for employment, their houses and persons are not as clean.

Dear Mr. Douglas:

I have for answer your letter of July 27 and wish to advise you that we would be prepared to hire both your wife and yourself. There is a considerable settlement of Whites in the Hay River community besides the intended school staff; in fact there is a Royal Canadian Signal Corps station and the headquarters of trucking firms who are using Hay River as the northern terminus of the Grimshaw highway. Transportation is by this new highway from Edmonton or by air from Edmonton.

There is a Roman Catholic Missionary at Hay River, but I cannot advise you as to whether he is permanently stationed there. However, in view of the fact that it is anticipated that Hay River will be the second largest town (next to Yellowknife) in the Territories, it is presumed one will be stationed there permanently.

I cannot advise you with regard to the Doctor but hospital facilities are available at both Fort Resolution and Fort Providence. While the school will be a four-roomed one, we do not expect to have more than two teachers for the first year. As the town grows, other members will be added to the staff. Attention - Colonel Neary

Adverting to discussions over the telephone with Colonel Neary, I may say that I referred to District Administrator Fred Fraser the report which Reverend Father Plourde had sent me about a discussion which Mr. Fraser had with the Hay River Board of Trade. A copy of Mr. Fraser's personal and confidential reply is attached.

I called Father Plourde on the telephone and gave him the substance of what Mr. Fraser had reported to me. Father Plourde expressed regret that Mr. Fraser should have seen fit to discuss with the local Board of Trade a matter which was obviously controversial, without first referring to the department and getting direction. Father Plourde then went on to say that the Roman Catholic Church is of the opinion that it would not be an acceptable solution of the situation to have Roman Catholics taught in one room of the public school and the Protestants taught in another room. He considers that a separate building is required. I explained the difficulties of the situation at some length and said that it seemed to be the opinion of the departmental officers concerned with education in the Northwest Territories that children could be taught together, irrespective of religious persuasion, provided there was a time reserved at the beginning or the end of the day - or at some other convenient time - for the giving of religious instruction, and also that the principal of each school was of the religious denomination of the majority of the children and the other teacher was of the faith of the minority. However, I indicated that the subject would be discussed again at a meeting of the Subcommittee on Education which will be held tomorrow. Father Plourde asked me to have read at that meeting the recent letter written by Bishop Trocellier.

Colonel Neary and I have been discussing this matter and we believe that, as there is only a limited time for the discussions of the Subcommittee, it is quite unnecessary to go into
the argument about what Mr. Fraser said to the Board of Trade. We believe that we should spend our time deciding what instructions should be given to the school teacher who has written you for direction. As the school has been established by your branch, I would suggest that either yourself or Colonel Neary lead the discussion on this subject. Mr. Lamberton has been asked to put an item on the agenda.

R.A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Dear Sir,

I have your communication of the 27th January and in reply may say that letters mailed by you at Hay River addressed to the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources at Ottawa are not entitled to free transmission in the mails, but must be prepaid at the rate of four cents for the first ounce and two cents for each additional ounce or fraction thereof unless you desire the item to be accorded complete air transport to destination, in which case the postage required would be 7¢ for the first ounce and 5¢ for each additional ounce or fraction thereof.

I may explain that the franking privilege applies only to correspondence on official business mailed by Federal Government Departments at Ottawa addressed to persons or firms receiving their mail at post offices which are served by ordinary surface conveyance.

In the case of post offices such as Hay River, North West Territories, which is served entirely by air, the free privilege does not apply, and any letters, therefore, mailed by you addressed to Federal Government Departments at Ottawa would require postage at the rates mentioned in the first paragraph of my communication.

Similarly letters mailed by Government Departments at Ottawa addressed to you at Hay River would also have to be prepaid in the same manner.

I am sending a copy of this letter to the Postmaster at Hay River for his information.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Attached, herewith, are monthly Day School returns for the Hay River Indian Day School. You will note that one copy is for the Northwest Territory Administration files and the other two copies are to be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch for their information and retention.

You will note that Mr. Believance listed on the attached form all Indian children as being absent and the reason for same is given as their desire for a separate school on the island. In this connection, you might refer to my recent report on the Hay River Indian Day School. It should be borne in mind that initially the Indians of Hay River asked for the organization of the new school and indicated their desire for same by a signed petition. I am inclined to the view that both Mr. Believance and the local Priest are the parties desiring the separate school on the island and not the illiterate Indians.

Had Mr. Believance desired the attendance of the Indian children, he would have visited their homes and solicited their support. There is absolutely no need for a separate school in Hay River as the present building

........2
will meet the needs of the community for at least many years to come. There is a need, however, of implementing compulsory attendance within the Hay River Local Administrative District Unit, and, for the enforcement of same, a truant officer.

There are some 60 children living within the Hay River Local Administrative District and a number is being added each week. Therefore, there is only one method of operating the school efficiently, that is by the enforcement of regular attendance of those living in the immediate vicinity of the settlement. When children live permanently in a settlement, I can see no good reason for irregular school attendance and this is the case at Hay River.

Yours very truly,

'sgd' J. W. McKinnon,

For your information and comment, if necessary, I am attaching herewith copy of letter dated August 3d from District Engineer W. J. Johnston concerning the rates of wages paid to Mr. Obermuller, caretaker at Hay River school, up to July 22nd.

R. BLAIS
CHIEF ENGINEER.
In the construction of the four-classroom day school and teacherage at Hay River, N.W.T., during the past year, it was necessary to retain the services of a janitor who would also act in the capacity of watchman. This arrangement became effective February 22, 1949, when work was suspended under Mr. Peter Mattson, contractor. Mr. Frank Obermuller had been engaged on the job for some time under Mr. Mattson and his services were continued in this joint watchman and janitor service. The rate of wages for workmen under the contract had been approved while the project was under the control of the Department of Mines and Resources, and the same wage scale was continued during the time (after June 1, 1948) when the Department of Public Works had supervision of the work. Mr. Obermuller was willing to remain on duty after the contract had been terminated, providing he received approximately the same pay as he was receiving when work was proceeding under the contractor. During the time the work was going on under the contractor, Mr. Obermuller received the benefit of board deductions at $1.25 per day.

Since February 22, 1949, Mr. Obermuller has been engaged as follows:

- Watchman - rate per month: $150.00
- Board Allowance - per month: $75.00

Total: $225.00

This is the equivalent of $2,700.00 per year.

School session started on July 15th, and Mr. Obermuller has temporarily terminated his services with the Department as of July 22nd. Mr. Obermuller has been in the office and advises me that the teacher at Hay River informed him he would only be allowed $2,300.00 per year if he remained as watchman of the school when the administration was taken over by the Department of Education in the Northwest Territories. He is unwilling to lose this $400.00 per year, but states he would continue at work if he received the same pay as he had received from this Department (Public Works).

Our carpenter forces are completing work on the school project at Hay River, and it is expected work will be finished before school opens, presumably around September 1st. Thus, within the next month this school project will not be under the control of this Department, and its administration will, presumably, be under the Department of Education.

I am writing at this time to draw this situation to your attention as the school buildings at Hay River are rather important structures and it is very necessary that a competent watchman with some general mechanical knowledge be available in order to operate the oil furnace, electric generator and other mechanical equipment.
Mr. Obermuller claims to have worked for some years as a journeyman electrician, although I have only his own word for this. His services while under this Department at Hay River are reported to be satisfactory.

I would suggest this matter be brought to the attention of Col. Bernard F. Neary, Department of Education, Indian Affairs Branch. If I should have drawn this letter to the attention of someone in the Northwest Territories rather than to Col. Neary direct, I would be glad to be supplied with the name of the party concerned.

W. J. Johnston,

Ottawa, September 15, 1949.

Major MacKay, Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,

As promised in our telephone conversation this morning I am sending you herewith:

(1) A copy of a letter dated the 6th instant received from Mr. J. W. McKinnon, Superintendent of Education for the Mackenzie District, to which is attached a copy of one dated the 29th ultimo written him by Mr. W. A. Bowerman, Principal of the Indian Day School at Hay River on the subject of religious instruction.

(2) A copy of a letter dated the 26th of July written to me by Mr. McKinnon to which is attached a copy of one dated the 5th idem written him by Archdeacon D. B. Marsh.

As you are aware the Northwest Territories Council has approved of a manual of instructions to school teachers and mimeographed copies of this manual are being mailed now. This manual does not deal definitely with the matter of religious instruction although this subject has been discussed at a number of meetings of the sub-committee of the Northwest Territories Council on education. I am under the impression that the reason why no definite instruction was issued about religious instruction is because the Indian Act seems to contemplate religious instruction of some kind whereas the Northwest Territories Ordinance is not so definite on the subject and, in fact, there was an opinion that a child should not be compelled to take religious instruction against the wishes of the parents. In fact it was proposed for the Northwest Territories schools that there should be an alternative to religious instruction in the form of some non-religious but cultural study or exercise.

The records of the sub-committee seem to indicate that the opinion about religious instruction in the schools run by the Northwest Territories Administration could be summed up about as follows:
Should any element of a community desire it, the last half-hour of the school day can be devoted to religious instruction. The parents of a child will determine whether the child shall receive instruction from a Roman Catholic Priest or a Protestant Clergyman, or, for that matter, no religious instruction whatever. The principal of the school will make arrangements for the convenience of the reverend gentlemen who will conduct the religious exercises. Those children who are not being given religious instruction will remain at school but their time will be occupied with special studies prescribed by the principal and in this connection musical appreciation, current events, visual education, handicrafts, vocational training and subjects in related fields are suggested for consideration. All teachers will remain on duty until 4 P.M. each day.

However, as I said before, no definite order has been issued and no doubt there will be further discussion on the subject. The fact that religious instruction is one of the features that will probably be dealt with in the Indian Act to be considered at the present session of Parliament, seems to indicate that the issuance of an item for the manual of instructions to teachers might be delayed for a while. However, I take it that when Mr. Bellevance was acting as Principal of Hay River School you gave him some instruction on this subject although it is possible that he did not leave these instructions on file for his successor.

No doubt you will be discussing this subject with our Deputy Minister and I shall be glad indeed to receive a copy of the letter you write to Principal Bowerman so that we may advise Superintendent McKinnon and also have the information available for the next meeting of the sub-committee on education.

R. A. Gibson,
Director.

Dear Sir:

Attached herewith is copy of letter from Archdeacon D. B. Marsh.

It appears that there would be considerable value in dismissing school at 3:30 p.m. for purposes of having the children go to the Church for religious instruction. This policy is followed at Fort Rae and could easily be put into effect in the Mackenzie District as the Church is in the centre of most settlements. This policy would remove the common criticism that there is too much religion in the school.

This letter is submitted for your information and in the hope that there may be some future solution to this problem.

Dear Sir:

In answer to your enquiry re the June Quarter school report for the Hay River Day School for last year,

May I point out that the Indians went out into the bush for their spring hunt and took the children with them so that there were not enough children left in the fort to hold school and for that reason no school was held and no report sent in.

In view of the possibility of a recurrence of the same thing this spring would it be better for me to send in a report even when no school is taught.

AIR MAIL.

Ottawa, January 6th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of the returns which you forwarded for the Hay River Day School for the quarters ended September 30th and December 31st, 1940. A cheque will be issued in favour of the teacher for the four months in these two quarters.

However, I wish to draw your attention to circular letter of May 10th, 1940, a copy of which is enclosed. You will note from this that between April 1st, 1940, and March 31st, 1941, provision is made for only nine months' salary for each teacher of an Indian day school. Mr. Richards was paid for three months in the June quarter and four months in the September and December quarters, making a total of seven months for which he has received salary. Consequently, we can only pay for two months in the March quarter.

If Mr. Richards so desires, the school may be closed for either the month of February or March, 1941.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. J. H. Riepel,
Indian Agent,
Fort Resolution, N.W.T.

Ottawa, February 7, 1945.

Dr. J. H. Riopel, Indian Agent,
Fort Resolution, N.W.T.

I am in receipt of the return for the December quarter showing attendance of children at Hay River, and it is noted that this is signed by Winifred Neville.

Right Reverend A. H. Sovereign, Bishop of Athabasca, wrote to the Department on August 10, 1944, suggesting that Miss Neville could teach the school and requesting information regarding what amount we could allow her for her services. In reply to that communication he was written as follows on August 24:

"I have your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the day school at Hay River.

Very careful consideration has been given to your suggestion that Nurse Neville be allowed some remuneration for teaching the school for a short period during the past few months. I regret that as Nurse Neville is paid salary as a full-time nurse, present regulations do not permit our making a separate payment for her services in operating the school."

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Attention Mr. Philip Phelan.

Dear Sir,

I beg to report that Rev. S. M. Richards of Hay River sent me the attached requisition for books and other supplies to be used in connection with the day-school at Hay River.

I do not know if these supplies are purchased through the Department or by the Church of England Society, so I beg the Department to let me know of the usual procedure in this case that I may inform Mr. Richards.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Extract from Report of Inspector H.A. Conroy on the Boarding Schools in Treaty No. 8 and Mackenzie District. Dated December 18/11. Original on File 160370-19E.

HAY RIVER.

The Mission is situated on the east bank of the Hay river, about a quarter of a mile from its mouth. It is far enough back from Great Slave Lake to escape the sweep of wind and is further sheltered by a varied growth of fair-sized timber.

The school is an old building, the original log house has been added to from time to time to meet the steady increase of attendance. The result is not all that might be desired. The ceilings of the first two stories are low, the lighting is insufficient and the ventilation poor. The third story, however, is very much higher, having for ceiling the gable roof and the lighting and ventilation are extremely good. The ground floor of the original building consists of a large class room 22 x 17.7 x 8.5 a bedroom, study and rather dark stairs leading to the upper floor.

The accompanying snap-shot will show the locations of the several additions. A is the original main building, B containing kitchen and pantry, joins the main building at C. This latter contains a dining room 21.8 x 15.7 x 7; a pantry and small bedroom. The upper floor is one large room, used as an annex to the main dormitory. D is a single story lean-to, 22 x 18 x 8 at the low end, and is used as the main
Hay River, cont.

school room. It is well lighted and fairly ventilated.

It will be seen, however, that the numerous additions to the main building do not tend to make a convenient boarding school. I understand that Bishop Holmes intends tearing away the additions next summer, and erecting a new building adjoining the main one. When the new building is finished it will afford greatly increased accommodation; and I think the school will be entitled to a materially increased grant as soon as the wing is in operation. The present buildings will accommodate, in the class rooms floor space 785-49 pupils: cubic space 6478 - 25 pupils: and in the dormitories 1375 feet floor space, and cubic space 12,000 ft. 24 pupils. The present average attendance is 32.

There are four cellars, one 10 x 10 x 5.6, floored and walled in planks, one 8 x 8 x 5.6, walled in logs: one 9 x 9 x 5 walls and floor of planks: and one 10x 10 x 6, also walled and floored with planks. These serve as store rooms for vegetables etc.

The foundations of the buildings are wooden blocks. The walls are of substantial logs, lime plastered. The main building has a plank roof/ but the additions boast metallic shingles.

Five stoves are used for heating during the winter, oil lamps for the staff and candles for the pupils.

The water supply is obtained from the river; a pump is used in summer/ but two large holes are dug through the ice in winter. Barrels for storing water are conveniently situated.

There are no fire extinguishers, but pails are always kept filled and ready, and axes for emergencies are placed near the doors. In summer the garden hose is kept attached to the pump: a fire bell, is so situated that it can
be rung from either outside or inside the building, and can be heard as far as the Hudson's Bay store. Fire drill is regularly practised, and an excellent record has been established. In summer every pupil is outside the building in less than a minute. In winter the pupils, attired in sufficient clothing, are outside the building in less than three minutes. The older children are trained to assist the younger ones.

The class work follows pretty closely the regulations laid down by the Department. Besides this, there is considerable attention paid to the general practical knowledge so essential to the Indian boy or girl. The boys are taught the use of saw, axe and plane, and are kept at work until they are capable of erecting a house. They learn to haul and square logs, and set them in place. They learn general farm work; are proficient at breaking ground and tending it, and learn to milk and tend cattle. The Mission deserves to be highly commended for its practical and efficient work.

The latrines, three in number are all outside. New holes are dug every year. The outbuildings include a house for cleaning fish; for storing fish, with a cellar for ice; a shop, a tool house/stable, warehouse—a new building 2½ stories high; two woodsheds; staff's dwelling; church; 2 sled stores and an interpreters house. The stables are well away from the dwelling houses. All the outbuildings are in good repair.

There are nine or ten acres of land under cultivation as garden. This year the crop of potatoes amounted to over 1,000 bushels.

The Mission owns two milch cows, one bull, three calves. Young heifers are to be sent in in the spring. A horse formerly used for ploughing and hauling wood has strayed into the woods and has failed to be located.

I would recommend that the Department send in a few
Hay River concluded.

fire extinguishers. The school room needs some wall maps of Canada, and particularly of the North Country. A Globe would be very beneficial and Ogilvies and McConnell's charts of the North would be also useful.

Two dozen more slates, with pencils are needed. I would mention in connection with all the schools in my district, that when occasionally the annual reports from the Principals go astray, or are delayed, it is on account of the difficult and unreliable mail service.
Dear Sir,

I now write to ask you to furnish me with full details required to proceed with the erection of a new Indian Boarding School House at Hay River Great Slave Lake, to replace the one now in use.

I believe the late Bishop Holmes was in possession of such details, but owing to his death in England, they are not available just now, and as we can have things imported but once a year it is necessary for us to act at once or a year's delay must ensue.

May I therefore ask for an early reply to enable me to take immediate steps to secure the needed articles to be imported?

I am

Rev., Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo asking to be furnished with full details necessary to proceed with the erection of a new Indian boarding school at Hay River, Great Slave Lake.

In reply I beg to say that before the Department can deal intelligently with this matter it should know how many pupils you contemplate providing for and what amount of money will be available for the erection of the building. As the Department has no details as to the style of building the late Bishop Holmes contemplated putting up it would be glad if you would give full particulars as to what you think would be required and the Department will then endeavour to prepare plans which will meet your needs.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 170367/5 under date of April 4, 1912, I beg to say I also have no details as to the style of building the late Bishop Holmes contemplated putting up for the Indian Boarding School at Hay River.

We are anxious to erect a building which shall comply with the standard of Government requirements for such a school as will accommodate at least (40) forty children, male and female. We expect it to cost from $3,000.00 to $5,000.00. Much of this money will have to be paid out in freighting the necessary building materials into the country.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, and in reply I beg to say that, under separate cover, you are being sent two copies of the Correspondence and Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools.

The Department realizes that owing to the difficulty of transporting material it is not possible for you and others similarly situated in the northern country to erect modern buildings. It is necessary, however, to have the required air space both in the class-rooms and dormitories, which is 250 cubic feet per pupil in the former and 500 cubic feet in the latter. There should also be hospital accommodation for the isolation of pupils ill with infectious diseases. Outside water closets should be kept in a sanitary condition.

It is also possible to provide a certain amount of ventilation even in the most simply constructed buildings. In the class-room this can be provided by running a six or seven inch pipe, either galvanized iron or ordinary stove piping, from the stove pipe down to within six inches of the floor to sit on, say, three supports. This will draw off the foul air from the floor and it will be carried away in the smoke pipe through the chimney. This vertical pipe can be placed at any convenient Rev. Alf. J. Vale,

convenient position between the stove and the chimney. The dormitories and other rooms may also be ventilated to a certain extent, provided there is a large chimney from the ground floor up. If openings are made into this chimney near the floor and shutters provided so that they can be closed if necessary it will be found that a great deal of the impure air will be carried away by this means through the chimney. All the windows should be made so that they can be lowered from the top as well as raised from the bottom.

Dear Mr. Hunter,

Letters have come up from Hay River, and in one of them Mr. Vale refers to the Shoe mending outfit, suggesting that a plentiful supply of leather and nails, etc., should accompany it. Will you please see that these are included.

I have asked the Indian Department to furnish us with an Acetylene Gas Outfit. This, I think, they will do. I shall be glad therefore if you will get some information respecting this light which will prove useful in the future. The R.C. Bishop says the light is satisfactory, but he has had some trouble with the automatic "shut off" which does not shut off, automatically or otherwise, and so much Carbide is wasted. His generator is installed in the basement, and I suppose ours would be there also. I do not know what is the usual method adopted by the Department in respect of such plants, whether they choose to order direct with any particular Firm, or leave that to the grantees. It would save much valuable time if you would kindly inquire at the office of the Indian Department as to what has been done in this matter.

Mr. Bury knows all the facts connected with this matter. If you are able to communicate with the Firm which is to supply the Plant, you will need the Plan of the Building showing what piping and fittings would be required. This I am enclosing for your guidance. Should it become known to you that the Plant will not be installed this year, I should advise you to order some Coal Oil for your own use.

I have also asked the Department for a WINDMILL, Pump, and 350 feet of Piping. The size of the pipe has just reached me from Hay River, viz., 1½ inch. Of course connections and elbows will be needed. Mr. Vale has sent the following illustration of the "LIFT" of the pump, thus,

"Lift will be about 25 feet. Distance from River about 225'."

I suppose it would be better for the Firm which supplies the Windmill to furnish the piping, also the pump. Otherwise, the Marshall-Wells Alberta Co., Edmonton, would do it as well as anybody as they are shipping a lot of material for me to Hay River. I hereby authorize you to act for me in procuring the material necessary for the above if the Grant has been made by the Indian Department for the Gas Plant and the Windmill. It will be wise to get "spares" of parts easily broken. It all will have to be shipped C/O H.B.Co., Peace River Freight, prepaid to that point. If not prepaid, then, C/o H.B.Co., Edmonton. I hope this will not burden you too much. We expect this to be the last mail but for the winter, hence the urgency to get this out.
Freeze & Dobbin,
Edmonton, Alberta.

The Model 12 Star Windmill 2 has won its own way into the favor of the windmill buying public. It has proved for itself that it has no equal. Star Windmills found their way to the world's market almost half a century ago and more than a million have since done service in the various civilized countries throughout the world.

The Model 12 Star is perfectly aligned, has a direct centre lift, and is perfectly equalizes its load. Where there is perfect alignment, direct centre lift and perfect equalization of load, there can be no unequal strains. Where there are no unequal strains there can be no undue friction. Where there is no undue friction there can be no uneven wear. And finally, where there is no uneven wear there can be no unwarranted breakages with the consequent repair bills and the inconvenience of being without water when water is most needed. All this means that the Model 12 Star is designed and manufactured to whirl on smoothly and silently long after the average windmill has outlived its usefulness.

Almost two windmills in one

The Model 12 Star Windmill 2 is almost two windmills in one; not only in the matter of lasting efficiency but in design and construction, too.

It has two pitmans, two gears, two pinions, and two wrist pins. Each one of these parts bears only one-half the strain borne by the single parts on mills so constructed. Moreover, each two of these parts, as found in the Model 12 Star Windmill equally divide all loads and strains and distribute them squarely and evenly. This "double construction" is largely responsible for the Model 12 Star's extreme responsiveness, its unusual durability and its all-round efficiency.

The pitmans are truss-shaped to give them extra strength; they are well braced and ribbed and capable of many times the load they would be compelled to carry; fitted with heavy ball-bushed bearings, easily and quickly removable, and have an extra big key well. Without these pitmans, even though there were two gears and two pinions, the load could not be so equally distributed.

The two gears are extra wide and are attached so as to make it impossible for them to bind with the pinions after the mill has been in service a year or two. The pinions also, are extra wide so as to give added strength to the main shafts, and are securely keyed to the shafts. It will be noted that the bearings are supported on both sides. This construction prevents the pinions from wearing out of mesh reduces to the minimum the strain within the bearings.

The wrist pins are big and powerful, made from the best grade of steel and furnished with castellated nuts which cannot possibly work loose to impair the efficiency of the mill.

An extra long cold-rolled, polished steel drive shaft of liberal diameter is easily able to bend all weights and strains upon it and makes possible extra long bearings—mighty factors toward durability.

Perfect equalization of load

The crosshead, to which the angle iron pump rod is bolted, is directly over the load. It is not concealed, rather it is the walking beam which first takes the load and applies it smoothly and evenly to the pitmans.

The walking beam is nothing more than a combined guide and oil well. Neither the pitmans nor the pump rod connects to the walking beam. This is exclusive Star construction which prevents from 30 to 40 per cent excess friction.

March 27th, 1917.

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge with thanks, your letters of February 8th & 12th, both of which reached me March 15th.

In reply to yours of Feb. 8th, I am pleased to note that owing to the location, and in accordance with precedence, you have consented to furnish the new School at Hay River, N.W.T. with beds, windmill, and Acetylene gas plant, together with the necessary gas piping and piping for use in connection with the water supply.

I note also, that the installation of the gas plant and the erection of the windmill, renewal of this equipment will have to be effected at the expense of the school authorities.

With regard to the payment of freight to Peace River only, I would respectfully urge that in the course of our conversation in your office last April, I fully understood you to promise to supply the Desks and Beds free to destination. I hope therefore that you will confirm this.

With this reservation, I gladly confirm the arrangement you have outlined in your letter.

In reply to your letter of Feb. 12th, No. 170367-Sty, I have not placed the order for piping, so am sending your requisition for
same to Messrs Freese & Dobbin, Edmonton, by this mail, and shall carry out your instructions respecting the forwarding of the account to your Department for payment after certifying to the receipt of the goods.

I note that nothing has been said regarding a pump, and am therefore instructing Freese and Dobbin to supply a pump for use with the windmill, as the latter will be useless without it. Will you please let me know if it will be in order to charge this against the Department also. I sincerely hope it will, but in any case the pump must be procured even though we have to bear the cost.

Gratefully acknowledging the help your Department is giving in connection with our school,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]
Bishop of Mackenzie River.
June 5th, 1917.

Most Rev. Sir -

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your Lordship's letter of the 27th March which reached me a day or two ago.

With regard to the payment of freight and supplies for the Hay River School from Peace River to Hay River, I have decided to recoup you for these charges upon receipt of accounts showing that you have paid the transportation. I think it much better to allow the church authorities to arrange this transportation and pay for it in the first place, as they will no doubt obtain closer prices than the Department would.

With reference to the pump I have to inform your Lordship that this was ordered from a firm in Regina at the same time as the wind-mill, and will be paid for by the Department.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of Sept. 10 which reached me too late for the last mail I now have pleasure in sending by chance passerby to Fort Resolution. I trust you will get it a month sooner in that way.

Regarding the food given last year to the village children as per account rendered by Bishop Lucas, would say this means a full meal given as per Boarding pupils. When the children attend the school they are invited to sit down at the table with the regular Boarders and fare the same. This food generally consist of such food as we can secure in the country e.g. Fish and country meat, potatoes and vegetables grown on our farm. During my absence on furlough last year a new system a food was established giving a much larger proportion of food imported such as Flour, beans rice butter bacon rolled oats etc. Some of the flour cost as high as $20.00 per hundred lbs as it was secured in the country to augment the former supply. When these things are placed before the Department I feel certain they will see at once the charge was not too high. Our usual custom is to feed the children as much as possible along the lines they are likely to be able to secure on their return home. This we consider wise for the following reasons. The change of food will be less severe on their constitutions and they will be more readily satisfied with their lot again among their own people. Furthermore we have in the past found too much heavy food does not agree
with them physically. Trusting this will convey the desired information.

I remain

Yours very faithfully,

LIGHTING OF THE SCHOOL.

Again I quote from Canon Vale's letter.

"The Acetylene Gas has not been so satisfactory as in other years, and has given signs of possible danger of explosion. One slight explosion did occur when under repairs. No damage done. The plant is showing signs of need for repair. What do you think of a new system? I think you broached the subject one time. I am inclined to think well of what is known as the Delco Light. It is an Electric system and Automatic by means of a small gasoline engine. Said engine could be used for the Laundry and Ironing, etc., would be very convenient, clean and cool in the summer.

You will notice I have not ordered any Carbide. That was really an oversight, but if you think well of it may be a good miss. I suppose it had better be laid before the Commission. Will you take it up with them. We have never had enough light for the year and have to be very careful over it and stint the staff under the present system. They have approached me with a suggestion that they contribute some of their money and get a larger supply that they may have a good light all the Winter. I have had to ask them to economize and they are nearly out as it is. With the new system I have suggested the initial cost would be heavier but in the course of, say, five years it would be saved and the cost then would be a very small fraction of the present. In addition, it could be extended to the Church House, stable and hospital."

Regarding the above, I had intended bringing the matter to your notice during your visit. The present system was installed by the Indian Dept., but I was never greatly encouraged with it. Its annual cost is nearly $200.00 and as explained above, does not meet all the requirements of the school and staff (though I have never sought to stint the latter and have ordered whatever was requisitioned by the Principal. I expect he thought the cost was already too high and so placed this restriction upon it).

As to any new system proposed, I feel that you have had so much experience in this direction that you will be able to deal with this matter effectually. If you decide to act this year, it would be well to advise Mr. Vale at once as to the particulars which will be needed before any order can be placed for the material.

If not, will you please send the usual order to Marshall Wells Alberta Co., Edmonton for 1400 lbs FBA CARBIDE.

The cost of Gasoline would have to be taken into account if used in connection with any proposed system. You might reckon it at about $1.10 per gallon, cost landed at Hay River.

Hoping the above will not add unduly to your burdens.

Yours very sincerely,

(signed) Jas R. Mackenzie River.

The present building, standing as it does on a point of land built up of sedimentary deposit, has begun to subside, with a result that the side walls have bulged out, the apex of the roof has curved in, the floors have lost their level, neither doors nor windows fit their frames. All efforts to prevent the subsidence have failed, and a new main School building is considered necessary.

A suitable site can be found about three or four miles further up the Hay River. Building stone could be procured for the basement, but timbers and lumber would have to be secured. Suitable timber can be found on the banks of Hay River, and as the Society have men on the school staff who could manage the engine and saw-mill, they hope that these may be provided next year, in order that timbers and lumber may be prepared for the building of the new School not later than 1925.

It is thought that a plant similar to the one installed at Lao la Honge would meet the purpose. Should this be thought too expensive it should be born in mind that (a) the engine should not have less than 25 horse power, (b) the rip-saw, which should have inserted teeth, and not be less than 36 inches in diameter, and, (c) that the outfit should include carrier planer and all other appliances required for converting logs into dressed lumber.

HAY RIVER

Reverend Stoddart, Acting Principal, had me examine the building of the Mission and School in order to recommend the reparations needed very urgently in order to make the building safe. The foundations are getting weak and are spreading and the whole structure should be raised and put on solid blocks, so as to save the frame which could be used later on either as hospital or farm house, in the event of a new construction being made. Some of the apartments should also be fixed with steel ceiling and one dormitory lined with beaver board. The whole cost of these repairs asked for by Mr. Stoddard would amount to approximately two thousand dollars - the work to be done by a local contractor from Resolution, who has the equipment to raise the building. The work would be done as soon as your approval would be obtained. There is no doubt that the foundation requires some immediate attention as the whole construction is caving and the work would be a difficult proposition to make a permanent success, being on quick sand and no rock.
