Dear Sir:-

--Re Motor Launch &c. for Hay River--
--School--

In reply to your letter of the 4th instant, and with further reference to my letter of March 31st respecting the necessity of purchasing the motor launch, canoe, motor boat parts, ox &c. left by the White Beaver Oil Co. at our Society's Hay River School, I beg to state that this necessity arises chiefly, but not solely, in connexion with the provision of food and fuel.

1. With regard to food. The staff and children at this school subsist largely on fish, both in summer and winter. These are mostly secured from a point several miles out in the Great Slave Lake, and consequently several miles away from the school. In the summer regular trips have to be made to the nets almost daily for the purpose. In the past the "Komba", a steam propelled boat belonging to the school has been of service in this connexion, but the hull and machinery have now got so much out of repair as to be practically useless. When I visited their school last summer it was in "dry-dock", and I recommended the Acting Principal, for his own safety, to leave it there! In the autumn several thousands of fish have to be brought in quickly, dried on the fish stages, and put away ready for winter use and emergency. Last autumn the number thus put away was about 7,000. Thus, in the procuring of fish the motor launch would be of very great assistance, as trips could be made to the nets quickly, even with small barges or lighters in tow.
2. With regard to food or fuel. In a report just received from the Acting-Principal and dated Jan.10,1924, he devotes one paragraph to this question and begins with these words, "The wood has been a serious problem". His reference is, of course, to a supply of dry wood. Green wood abounds, but not close up to the school and much of this has to be towed in from the lake shore, or through three or four miles of "dead water" at the mouth of the Hay River. Thus, for the procuring of both dry and green wood for fuel purposes as well as for securing logs for lumber, the motor launch would be of very great assistance.

The canoe, motor-boat parts, and gasoline should be included with the launch.

3. The ox is very necessary for gardening and hauling purposes, and his purchase should be included with the rest.

The maintenance of this School cost our Society last year over $15,000. The amount your Department allows us by way of per capita grant is for fifty pupils at $165 each, or a total of $8,250. Some time ago, during a visit to your Department I pointed out that I did not consider this grant either adequate or equitable, and I am still of this opinion. I shall be obliged if, in addition to purchasing the equipment referred to in the letter, you will carefully and sympathetically consider the question of increasing the per capita grant for this School.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir :-

With further reference to the list of requirements for our Society's Indian Residential Schools for the year 1924, forwarded to the Deputy Superintendent General on the 22nd of last November, I beg to call your attention to the first paragraph of page 10 of the list submitted with that letter, dealing with the Hay River School. It reads as follows:

"The present building, standing as it does, on a point of land built up on a sedimentary deposit, has begun to subside, with the result that the side walls have bulged out. The apex of the roof has curved in; the floors have lost their level, and neither doors nor windows fit their frames. All efforts to prevent this subsidence have failed, and a new school building is a necessity."

As I have gathered from correspondence which has recently passed between our Society and your Department that the building of a new school cannot be undertaken in the immediate future, a good deal of repair work must be undertaken this summer on the present main school building to render it habitable until the new institution has been provided.

In addition to the paragraph quoted above from my own letter I beg to quote a paragraph from a letter dated Hay River, Feb. 11 and written by the Rev. D.A.B. Stoddart, M.A., B.D., the present Acting-Principal. He wrote as follows:
"We are facing rather a peculiar position. Both chimneys leading from the furnaces are practically in a state of collapse. The one leading through the boys' dormitory is particularly dangerous. I am securing from the Pure Oil Co.'s stock up the river, two pipes which we will place in position and make into the necessary chimneys. Our stock of stove piping is completely exhausted."

It is obvious from the above quotations that some steps towards the improvement of this situation should be undertaken without further delay, and I am writing to solicit your assistance in this matter.

In a letter from Mr. Stoddart dated March 21, he adds the following postscript:

"Dr. Bourget (the Agent and physician representing your Department at Fort Resolution) has asked for an authorization to spend the sum of $1,000 in repairs on our school during the coming summer".

This sum, if granted, would be a very considerable help in meeting the cost of the repairs necessary, but I do not think it would be sufficient to make the school reasonably comfortable for the staff and the children for another two, possibly three, years.

To jack up the building, it is estimated that not less than ten 10 ton jack-screws would be required. In addition to this four iron rods would be required to draw the walls back to the perpendicular, making them secure. This heavy work, along with the regular school work, would over-tax, I fear, the capabilities of our staff there, and some extra labour would be required. An expert could, I believe be secured, either at Fitzgerald or Fort McMurray.

As the boiler attached to the little engine in the saw-mill is leaking beyond repair, it is now quite out of the question for any lumber to be made on the spot, and this, along with the other items mentioned above, incline me to the opinion that $1,000 will scarcely meet the expenditure which will be necessary if the school is to be sufficiently restored as to make it safe for occupation and a few years' further service. The sum of $2,000 would probably do this, and I should be glad to know at your earliest convenience if instructions may be issued to the Rev. Canon Vale, the Principal, who will shortly return to take charge of the school, to effect repairs, the cost of which your Department will meet, provided they do not exceed the sum I have suggested.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:-

I am very deeply obliged to you for your letter of the 4th instant (134-7-5) in which you undertake to give consideration to an itemized list of repairs of an imperative nature required at our Society's Hay River School.

From the statement attached to my letter of October 30th last, addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General, it will be seen that the erection of a new School building on a different site, is a matter which can not be postponed indefinitely. However, until this can be accomplished it is essential on account of the long and cold winters which prevail in the northern latitude in which this school stands, that the heating and lighting systems should be maintained in an efficient state. The repairs, therefore which are of immediate urgency are as follows:

1. New Furnaces,
2. An electric lighting system,
3. Enlargement of dormitory space for the girls.

With regard to the furnaces when I visited this school in the summer of 1923 I examined them carefully and concluded that they would soon have to be replaced by new ones. In a letter recently received from the Principal and dated Mar. 21st last he asks for new furnaces to be sent in this year. The Hudson's Bay Co., inform me that they can supply two at $400.00 each or a total cost of $800.00
2. The Acetylene gas plant now in use is in much the same condition as the furnaces. The cost of carbide even with the best of plants is very expensive, and where the plant is defective this cost is increased. The cost of this item alone at this school last year was approximately $200.00 and is not likely to be any less this year. An electric lighting system would add both comfort and safety to the school, and reduce our Society's operating expenses which at present are exceedingly high. This system could be removed to another building at a later date.

3. A third and very urgent requirement is more dormitory space for the girls. There are more girls in residence at present than boys, and as this is always likely to be the case, in the opinion of the Principal, he suggests that an upper story be built above the Kitchen. This suggestion has my own approval. A window from the present dormitory could be enlarged to make a doorway, and the heat from the Kitchen would help to keep it warm. He estimates the cost at $300.00

Any assistance which you may be able to render in providing the above requirements will be greatly appreciated by our Society.

As the per capita earnings of this school for 1924 were only $8,250.00 and the maintenance expenses, as given in our Auditor's report, amounted to $15,622.94, you will see that our Society had to raise the sum of $7,373.94 to keep it in operation.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have the honour to report that on February 13th I made a trip to the Hay River post.

I believe Canon Vela has taken with his headquarters, before leaving the North, the question of paint for the school, which would be of benefit. The most serious feature of the Institution at present is the great shortage of wood cut in the woods, much bigger than usual, but unfortunately it was burnt during the forest fires, and it left Mr. Singleton the new principal, in the very bad position of having two men employed, working every day cutting wood and hauling a relatively long distance with one team of oxen, just bringing a day supply ahead. This is a serious condition because were the men to fall sick, or the oxen to have accidents, it would leave the school without wood and no help to be procured from the Fort, the Indians being away in the woods. This year this condition was exaggerated from the wood burning in summer, but as a rule the supply is never sufficient and is a drawback to the school. The only possible course and recommendation would be to make the necessary expenditure to have a supply cut by special wood cutters so that there would be a supply of a year in advance. This would give better wood, save the situation, time and money in the long run and leave the employees able to attend to fishing and other works, clearing land for vegetables etc. The wood cut in advance on the river is very good but needs a year to dry, the same thing applies to the drift wood, which is far better if given a few months to dry and does not create so much creosote in the chimneys, eliminating a danger of fires.

C. Bourget, M.D.

Dear Sir:

Re: Saw Mill for Hay River School

Some time ago our Commission received a request from the Principal of their Hay River School that the saw mill at that institution be placed in a satisfactory working condition, and I find that I made reference to this in a letter addressed to you on the 10th of August last. (see also my letter of June 7th. last.) Our Commission have given a great deal of careful thought to this request, and have come to the conclusion that in order to keep their expenditure as low as possible, without impairing the School's efficiency, the saw mill should be made capable, not only of cutting lumber, but also of cutting the School's supply of wood. As gasoline costs a great deal when delivered to so remote a centre, they have decided that the wood-burning engine on their steamer the "Komba", should be placed ashore, as the hull of the "Komba" is no longer seaworthy, and made to operate the mill. This action would eliminate the necessity of purchasing the engine referred to in my letter of June 7th. last.

To put the saw mill in order, however, for cutting lumber and wood, certain iron fixtures are essential, and acting on the request of the Principal, our Commission have endeavoured to secure quotations which they might submit to you in this connection. As the list of fixtures submitted by the Principal was not sufficiently specific for the purpose of the Commission it has been referred back to him for further information. Dear Sir:-

Re:- Motor Launch for Hay River.

The Principal of our Society's School at Hay River, has directed the attention of our Commission to the urgent need of a new motor launch to enable the School management to secure the large quantity of fish required yearly to feed the staff and pupils, and patients in the hospital. In his letter of Jan.11th, last, setting forth his application for this very necessary item of equipment, he writes, in part, as follows:-

"What we require is an adequately large and strong boat suitable for big lake fishing. Our staple meat diet is fish, the daily school requirement being 100 fish. The Northern climate being subject to almost daily winds, and this lake being of very shallow depth, and extremely so within two miles of the River mouth, the waves rise up very quickly. Last fall due to almost constant wind, we could reach our nets on an average of only twice a week. Then generally it was with much misgiving as to the safety of our fisherman and boy helper, who were out a mile and a half in the Lake from three to five hours at a time, in a small canoe skiff. Frequently I went out with a boy myself, and due to the distance, the slowness and difficulty of travel, and the quickly rising winds, I realized that we have not adequate equipment for fishing on a large scale. Both the size and speed of the boat have to be considered for regular and successful fishing for a school like this. This model or a boat which I describe is based on one owned by a neighbor fisherman, who declares it capable of easily enduring a rough lake. This design, improved upon to greater strength according to his advice, is as follows:-

Dimensions. Length 25' bottom, 30' top.
Width 5' bottom, 8' top.
Ribs 2"x 4" and 16" apart.
Plank Material 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)"."
Stern built for outboard motor.
Estimated cost of boat $85.00.
Suggested boat builder, Mr. Mercredi or Frank Conibear.
Fort Smith, N.W.T."

In a later letter dated Feb. 8th, he further writes,
in part, as follows:

"The fish scarcity continues to be serious in this community.
All the people are experiencing it alike. Eight large nets
altogether yield an average of twenty to thirty fish every
two days. With much labor we have moved part of our nets
five miles out into the Lake from a three mile point with
a little better result. We may place some of them two or
three miles further still."

The boat at present in use, was bought in 1924 for
$700.00. of which amount your Department provided $500.00. and our
Society the balance. It was a second hand boat when purchased,
but the service it has rendered seems to me to have fully justified
the expenditure. Now, however, it is not sea-worthy, and the
Principal states that "the engine is worn out, and not worth the
great expense needed to repair it". He suggests that a new boat
be provided of the dimensions set forth above, and that it be
provided with a 6-8 h.p. Kermath engine, which would cost,
according to the attached price list, approximately $425.00. To
this would have to be added the cost of freight. The Principal
states that this engine was recommended to him by the engineer
on the Hudson's Bay Co's Liard River steamer, who "insists that
a fairly heavy and strong engine is necessary for freighting
purposes on large waters such as Great Slave Lake where the force
of contrary winds is so great". He also states that "this engine
is popular in Northern waters".

As the boat and engine I have described are undoubtedly
an urgent necessity at this institution, not only for procuring
the daily and annual fish supply, but also for hauling a large
when collecting the wood and hay required, our Commission have
instructed me to apply to your Department for authority to purchase
the same in time to go forward by the first steamer going North
from Fort McMurray this summer.

As the saw-mill required at this School is not to be
provided this year (see your letter Jan. 8th, 1929, 139-2-5), and
as the engine sanctioned in your letter of June 13th, 1928,
139-2-5, is not being purchased, I trust that you may be able to
grant the authorization requested, or place the orders direct for
the boat and engine specified by the Principal.

I have the honour to Be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:- Re - Motor Launch for Hay River School.

With further reference to my letter of March 19th last re a motor launch for our Society's School at Hay River, N.W.T., and your reply to the same on March 25th, 139-2-5, I beg to state that it was only on the 3rd instant that I received a reply from the boat builders at Fort Smith to my letter of April 2nd, desiring to know if they could build a boat according to the dimensions given, and at an approximate cost of $85.00. Mr. Mercredi in his reply states that he could not build a boat for the sum specified, and advised me to apply to a boat builder at Waterways. I have already written to a boat builder at Waterways, but do not expect to hear from him before I leave here at the end of this week to visit Hay River. I am, moreover, somewhat doubtful about the ability of small boat makers to install a valuable engine satisfactorily in a boat of their own make, and feel that it would be better to pay a little more and have a boat properly made, and the engine properly installed.

Acting on the recommendation of the district manager of the Hudson's Bay Company for the Mackenzie River district, I wrote to the Alberta Motor Boat Co., Ltd., Edmonton, to ascertain if they could build a boat according to the dimensions given by the Principal of the Hay River School, the cost of the same, and the earliest date at which they could have it ready. Their reply was just received here yesterday, and you will find the same enclosed herewith for your information. From the description of the boat recommended in this letter, I am in doubt as to whether it would be the most suitable model for the Hay River School's use, as the boat required is largely for fishing purposes. I am satisfied, however, that the boat required could not be built for the sum of $85.00 as suggested by the Principal, and as I expect to be in Edmonton on Monday, June 17th, on my way to Hay River, I should
like to have authority from you to place the order with the Alberta Motor Boat Co., for a boat which will meet the requirements of the Hay River School. I am of the opinion that after I have talked the matter over with the Alberta Motor Boat Co., that I can persuade them to build a suitable boat for less than $475.00, but am unable at present even to estimate what the amount would be. I should be glad, therefore, to have authority from you to place an order with this Company for the most suitable boat I can get, and on the best terms I can secure, it being understood that the price will not exceed $300.00 or $350.00 at the outside. If I can secure it for less I shall certainly do so. There can be no question whatever about the urgent necessity of this boat, and where the health of the staff and pupils depends so largely on an adequate supply of fish, I consider it would be well worth while to spend the extra amount, and provide them with a really serviceable boat and engine to assist them in procuring the same. A letter from you in reply if written immediately would reach me at Edmonton by June 17th if addressed in care of Bishop Gray, 10049 - 103rd St., Edmonton.

Thanking you in advance for any help you may be able to give in this important matter.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re:- Electric lighting plant for Hay River School, C. of E.

For some years past our Society has included in its list of requirements for the Hay River School an electric lighting plant to take the place of the acetylene plant which has been in use so long that it is quite worn out. In a letter written by Bishop Geddes from Hay River on Feb. 16th, 1933, he states that the plant has developed so many leaks which they cannot locate, that it has become more of a menace than a help to the school. He further describes its condition in the following words: "But the plant to my mind is in much the same condition as the rifle of the man who said that if he had a new lock, stock and barrel, he would have a good gun."

Two years ago I secured from the Principal a rough plan of the buildings to be served by the electric light plant, with a list of the lights required for the various buildings. I submitted these plans, etc., to the Mumford & Co. Ltd., successor to R. A. Lister & Co. (Canada) Ltd., who are established at Wall St., and Portage Ave., Winnipeg, and asked them to furnish me with a quotation on a plant which they considered would meet the requirements of the case, and I enclose herewith a copy of their reply, along with the original of the plan of the buildings as prepared by the Principal.

You will please note that the prices quoted are f.o.b. Waterways. It is estimated that the carrying charges from Waterways to Hay River will be approximately $200.00.

In view of the great urgency of the need of this plant, I beg to recommend that the quotation for the Used Demonstrator LISTER BRUSTON Fully Automatic Light Plant, quoted at £1,190.00 f.o.b. Waterways, be accepted, and that an authorization be issued by your Department for the purchase and delivery of the same.
Our Society will undertake to meet the cost of installation, including expert labour, cement for the foundation on which the engine and generator will rest, shell for the batteries, etc., etc., we cannot undertake to meet any part of the initial cost of the plant itself.

Your prompt and sympathetic consideration of this pressing need will be greatly appreciated by our Society.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.C.S.C.

Department of Mines and Resources.

In regard to the school at Hay River, N.W.T., I have been in touch with School Inspector Mr. McKinnon discussing the building of the school, also the residence. I obtained blueprints from Mr. McKinnon, from which the building of the school and residence are to be constructed with different changes to this blueprint.

I am very interested in getting the contract and would appreciate if the proper blueprints and details could be forwarded to me as quickly as possible.

I received the following letters from Peter Matson today. I don't know why the dope wants other blue prints and perhaps they are not needed. You could discuss this with Col. Neary and do as you see fit. McNiven, Lindrom and myself at Neary's and Gibson's request have followed the course suggested. The blue prints for the Yellowknife school were not followed exactly - the cellar was eliminated and position of the doors changed. Similarly we would follow exactly the blue prints for the Hay River school with the only exception the elimination of the basement and raising of the door and eliminating of the (window or transom) above it.

Get copy of the prints and study same. Whatever you do tie him down to the suggestions listed in my letter previous which I discussed fully with him and he agreed to. If you haven't any other prints of the building, perhaps you could either have them drawn up or else wire him that the plans submitted were the ones to be followed and if interested to submit his offer - if not to notify us to that effect, so other interested parties might be contacted.

Fraser says he is an excellent contractor and honest - but find out how much money must be submitted. It is hoped we could advance payment either through the Yellowknife Bank which would be the best - and have the bills submitted there for payment. Perhaps $8,000 could be submitted and when one-quarter completed another $8,000. They have the accounting system already set up. Mr. McIlroy of the M & R there could attend to it and issue the cheques as the bills were submitted.

Matson would have to be bonded for about $3,000 I believe. These particulars should be clarified and he informed. We must not be too rigid - as I doubt if we can obtain another contractor at present for the job. He said he would do it for $32,000 when there - so have no alarm - but if separate prints can be obtained fine and good.

The floors should be of maple and the rest of good quality lumber. - same as that used at McPherson - check and find out type. The accordion doors can be put in by any type of fair carpenter. Lindstrom says as one story wood lattice work or supports above will be plenty strong enough and no iron beam is needed.
You could submit to him more details either by 50 word wire or letter - and here is hoping we get going right away. It is possible I've held him down to a fairly fair figure - and he is leary whether he can make it pay or not. It is a good idea that my ideas be submitted by Hoey or Neary to him - also wire telling that they will be sent immediately.

REQUEST FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Requesting authority for the construction of a four-room Indian day school and teacher's residence at Hay River, Northwest Territories, for which funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a four-room Indian day school and teacher's residence at Hay River, in the Northwest Territories;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children in the Hay River district;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 186, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part, as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any department of the Government the minister having charge of such department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the vicinity of Hay River but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building contractor, namely Mr. Peter Mattson, Hay River, who, our officials state, is a very reliable man, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately, on the basis of cost plus ten per cent;

THAT it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above quoted, and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the construction of this building as outlined, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time, being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available by the time the next school term commences.

Acting Minister

Proposed Hay River Indian Day School

On his return last week from a survey trip throughout the Mackenzie District, Mr. J. W. McKinnon, our Inspector of Schools, discussed with Mr. C. H. Buck of your branch the plans for the above mentioned school.

In view of the local situation at Hay River Mr. McKinnon was most anxious that some educational facilities be provided as quickly as possible. Since it appeared that the preparation of the detailed specifications for the proposed school would not be completed in time to allow for construction this fall it was decided to ask the contractor if he would accept a contract on a cost plus 10% basis. Should such a procedure be acceptable to the contractor, it was planned to proceed with the immediate construction of the teacher's residence and to use same as temporary classrooms quarters during the coming winter season. A wire received today from the contractor indicates his acceptance of this proposal, and hence this plan will be carried out.

The teacher's residence will be constructed according to the plans and specifications already prepared by your branch, with the exception of the fact that a furnace room will be substituted for the complete basement and provided in the existing plans.

It will not be possible to prepare the plans for the school without any undue haste and in the light of all
available information concerning construction conditions. In this respect Mr. McKinnon has advanced the following suggestions:

(1) That the basement be eliminated from the proposed new school building and that a furnace room be substituted;

(2) Having in mind the subjects that will be freed by the elimination of the basement stairways that inside toilets be provided in the school building;

(3) That the building be completely equipped with wiring and plumbing installations, to allow for the installation of a Delco light plant and a water-pressure system;

(4) That accordion doors be placed between two of the classrooms so that the rooms may be readily convertible into a small auditorium for school purposes;

(5) That built-in cupboards be installed in each classroom.

ABRIDGED SPECIFICATIONS FOR
REINFORCED CONCRETE WORK

EXTENT
The contractor shall construct all plain and reinforced concrete work, including all beams and slabs required for the proper completion of the structure in accordance with and to the full extent of drawings and specifications.

MATERIAL
Cement All cements used shall be Portland cement, provided that special cements may be used with the permission of the Chief Engineer, or his representative. Portland cement shall comply with the requirement of C.E.S.A. Specifications A5-1940.

High Early Strength Cement High Early Strength Cement shall comply with C.E.S.A. Specification A.57-1940.

AGGREGATES
(a) Fine Aggregate Fine aggregate shall consist of sand having clean, hard, durable, uncoated grains, free from deleterious substances, and shall range in size from fine to coarse within the following percentages by weight:

Passing No. 4 Sieve..........................95 - 100 per cent.
Passing No. 16 Sieve..........................45 - 70 per cent.
Passing No. 50 Sieve..........................15 - 30 per cent.
Passing No. 100 Sieve.........................3 - 8 per cent.
Volume removed by sedimentation - not more than 3 per cent.

Not more than 35 per cent shall pass a standard size sieve and be retained on next smaller standard sieve.

(b) Coarse Aggregate Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone, gravel or other approved inert materials with similar characteristics or combination thereof, having clean, hard, durable, uncoated particles free from deleterious matter. After acceptance of a grading, a variation in the amount passing any sieve size of more than 10 per cent of the total will not be permitted. The grading shall be within the following percentages, by weight:

Passing a 1-in Sieve..........................95 - 100 per cent.
Passing a 3/4-in Sieve..........................35 - 70 per cent.
Passing a 3/8-in Sieve..........................10 - 30 per cent.
Passing a No.4 Sieve..........................0 - 5 per cent.

(c) Admixtures Admixture may be used only in concrete with the approval of the Chief Engineer, or his representative, based upon evidence that the compressive strength of the concrete will not be reduced more than 10 per cent by the use of such admixtures.

WATER
Water for concrete shall be clean and free from injurious amounts of oil, acid, alkali, organic matter, or other deleterious substances.
METAL REINFORCEMENT

All steel used as reinforcement shall comply with the requirements of C.E.S.A. Specification G.30-1938 for Billet-Steel Concrete Reinforcement Bars, or C.E.S.A. Specification G.31-1938 for Rail-Steel Concrete Reinforcement Bars. Hard Grade billet-steel or rail-steel shall not be used for stirrups, column or beam ties.

CONCRETE PROPORTIONS

Ordinary Concrete In ordinary concrete the water content per 87-1/2 lbs. sack of cement, and based on a compressive strength at 28 days for 2500 lbs. concrete shall not exceed 5.10 Imperial gallons.

Allowance shall be made for surface water present in the aggregate when computing the water content. In the absence of more exact determination, the amount of surface water may be estimated from the value given in the following:

| AGGREGATE                  | APPROXIMATE QUANTITY OF SURFACE WATER |
|----------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| Very wet sand              | 3/4 gal. per cu. ft.                 |
| Moderately wet sand        | 1/2 "                               |
| Moist sand                 | 1/4 "                               |
| Moist gravel or crushed rock | 1/8 to 1/4 gal. per cu. ft.         |

Consistency and Aggregate Content In all concrete the proportions of fine and coarse aggregate and cement shall be such as to produce a mixture which will work readily into the corners and angles of the forms and around reinforcement with the method of placing employed on the work, but without permitting the material to segregate or excess free water to collect on the surface. The volume of coarse aggregate shall not be less than the volume of fine aggregate and not more than twice the volume of fine aggregate. These proportions do not necessarily apply to light-weight aggregates.

During the progress of the work, compressive tests shall be made when required by the Chief Engineer, or his representative.

The tests shall be carried out in accordance with C.E.S.A. Specification A.23-1942, Appendix VII "Method of Making and Storing Specimens of Concrete in the Field". The standard age of test shall be 28 days, but 7-day tests may be used provided the relation between the 7 and 28-day strength of the concrete is established by test for the materials and proportions used.

In all cases where the average strength of the test specimens falls below the required strength, the Chief Engineer, or his representative, shall have the right to order a change in the mix for the remaining portion of the structure. When conditions are such as to leave reasonable doubt as to the adequacy of the concrete for the purpose for which it is intended the Chief Engineer, or his representative shall have the right to order load tests to be made on the portion of the structure so affected.

The cost of all tests shall be borne by the Contractor.

Where cylinder tests are not called for the following quantities of fine and coarse aggregates in cubic feet are to be used per sack of cement measured dry.

Sum of separate volumes of fine and coarse aggregate in cubic feet measured dry per sack of cement:
Assumed Compressive Strength at 28 days Plastic Concrete Slump 0-4" Moderately Wet Concrete, Slump 5-7"

MIXING CONCRETE

(a) The mixing of concrete, unless otherwise authorized by the Chief Engineer, or his representative, shall be done in a mechanical batch mixer. The mixer shall be equipped with a suitable charging hopper, water storage and water measuring device. It shall be cleaned at frequent intervals when in use and maintained in such a condition that the mixing action will be unimpaired.

(b) Machine Mixing at the Site The mixing of each batch shall continue until there is a uniform distribution of material and the mass is uniform in colour and consistency. In no case shall the mixing time be less than two minutes after all the materials are put into the mixer.

(c) Ready Mixed Concrete Ready mixed concrete shall be proportioned, mixed and delivered in accordance with the requirements of C.B.S.A. Specification C.94-1936, "Specification for Ready Mixed Concrete".

(d) Hand Mixing When hand mixing is permitted by the Chief Engineer, or his representative, 10 per cent extra cement shall be used. Hand mixing shall be carried out on a water-tight platform and great care shall be taken to ensure that the mixing is continued until the mass is uniform in colour and consistency.

PLACING CONCRETE

(a) Conveying Concrete shall be conveyed from the mixer to the place of final deposit by methods which will prevent the separation or loss of materials.

(b) Depositing Concrete shall be deposited as nearly as possible in its final position to avoid rehandling. Concreting shall be carried on as a continuous operation until the panel section, or other unit of the operation is complete. The top surface shall be generally level. When construction joints are necessary they shall be made in accordance with Item "Construction Joints".

(c) Compacting All concrete shall be properly compacted by suitable means during the operation of placing, and shall be thoroughly worked around reinforcement, around embedded fixtures, and into the corners of the forms.

(d) Re-temping of Concrete The re-temping of concrete that has partially hardened, that is, remixing with or without additional cement, aggregate, or water, will not be permitted.

CURING OF CONCRETE

After concrete has set sufficiently, its exposed surfaces shall be kept continuously wet. This shall continue for a period of at least 7 days after the concrete is deposited. In warm weather particular care shall be taken to prevent drying out of the concrete at any time during the curing period.

COLD WEATHER REQUIREMENTS

(a) Adequate equipment shall be provided for heating the concrete materials and protecting the concrete during freezing, or near freezing weather. No frozen materials, or other materials containing ice shall be used.

(b) All concrete materials and all reinforcement, forms, fillers and ground with which the concrete is to come in contact, shall be free from frost.
(a) Concrete mixed and deposited when the temperature of the surrounding air is 40°F or lower shall have a temperature of not less than 50°F nor more than 90°F. Effective means shall be provided for maintaining the temperature of the concrete at not less than 50°F nor more than 80°F for at least 72 hours after placing. Whenever the atmospheric temperature is less than 50°F, a continuous record of the atmospheric temperatures in the vicinity of the concrete shall be kept. The housing, covering, or other protection used in connection with the curing shall remain in place and intact at least 24 hours after artificial heating is discontinued. No dependence shall be placed on salt or other chemicals for the prevention of freezing. Manure, when used for protection, shall not be allowed to come into contact with the concrete.

FORMS

Forms shall conform to the shape, lines and dimensions of the members, as called for on the plan, and shall be substantial and sufficiently tight to prevent leakage of mortar. They shall be properly braced or tied together so that they will maintain their position and shape. Care shall be taken to ensure that forms do not become dried and warped before concrete is deposited. Temporary openings shall be provided at base of column and wall forms and other places where necessary to facilitate cleaning and inspection. These openings shall be so placed that water for removing debris shall have a clear run to the outside of the forms. Bolts and rods used for internal ties shall be so arranged that when the forms are removed there shall be no metal within one inch of any surface. Wire ties will be permitted on unimportant work; they shall not be used through surfaces where discolouration will be objectionable.

WOOD FORMS

Wood forms for exposed surfaces shall be built of lumber dressed to a uniform width and thickness and free from loose knots and other defects. Joists shall be horizontal, or vertical. For unexposed surfaces, plastered surfaces and rough work undressed lumber may be used. Lumber once used in forms shall have the nails withdrawn and surfaces to be in contact with concrete thoroughly cleaned before being reused.

REMOVAL OF FORMS

Forms shall be removed in such manner as to ensure the complete safety of the structure. When the structure as a whole is supported on shores, the removable floor forms, beam and girder sides, column and similar vertical forms may be removed after twenty-four hours, providing the concrete is sufficiently hard not to be injured thereby. In no case shall the supporting forms or shoring be removed until the members have acquired sufficient strength to support safely their weight and the load thereon.

BOLTS, ANCHORS, ETC.

Build into concrete all bolts, anchors, etc., sleeves, pipes, etc., shown on concrete work.

REINFORCEMENT

Reinforcement before being placed shall be clean and free from coatings, including ice, that would tend to reduce the bond. Where there is delay in depositing concrete, reinforcement shall be reinspected and cleaned when necessary.
Reinforcement shall be accurately formed, to the dimensions indicated on drawings. Stirrups, column ties and beam ties, under 3/4 inch size, shall be bent around a pin having a diameter not less than twice the size of the bar for bends up to 90 degrees, nor less than three times the size of the bar for bends between 90 and 150 degrees. Where stirrups and ties are 3/4 inch in size and over the corresponding minimum pin diameters shall be three times and four times the bar size respectively. Except in standard hooks, other bars of structural or intermediate grade shall be bent around a pin having a diameter not less than 12 times the size of the bar. Bars of hard grade or rail steel shall be bent around a pin having a diameter not less than 12 times the size of the bar.

Reinforcement shall not be straightened or rebent in a manner that will injure the material. Bars with kinks, or bends, not shown on the drawing, shall not be used. Heating of the reinforcement will be permitted only when the entire operation is approved by the Chief Engineer, or his representative.

Reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by using annealed iron wire ties, or suitable clips at intersections, and shall be supported by concrete or metal supports, spacers, or metal hangers. Brick, wood, gypsum, tile or other similar materials shall not be used to support reinforcement. When it is necessary to splice reinforcement at points other than shown on the drawings, the character of the splice shall be approved by the Chief Engineer, or his representative.

Exposed reinforcement intended for bonding with future extensions shall be effectively protected from corrosion.

All reinforcement shall be placed so that its distance from the nearest face of the concrete shall not be less than that shown on the drawings.

CONSTRUCTION JOINTS

Joints not indicated on the drawings shall be so made and located as to least impair the strength and appearance of the structure, and shall be subject to the approval of the Chief Engineer or his representative. Construction joints in columns shall be located at the underside of floor members. At least two hours shall elapse after depositing concrete in columns before depositing concrete in the floor system.

Construction joints in floors shall be located near the middle of slabs, beams or girders, unless a beam intersects a girder at this point, in which case the joints in the girder shall be offset a distance twice the depth of the beam.

Where a joint is to be made, the surface of the concrete shall be thoroughly cleaned and all laitance removed. In addition to the foregoing, vertical joints shall be thoroughly wetted, but not saturated, and sluished with a coat of neat cement grout immediately before placing new concrete.

FLOOR FINISH

Floor, curb and exterior face of concrete shall be trowelled to a smooth even surface.

(h) Re-tamping of Concrete. The re-tamping of concrete that has partially hardened, that is, remixing with or without additional cement, aggregate, or water, will not be permitted.

CURING OF CONCRETE

After concrete has set sufficiently, its exposed surfaces shall be kept continuously wet. This shall continue for a period of at least 7 days after the concrete is deposited. In warm weather particular care shall be taken to prevent drying out of the concrete at any time during the curing periods.

COLD WEATHER REQUIREMENTS

(a) Adequate equipment shall be provided for heating the concrete materials and protecting the concrete during freezing, or near freezing weather. No frozen materials, or other materials containing ice shall be used.

(b) All concrete materials and all reinforcement, forms, fillers and ground with which the concrete is to come in contact, shall be free from frost.
Concrete mixed and deposited when the temperature of the surrounding air is 40°F or lower shall have a temperature of not less than 50°F nor more than 60°F. Effective means shall be provided for maintaining the temperature of the concrete at not less than 50°F nor more than 60°F for at least 72 hours after placing. Whenever the atmospheric temperature is less than 30°F, a continuous record of the atmospheric temperatures in the vicinity of the concrete shall be kept. The housing, covering, or other protection used in connection with the curing shall remain in place and intact at least 24 hours after artificial heating is discontinued. No dependence shall be placed on salt or other chemicals for the prevention of freezing. Manure, when used for protection, shall not be allowed to come into contact with the concrete.

FORMS

Forms shall conform to the shape, lines and dimensions of the members, as called for on the plan, and shall be substantial and sufficiently tight to prevent leakage of mortar. They shall be properly braced or tied together so that they will maintain their position and shape. Care shall be taken to ensure that forms do not become dried and warped before concrete is deposited. Temporary openings shall be provided at base of column and wall forms and other places where necessary to facilitate cleaning and inspection. These openings shall be so placed that water for removing debris shall have a clear run to the outside of the forms. Bolts and rods used for internal ties shall be so arranged that when the forms are removed there shall be no metal within one inch of any surface. Wire ties will be permitted on unimportant work; they shall not be used through surfaces where discolouration will be objectionable.

WOOD FORMS

Wood forms for exposed surfaces shall be built of lumber dressed to a uniform width and thickness and free from loose knots and other defects. Joints shall be horizontal, or vertical. For unexposed surfaces, plastered surfaces and rough work undressed lumber may be used. Lumber once used in forms shall have the nails withdrawn and surfaces to be in contact with concrete thoroughly cleaned before being reused.

REMOVAL OF FORMS

Forms shall be removed in such manner as to ensure the complete safety of the structure. When the structure as a whole is supported on shores, the removable floor forms, beam and girder sides, column and similar vertical forms may be removed after twenty-four hours, providing the concrete is sufficiently hard not to be injured thereby. In no case shall the supporting forms or shoring be removed until the members have acquired sufficient strength to support safely their weight and the load therein.

BOLTS, ANCHORS, ETC.

Build into concrete all bolts, anchors, etc., sleeves, pipes, etc., shown on concrete work.

REINFORCEMENT

Reinforcement before being placed shall be clean and free from coatings, including ice, that would tend to reduce the bond. Where there is delay in depositing concrete, reinforcement shall be reinspected and cleaned when necessary.
Reinforcement shall be accurately formed, to the dimensions indicated on drawings. Stirrups, column ties and beam ties, under 3/4 inch size, shall be bent around a pin having a diameter not less than twice the size of the bar for bends up to 90 degrees, nor less than three times the size of the bar for bends between 90 and 150 degrees. Where stirrups and ties are 3/4 inch in size and over the corresponding minimum pin diameters shall be three times and four times the bar size respectively. Except in standard hooks, other bars of structural or intermediate grade shall be bent around a pin having a diameter not less than 12 times the size of the bar. Bars of hard grade or rail steel shall be bent around a pin having a diameter not less than 12 times the size of the bar.

Reinforcement shall not be straightened or rebent in a manner that will injure the material. Bars with kinks, or bends, not shown on the drawing, shall not be used. Heating of the reinforcement will be permitted only when the entire operation is approved by the Chief Engineer, or his representative.

Reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by using annealed iron wire ties, or suitable clips at intersections, and shall be supported by concrete or metal supports, spacers, or metal hangers. Brick, wood, gypsum, tile or other similar materials shall not be used to support reinforcement. When it is necessary to splice reinforcement at points other than shown on the drawings, the character of the splice shall be approved by the Chief Engineer, or his representative.

Exposed reinforcement intended for bonding with future extensions shall be effectively protected from corrosion.

All reinforcement shall be placed so that its distance from the nearest face of the concrete shall not be less than that shown on the drawings.

CONSTRUCTION JOINTS

Joints not indicated on the drawings shall be so made and located as to least impair the strength and appearance of the structure, and shall be subject to the approval of the Chief Engineer or his representative. Construction joints in columns shall be located at the underside of floor members. At least two hours shall elapse after depositing concrete in columns before depositing concrete in the floor system.

Construction joints in floors shall be located near the middle of slabs, beams or girders, unless a beam intersects a girder at this point, in which case the joints in the girder shall be offset a distance twice the depth of the beam.

Where a joint is to be made, the surface of the concrete shall be thoroughly cleaned and all laitance removed. In addition to the foregoing, vertical joints shall be thoroughly wetted, but not saturated, and sluiced with a coat of neat cement grout immediately before placing new concrete.

FLOOR FINISH

Floor, curb and exterior face of concrete shall be trowelled to a smooth even surface.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Hay River Indian Day School

When the sum of $30,000.00 was included in the supplementary estimates for the construction of a school at Hay River, it was presumed that this would be a standard type of school and that building conditions would be normal. However, we are finding that this is very far from being the case.

The specifications for the building being constructed are entirely different from any that has been built previously as an Indian day school. This is due to the permafrost condition which exists at Hay River. Because of this, we have previously requested you to appoint an official who could supervise the rather unusual type of construction necessitated by the climatic condition which exists in this area.

On August 14 an Order-in-Council No. P.C. 3269 was obtained for the granting of a contract for the erection of this school to Mr. Peter Mattson of Hay River.

You will recall that on June 17 I received a letter from you in which Mr. Fred Fraser, Mining Recorder at Yellowknife, had sent you a wireless message reading as follows:

"RETEL THIRTEENTH MATSON REPORTED COMPETENT AND RELIABLE IN EVERY WAY".

When the blueprints and specifications of the proposed piling and foundation details for these buildings were ready, they were forwarded to Mr. Mattson on November 3. On November 4
our Chief Treasury Officer drew to the attention of our Superintendent of Education the following comment which had been made by G. H. Colson, Treasury Cost Auditor, after a visit to Mr. Mattson at Hay River:

"I gathered from Mr. Mattson that he is not in a position to finance the purchase of materials and he would be glad to know what arrangements are being made regarding this".

It was then decided, before any further steps could be taken, that a sample copy of our standard contract should be sent to Mr. Mattson for his consideration.

We have now received an answer from Mr. Mattson reading as follows:

"To your letter of November 5 including sample contract, I have with careful attention noticed difficulties regarding Hay River School contract, which I am fully aware of and capable to fulfill and operate, with the exception of financial obligations as my funds are very limited. Therefore I require your financial backing as far as purchasing and transporting materials to school grounds, wages paid out, operational expenses required for construction.

"I have on instructions from Chief Engineer Campbell started operational forework, such as preparing holes for piling, road to school grounds, wood supplies for steam jetting, pilings ready for delivery, small building for equipment storage. Trusting you will find this satisfactory and that arrangements can be made for financing.

"Please notify if above arrangements can be made, as Hay River mail will not arrive until December 5."

In view of the fact that our nearest Indian Agent is Dr. Mulvihill, located at Fort Resolution, which is several
hundred miles away, it will not be possible for us to arrange the financing of this project as suggested.

Due to the fact that you will have a supervising engineer on the job, it is recommended that your Branch take over the responsibility for the construction of this school and principal's residence. We will set up the necessary encumbrance for the amount voted. While our Education Division is willing to assume the responsibility for the construction of standard one and two room school buildings, it is felt, in view of the technical and other difficulties involved in the erection of this Hay River School plant, that it should be handled by the Lands and Development Services.

Director.

In the first place, I am obliged to say that no arrangement between Mr. Keenleyside and His Excellency Bishop Trocquier has been agreed upon. On the contrary, His Excellency in a written document has exposed his objections and refused in a very explicit manner to accept the offer of the plan of Mr. Keenleyside.

Secondly, I cannot see why the Department has seen fit to proceed with the implementation of a project which His Excellency considers as a violation of the rights guaranteed by law and confirmed by long years of recognition, of white and Indian children of the Catholic Faith.

Under these circumstances, we respectfully submit that we do not agree with your statement to the effect that "the arrangement was agreed to and does not contemplate any changes in or disturbs the existing rights of persons of any religious denominations."

Very sincerely yours,

"J. O. Plourde, O.M.I."

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 14th August, 1947.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated August 6, 1947, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, respecting:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a four-room Indian day school and teacher's residence at Hay River, in the Northwest Territories;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children in the Hay River district;

That Section 35 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 136, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any department of the Government the Minister having charge of such department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

That efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the vicinity of Hay River but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building contractor, namely Mr. Peter Mattson, Hay River, who, our officials state, is a very reliable man, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately, on the basis of cost plus ten per cent; and
That it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 38 above recited, and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the construction of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

R. BLAIS, CHIEF ENGINEER, D.P.W., OTTAWA.

This will acknowledge your letter of the 19th instant - file Misc.4-1 - with attached copy of letter of the 9th instant from the Acting Deputy Minister, Department of Mines and Resources, to the Deputy Minister of this Department.

There was not, however, enclosed with your letter a copy of the Order-in-Council P.C.3269, as mentioned in the Acting Deputy Minister's letter.

Enquiry is made if I could take over the supervision of the construction of an Indian School and Principal's Residence, which is now under construction at Hay River, N.W.T. by Mr. Peter Mattson. This project has been under the direction of the Engineer representing the Department of Mines and Resources on the Grimshaw-Hay River road, up to the present.

I would be agreeable to take over the direction of the completion of these two buildings. I should be given all particulars regarding the past procedure which has been adopted in carrying out this project and should also be informed of the cut-off date when the interests of those who have previously directed this project will cease and my responsibility begins.

It is generally unsatisfactory to take over an unfinished job from another party, but in view of the request from the Acting Deputy Minister of the Department of Mines and Resources, I am, as above stated, willing to undertake this work. I may point out, however, that the work has been initiated by others and if the cost is too high I should not be asked to assume any responsibility for this. This does not mean that there is any intention of negligence here in completing this project, but merely that there has been divided responsibility and that I am called on to continue systems and methods which, when once started, cannot be changed.

I visited Hay River on March 21st in company with Mr. J.W. McKinnon, Inspector of Schools. Mr. McKinnon wished to see the progress made in the construction of this school and while I inspected the construction work to date, with him, my visit at that time had not the same interest in the project but was only of a general nature. From this visit, however, I am aware of the work which has been done to date, and the placing of concrete piles 12 X 12 inches -26 feet- under the school building and timber piles under the proposed residence.

On account of the project being undertaken by others, and the need of my being fully informed of same and also to ensure proper supervision, I propose to put a Clerk on this job, full time, for a considerable period. A full check must be made of the materials which have been ordered, the prospects of a continuous flow of supplies to ensure the completion of the project, and also the ordering of any shortages which may develop from a study of the situation. Furthermore, if instructed to take over this project, I shall have an Engineer from this Office visit Hay River for several days, learn fully all angles of the work to date, and what is proposed, and leave a clerk there, as a Departmental representative, to keep control of the situation; also from time to time an Engineer will visit the project during the remainder of its construction.

It will be necessary, providing I am asked to undertake this work, to put a man in charge of it practically immediately. I would therefore ask approval for a Clerk Grade 4, to be assigned to this staff for this work, for a three months' period beginning approximately May 1st.
If further extensions are necessary from time to time, I shall advise you.

Sgd. W. J. Johnston

Extract from Annual Report on Fort Resolution Northwest Territories Agency, dated 1947-48.

Hay River

It is expected that the village of Hay River will, on the completion of the highway from Grimshaw, become an important community. Fishing at Hay River is exceptionally good, the people always have sufficient to eat. Because of the good fishing several companies offer employment to Indians during the winter months. Up to the present additional employment with highway construction gangs has been available but I understand that since the Indian is not a reliable worker, there is a growing tendency to import white labour.

The Indians at Hay River have called for less action on my part than those in any other settlement. Miss Neville of the Anglican Mission attends to most of their medical problems, although she can do nothing about the Tuberculosis situation. There is a need, however, for a new modern nursing station at this community. Constable D. Allan of the R.C.M. Police handles the distribution of Indian welfare rations; his assistance is greatly appreciated.

Although the Indians at Hay River are better off financially than those of Fort Resolution since they have a greater opportunity for employment, their houses and persons are not as clean.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa June 29, 1948.

Re: Electrical Power Supply,
Hay River Townsite, N.W.T.

In reply to Mr. Hoey's memorandum dated June 17th, bearing your marginal notation thereon of the 19th instant, in connection with the above, we make the following remarks:

In your memorandum to this Division dated June 3rd, you advised that the local source of electricity for the School and Teacher's Residence will not be available before next year. Because of the forced hot air heating system used in these two buildings it is necessary that we provide a source of alternating current power for the coming heating season.

The estimated cost of lighting plant equipment for a permanent installation is approximately $10,000.00 with an annual operating and maintenance cost of approximately $1,200.00. The probable yearly cost of purchasing power from a local source at the Power Company's proposed revised rate of 18 cents per kilowatt hour is estimated at $1,300.00. In view of these costs, we investigated the possibility of providing a temporary source of power necessary for the operations of the heating equipment until such time as the local power source is available.

The scheme we propose, consists of providing an automatically controlled generating unit to supply heating equipment only, provision being made for supplying the lighting loads. This plant could be dismantled next year when the local power source is available and re-erected at some other location or retained at this site as a standby unit. Lighting where necessary, could be provided through the use of Coleman or equivalent type of lighting units. Mr. Kosmar of this Division, contacted Messrs B.F. Neary, J.W. McKinnon and H.R. Lamberton and discussed the proposition with them and they were in favour of providing electric power for the buildings as outlined above, as a temporary measure until the local source is available, rather than providing a permanent generating plant installation.

A gasoline driven 5 kw, 110 volts, single phase, 60 cycle, alternating current generating unit with fully automatic control panel is recommended. In this connection we advise that the General Supply Company of Canada Limited, in Ottawa, have in stock a suitable unit which is a war surplus item. This unit is available at a reasonable price of $950.00, and complete with automatic control panel, which can be supplied, the cost of the Department should not exceed $1,100.00 f.o.b. Ottawa.

Should it be decided to proceed on this basis, the Department of Public Works should be advised of the availability of the above mentioned generating unit and it is also suggested that they be requested to enquire as to the type of motors on the heating system equipment and if necessary make arrangements to provide regulation-division motors to limit the starting current. If it were found from test, that power was available after allowance was made for the starting load of the School fan unit motor, it would be possible to provide a number of temporary lighting outlets in advantageous areas.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
It will also be necessary for the Department of Public Works to arrange for distribution conductors to be run between the two buildings and to make provision, as required, for generating unit exhaust and ventilation. It is suggested that the panel feeders be disconnected and temporary connections made between the existing service switches and heating equipment.

We submit the above scheme for Indian Affairs consideration and advice on their decision in connection with this proposal.

Chief Engineer.
Ottawa, August 3, 1948.

Ottawa, August 12, 1948.

Re: Electrical Power Supply, Hay River Indian Day School and Principal's Residence.

At the time of preparation of our drawings for the above two buildings the intention was that electrical energy would be available at the site from a local source.

It has developed however that this source of electrical power will not be available until next year, and the question of electrical power supply was investigated.

It has been suggested and concurred in by the Indian Affairs Branch that a temporary source of power should be provided to operate only the automatically controlled forced warm air heating equipment designed for these two buildings until the local electrical supply is available. Lighting for the buildings will be provided by the Indian Affairs Branch through the use of fuel burning lamps as required.

The type of generating unit required is a 5 KW, 110 Volt, single phase, 60 cycle, A.C. unit equipped with fully automatic control panel to start and stop as the heating loads come on and off.

You are advised that the General Supply Co. of Canada at Ottawa have a war surplus plant in stock of the above capacity which can be supplied subject to prior sale complete with automatic control panel at a cost not exceeding $1,100.00 f.o.b. Ottawa. We suggest that this firm be contacted in an endeavour to provide power at the site as soon as possible.

It will be necessary for your engineers to provide conductors between the two buildings, use being made of the existing service switches and standpipes, and also to provide ventilation and exhaust openings in the walls for the generating unit.

It is suggested that the feeders to the lighting panels be disconnected until the local source is available, and that temporary connections be run from the generating unit to the heating equipment thus preventing indiscriminate use of the power. It is also suggested that your engineers consider the motors supplied with the heating equipment and have these replaced with low start type.
Ottawa, August 19, 1948.

In order that you might be informed of the building progress at Hay River, I quote from a letter received on August 26th last.

"The school building itself is progressing slowly, mainly due to non-delivery of ordered materials. Mattson, however, has informed me in general discussion, that it is his plan to put on as many carpenters as he can possibly secure within limits to rush the main building to completion for use this fall. At the present date, the main building is in the studding stage on the upper floor and is sheathed in with ship-lap on the main floor. Foundation work, which is a large factor in the type of building being erected, is of course, completed. Continual rain throughout the last ten days has kept the crew from working most of the time.

The teacherage itself is much further advanced as is the boiler room attached to it. Shingling and outside finish has been completed and much of the inside work also. My personal estimate (and I wish to stress the point that it is only an estimate), is that the teacherage may be ready for occupancy by the end of September and the mail school building itself, possibly a month later if the ordered materials arrive in the near future. To substantiate such an estimate, I would prefer that you contact others in the area to get their idea".
Several large families have already moved into Hay River as permanent residents now that the road is open. This should, and I am sure will, assure you of at least fifty pupils and possibly many more.

J.W. McKinnon.

Peter Mattson, Contractor

Your memorandum of September 24, 1948, file C.E. No. P P 62, addressed to the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, dealing with the payments due Mr. Peter Mattson as contractor has been referred to this office for reply.

The contract for the construction of a four-room Indian Day School and teachers' residence at Hay River, Northwest Territories, was awarded to Mr. Peter Mattson under authority of Order in Council P.C. 3269, dated August 14, 1947. It was soon realized that Mr. Mattson was not in a position to finance this construction operation from his own resources. As there was no other qualified contractor available in the district to take over the work, it was decided to continue the contract with Mr. Mattson and to assist him in financing the project by paying all accounts promptly as they came due.

It was also decided that since there would have to be a hold-back on Mr. Mattson who was working on a 10% cost plus basis, advances to him would be limited to what would be paid a foreman. This advance which was accountable against his 10% fee was set at $300.00 per month. In addition to this monthly advance he was given $500.00 as an accountable advance against his fee, when it appeared that he lacked sufficient financial resources to provide him with ready money for expenses payable in cash.

It is hoped that the above explanation of the arrangements made to enable Mr. Mattson to carry on the work will clarify for you the procedure which we followed in making payments to him. These arrangements seemed the best at the time but we are aware of no reason why you could not amend them as you see fit within the terms of the Order in Council and the contract with Mr. Mattson, to meet changed conditions.

Director.

About the 24th September last you were inquiring as to progress being made on the school building at Hay River. Enclosed is copy of report dated the 18th October from District Engineer W. J. Johnston covering all the school buildings for which he is responsible. It is hoped this is the information you want.

AAA/S.
I am replying to your letter of September 24th - C.R.File PR.82 - making a report on the progress of school buildings at Hay River and other points.

RE: Hay River: Work on this project has not progressed at too rapid a rate owing to the difficulty in obtaining sub-tradesmen as required. This refers to plumbers, electricians, and sheet metal workers for hot-air furnaces and duct installation. This has resulted in having to keep the carpenter crew at a smaller force than would otherwise be the case. However, all these tradesmen have either recently been at that point, or are engaged there now, so that it will be possible shortly to add more carpenters to the labour force. An estimate was given by Mr. Matson of the work load, that with the crew then engaged, the project could be finished in January. However, as soon as it is practicable to do so, I am adding as many carpenters as appears reasonable for the size of the job, so as to be assured of completion during the present calendar year.

RE: Roche River: The E-Glenaroc Day School and Teachers' Quarters has been erected and has outside finish on the walls and a built-up tar and gravel roof recently completed by a roofing contractor from Edmonton. The roughing-in has been done for electricity. The hot-air furnaces and heating ducts are now being installed. It was not possible for the plumbing contractor to deliver materials to destination this year, owing, in part to the lateness in which the contract was let, and also to the fact that there are only about four boats per season from Fort Smith to this point. Carpenter work has advanced to a point where three carpenters could finish by early December. Work on this project was closed down for the season on the 15th instant, due to the impossibility of having a generator delivered, which was necessary for operation of the blower in connection with the hot-air furnace. I wrote you by letter #2961 on October 6th, in reference to specifications calling for a fully automatic electric generating machine, and the reluctance of firms to supply this unit. I am still awaiting your instructions if a manually controlled machine could be installed.

So far as I know, no desks or schoolroom fittings have been received at Roche River, and there is no furniture on hand for the teacher's quarters. In fact, the arrival of these fittings, furniture, and so forth, at a settlement where there is little, if any, warehouse storage space, presents a problem and it is doubtful if such should be delivered until the school building is ready to receive these articles, which represent a considerable investment. It should, however, be possible to begin work next spring on the school project and have it completed early in June when the first boat arrives there. Incoming shipments of furniture, classroom supplies, fittings, rations for the teacher, and so forth, should be scheduled to arrive on the first boat arriving at Roche River next year. That would permit the opening of school by July 1st if this were desired.

(OWR)
RE FORT NORMAN: - A carpenter crew is engaged at Fort Norman and is being retained there over freeze-up. The building is closed in with siding in place, and a tar and gravel roof has been proceeded with so as to protect the building, but not wholly completed; cold weather in the late fall preventing its completion. Electrical work has been completed, hot-air heating installed, and in operation. The carpenter crew will finish, it is expected, during January. At that time the class could be transferred if desired, from the present temporary quarters, to the new school building. The alternative would be to retain the school in its present quarters until the spring or early summer, when the weather would not be too severe for the transfer. This, however, is a matter for local decision. Some work will be needed next year, such as outside painting, installation of plumbing, and other small items of unfinished work.

RE FORT FRANKLIN: - Practically all materials have been delivered at Great Bear River and are held in storage there over winter. This department had several prefabricated buildings erected during previous years at Great Bear River and also had a crew of men work there during 1948. This crew had the materials for Fort Franklin placed within the prefabricated buildings, and also under our tarpaulins and tent shelters which were erected. It is intended to move the materials to destination at first hands in June, 1949.

RE FORT HALL NORTH: - Practically all materials have been delivered at this point. The materials are either stored in a local warehouse, or within the shed which was erected by this department on the school property. Thus sufficient materials are on hand to warrant beginning this work when weather conditions permit in 1949.

RE ARTHUR RED RIVER: - The bulk of materials have been delivered at this point and placed within existing buildings, or under tarpaulins, tents, and so forth. It would appear work could begin here in 1949 when weather conditions permit.

RE JOCKEY RIVER: - Approximately 30% of the freight has been delivered at this point and is properly warehoused or stored for over winter. A quantity of gravel was also delivered in readiness for construction next year. Some 90 tons of freight is in custody of Hudson's Bay Company (Mackenzie River Transport) at Niktoyaktuk - some 100 miles north of Athabasca. This material will be forwarded but cannot reach Coppermine until the latter part of July 1949.

GENERAL REMARKS: - The question of delivery of classroom furniture and fittings; of furniture and supplies and foodstuffs for the teacher's quarters, is one which should be given attention. If these articles are not ordered and delivered in 1949 it will mean that the programme of classroom instruction may be deferred a year, in the event of the buildings being completed and no fittings on hand for them. Thus all supplies should be ordered and sent forward for delivery, as follows:

- Jockey River: to reach Waterways May 15th for forwarding by Hudson's Bay Co., Bay River: to reach Waterways May 15th for forwarding by Northern Transportation Company;
- Fort Norman: to reach Waterways May 15th for forwarding by Northern Transportation Company;
- Fort Franklin: to reach Waterways Aug. 1st for forwarding by N.T. Company;
- Fort Good Hope: to reach Waterways July 15th for forwarding by N.T. Company;
- Arctic Red River: to reach Waterways June 15th for forwarding by N.T. Company;
- Coppermine: to reach Waterways May 15th for forwarding by Hudson's Bay Co.
