Under date of June 19, 1948 I wrote to you stating that District Engineer W. J. Johnston, who had taken over the completion of the four-classroom day school and teacherage at Hay River, N.W.T., estimated the cost of completion of this work at $17,000, and asked if you could arrange to have this amount placed in your Supplementary Estimates.

Under date of October 21, 1948 Mr. Johnston reported that the amount now required to finish this school was $25,000. Copy of this letter is attached. As there seems to be some question as to the necessity for this full amount or whether some of it could be provided out of funds already authorized, he was asked to check his statement and say whether the $25,000 was the total required to complete the construction of the school and teacherage in the current fiscal year and whether any money would be required next year or not. He replied under date of November 3rd, copy of which reply is also enclosed, and it will be seen that the full $25,000 is required. May arrangements be made, please, to have this money obtained from some source and transferred to this Department so it may be encumbered for use of the District Engineer in completing this work.

In this connection I would call attention to the fact that we have today received a wire from Mr. Johnston stating that the necessity for this money is
urgent and that if he does not receive it immediately, he will have to close down the work. As a result of telephone conversation between our Mr. Anderson and your Mr. Phelan I have sent a wire to District Engineer Johnston that $8,800. is being made available immediately and that the remainder of the $25,000. will be available next week. It is hoped that you will be able to make it available by that time.

R. Blais,
Chief Engineer.

It has been practically impossible up to now to give you an idea of the cost of construction of the four-classroom day school and teacher's quarters at Hay River, N.W.T. This was by reason of the fact that this Department (Public Works) took over the project after it had been started, and there was not a clear idea immediately of what materials had been ordered and what were still necessary to obtain. It has taken some time to collect this information.

For Estimate purposes I have given a completion date of December 11th for this project, but it may not be possible to reach this objective. There is now a considerable labour force at work here and work should be speeded up from now on. There would, however, be an unnecessary expense in adding to the present
I acknowledge your letter of the 23rd of October in reply to my letter No. 3205 of October 21st in which I ask that $25,000 be released to the District Treasury Office, Edmonton, in order to pay outstanding accounts, and the further sum necessary to complete the 4-Classroom Day School and Teachersage at Hay River, N.W.T.

In paragraph three of your letter you state the Chief Treasury Officer has pointed out there was a balance on hand in the District Treasury Office in Edmonton of about $5,700 at the end of September. The books in the District Treasury Office here close around the 22nd or 23rd of each month in order to comply with expenditures being made on behalf of the Department of Transport. Thus when my letter of October 21st was written it was practically a month after the closing of the books for the month of September in the District Treasury Office. My letter was written after checking with the District Treasury Office here and learning that their funds were practically exhausted.

Every effort is being made to complete this project during the calendar year, or at most to have it so far along so that the completion would be not later than the middle of January, 1949.

Heavy commitments have been made for purchase of materials and I am still receiving requests for small amounts covering shortages which have developed, in order to complete the project. It must be stressed that the amount of $25,000 is considered necessary; furthermore, that I had no part whatever in the inception of this project and knew nothing of its earlier costs until sometime after I assumed control of the Project on June 1st. Thus, without any further delay, the amount of money should be made available at once.

(over)
No provision has been made for purchase of an electric generator and this is necessary for lighting and also to operate the fan in the school which regulates the hot air heating. In fact, without this fan, electrically operated, the hot air system cannot be made to function efficiently. I am, however, withholding making an expenditure to the amount of $4,000 until I am assured that money will be made available to complete the project. It is inconceivable at this time that the project so far advanced and with all steps taken to assure its completion, should be delayed at this stage by not having made available to it the money to complete it.

In connection with the school project at Hay River, N.W.T., Mr. Peter Mattson entered into an arrangement with Whalen Insurance of Yellowknife, N.W.T., for Public Liability and Workmen's Compensation Insurance; at least that is what I understand up to the present, although I am asking further particulars from the Insurance Company. The rate charged is 3½%, and the payroll is currently running around $5,000 each fortnight. Thus per month, the premium will be in the vicinity of $225.00.

This Contract is being carried out under an arrangement at present which practically amounts to the Department doing the work on a day labour basis, with Mr. Mattson providing the supervision. In other words, the Department does all purchasing and pays such accounts, and also pays the payrolls, similar to a day labour project.

It might be possible to eliminate this charge to Whalen Insurance if the project were to be continued for any length of time, but I anticipate it will be concluded about the end of this calendar year and it might not be worthwhile making a change.

I would, however, like to know that this Department pays to the Province of Alberta for Workmen's Compensation and benefits on its day labour projects. I would then have a comparison of costs of the two forms of Insurance.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Hay River Indian School Buildings, Insurance.

Ottawa, December 14, 1948.

With reference to your memorandum of November 27th to which you attach copies of letters from the Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works and from Mr. Johnston, District Engineer for Public Works at Edmonton, the insurance question was dealt with and disposed of finally prior to turning the Hay River School Buildings project over to the Department of Public Works.

The contract with Mr. Mattson dated March 10, 1948, Section 2, Clause A, subsection 4, reads as follows:

"To insure all workmen employed on the work against injury, or death, resulting from their employment on the work."

Mr. Mattson accordingly took out a Policy with the Whalen Insurance Company on January 12, 1948. We tried to get the Employees' Compensation Division, Department of Transport, to accept responsibility for the Hay River Workmen under the Employees' Compensation Act, but were unsuccessful, in spite of the fact that Mattson's men were paid by Government cheque.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Booth Building,
165 Sparks Street,
Ottawa, Ontario.

.............2
We could hardly permit the employment of men without protection of any sort, and we therefore had to approve Mr. Mattson's action in taking out Workmen's Compensation Insurance.

Mr. Johnston refers to Public Liability Insurance in his letter of November 12th to Mr. Blais. The only Insurance paid for in this Branch was Workmen's Compensation. In fact, Mr. B.G. McIntyre, Comptroller of the Treasury, wrote Mr. E.A. Sawyer on March 24th that in his opinion it would not be proper to pay for Public Liability and Property Damage Insurance on the Hay River Project. Mr. McIntyre has since made it clear that his letter to Mr. Sawyer dated March 24th, does not refer to Workmen's Compensation Insurance.

We passed to Treasury all invoices rendered by the Whalen Insurance Company on account of Workmen's Compensation Insurance to May 31, 1948, and Treasury paid the accounts.

We have no definite information on the rate of insurance paid to the Province of Alberta by the Department of Transport for workmen employed by the Dominion Government. We do know that the Whalen Insurance Company's rate is below the rate charged by the Alberta Workmen's Compensation Board in all ordinary cases. In any event, the Employees' Compensation Division of the Department of Transport, has refused to insure Mr. Mattson's workmen under the provisions of the act, as noted in the fourth paragraph of this memorandum.

Re: School Situation - Hay River

I beg to advise you that I left Fort Smith on the afternoon of the 17th and proceeded to Yellowknife, leaving Yellowknife at 8:00 am., on the morning of the 18th for Hay River. Remained at Hay River until 3:00 p.m., on the 19th, and returned to Fort Smith from Yellowknife on the 20th instant.

On arriving at Hay River I met Col. Newcomen, Engineer of the Department of Public Works, who was sent to Hay River in December by W.J. Johnston to supervise the contractor in the construction of the school. I might say that I was very surprised at the advance in construction made on the school building since my last visit to Hay River on November 18th. There remains considerable work to be done, particularly on the ground floor. The 2 classrooms on the upper floor have been completed and painted, and there remains only a small amount of varnishing, the sanding of the floors and laying of the 1/4 round. On the ground floor there is a considerable amount of interior finishing to be done, and all of the painting.

I was informed that there is still a shortage of material, which Col. Newcomen had listed and which had not arrived, including the accordion doors which separate the two lower classrooms.

There is no doubt but that the contractor has been badly handicapped by the lack of electric power, and, as a consequence, adequate heating and lighting. No generator has, as yet, been secured, and I took immediate steps to see what could be done. I sent a wireless message to Mr. McNiven to see if one could be found in Yellowknife, but on my arrival there on the 19th was informed there was no generator of a size which would be suitable, they were either too small or too large, and the expense of shipping one of the larger machines over would be prohibitive.

The small generator moved to Fort Smith by Mr. Oldham from Trout Lake is exactly right for this job. This generator was loaned
the R.C.M.P., until our new installation here was completed. I requested the return of it in November but was informed by the N.C.O. in charge that the generator was under seizure as stolen equipment and could not be released.

While in Yellowknife, I contacted Mr. Hunter, Department of Transport, from Edmonton, and he informed me his department were quite willing to turn this generator over to the Department of Mines and Resources and had no objection whatever to the generator being sent to Hay River. I understand all equipment at Trout Lake was taken over from the U.S. Army by the Department of Transport, therefore, I can see no reason why the R.C.M.P. could not release this generator. We could send it to Hay River in our plane, as I will be returning there in a few days.

Now to deal specifically with the complaints made by the Board of Trade.

It seems that no one has visited Hay River in connection with school matters since March of last year, and, consequently, those responsible have not a clear picture of the requirements of the settlement. There are at present 86 children of school age, and school desks for 40 pupils only have arrived. The principal also informs me that no school books, chalk or other required supplies are on hand — he has no idea whatever if they have been ordered or when they will be received. Immediate steps should therefore be taken to order, and have shipped, an additional 60 desks, together with all the required text books, etc.

As there will be a large number of native children attending the school, the citizens are concerned that no x-rays have been taken in Hay River. Many of them state that they will not send their children to school to be confined in a closed space with other children who may have active tuberculosis. I think their stand has some justification. Would it be possible for the Charles Gonnell Hospital to send in a portable x-ray unit with the required medical and technical personnel to carry out x-rays of the Hay River population?

Adequate provision does not appear to have been made for sanitation in the school, although there are washrooms, both upstairs and downstairs the only toilets are outside ones; no pits have been dug nor have any receptacles been provided. Would it not be possible to place sanitary closets in the school, which could be attended to at regular and necessary intervals by the janitor? This would be a much more satisfactory arrangement for the winter months, and the outdoor toilets would be quite satisfactory during the summer months.
The principal, who appears to be a competent teacher, states that he will not be able to adequately attend 86 pupils, and that it will be necessary to have 1 more, and preferably 2 more teachers. I understand that about 50 of the 86 pupils will be in the primary grade, and the other 36 pupils will be from grades 4 to 10. The principal is obtaining this detailed information, which will be forwarded to his department within a short time. It does seem, however, that there should be 2 primary teachers for this year.

We estimated the population of Hay River in August to be between 400 and 500. I am informed by the Fisheries Inspector there have been 515 individual fishing licences issued for the vicinity of Hay River, which does not include Yellowknife. Of these, it is estimated that over 400 are newcomers. With the increased quota allotted by the Fisheries Department, the fishing industry will no longer be seasonal; and I think it is safe to assume that many of these fishermen will bring their families to settle in Hay River this summer. The Board of Trade think that the number of pupils who will be attending school at the commencement of the fall terms this year will be increased to about 120, and I think this figure is not an over-estimate. Arrangements should be made accordingly.

When the principal arrived in Hay River, no accommodation being immediately available, he lived with the R.C. priest, and some of the parents complained about this. It looked as though there might be a few narrow-minded people who would object to their children being taught by a teacher of the R.C. faith. We had a discussion on this point, and I pointed out that teachers were not selected on the basis of their religious denomination, and that at Yellowknife and Fort Smith no such question had ever arisen. Religious instruction is not a part of the curriculum. The complaint was settled very amicably indeed, and I sincerely hope we will hear nothing along this line again.

The Board of Trade complained that the Medical Health Officer at Fort Resolution does not visit Hay River at frequent intervals. In their opinion, the school inspector should be at Hay River when the school opens in order to assist in the organization of classes and meet with the Board of Trade from time to time.

When the meeting with the Board of Trade concluded, they expressed their thanks and appreciation of my visit and of the
I had been able to give them, and I assured them that their representations would be presented to the proper officials and that they would receive immediate and earnest consideration.

(sgd) Fred Fraser

Re: Day School - Upper Hay River.

In reference to your letter, File 131-18-1 (E) re buildings at Upper Hay River.

I have just returned from Hay River, and wish to advise that the buildings referred to, were torn down over a year ago, by the Yellowknife Transportation Co. The floors belonging to building are still almost intact, and could be used, but most of the material has disappeared, and all the 5 Ply Veneer ruined, as it was all left exposed to the weather.

There is a seizure notice on what is left by the Provincial Lands & Mines, so they apparently are going to use what is left. My valuation of the lumber etc. that could still be used is $300.00, that is for the foundations and floors left out of the three buildings, besides rafters and sections still left.

I would suggest that this material be taken over as very soon it will all disappear. A school at Hay River is needed, also at Hay Lake and Little Red River, and think education is the only solution for the disgraceful conditions existing today. You will find the Indians will co-operate when it comes to building, and a start should be made at once. Schools in this part of the country need not be expensive or elaborate, and children even if only counting marbles, ought to be in school. Health education alone would do more to help stamp out T.B. than the Camsell Hospital is doing today.

I have resigned my position here, but will be always interested in Indians and their education, and I trust there will be no time wasted in getting something started.

Neil Walker,
C.C. G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Superintendent,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Encls.
Mr. P. Mattson, Contractor on construction of 4-Classroom Day School and Teacherage at Hay River, N.W.T., has been in Edmonton during the past several days and has discussed with me the possibility of terminating his Contract. Attached hereto is copy of letter from Mr. Mattson in this connection.

I have previously advised you by letter No. 4716 on February 16th that this Project was likely to close down soon and the actual stoppage of operations was on the evening of February 21st. There was every reason for closing down work as it would have been continued at an excessive cost.

Attached hereto is a memorandum from T. Newcomen, who was Engineer in charge of this Project during its latter stages. This memorandum sets forth the work remaining to be done under the Contract. It will be noted that some of the work could more economically be done during the warm weather of the summer, and in fact the exterior painting should be deferred until this time.

School sessions are now being held in an upstairs room in the school. However, with the likelihood of more pupils entering school shortly, I believe it is intended that two classes be operated with one teacher in charge. At that time the two classes will be held in the two rooms downstairs, and for this reason the accordion doors will be left open so that one teacher can supervise both school classes.

This school Project is still considered under construction and when recently in Ottawa I discussed the matter with Mr. B. Neary, Education Branch, Department of Mines and Resources. I explained to Mr. Neary that I considered the Department of Public Works should retain control of the building until all construction activities were finished and hand over the building as a completed structure. This means that the Department of Public Works is continuing to pay such expenses as lighting, heating, janitor service, and so forth. Such charges may conceivably continue for possibly three months, until all details of construction have been completed. Mr. Neary was agreeable to this proposal.

In the attached letter from Mr. Mattson he wishes termination of his Contract as at close of work on February 21st. He would thus have no interest in, and receive no profit from, any labour which might subsequently be performed. In regard to purchase of materials, this falls into two classes — (a) — materials which had just arrived on cessation of work and on which no labour charges had been incurred to place in the structure. (Statement A.) — (b) — materials on order but which through scarcity of materials or other causes, have not yet been received. (Statement B). The total for purchase and delivery charges on these two items under (a) and (b) might amount to around $4500.00. Under the agreement made by Mr. Mattson he agrees to receive no commission on the purchase of such materials. It is considered this arrangement is in the public interest and the best which can be made under the circumstances. I recommend the acceptance of this offer of the termination of the Contract on the terms above outlined.
If this proposal is accepted Mr. Mattson will have to supply a statement accompanied by a Statutory Declaration guaranteeing the Department from any defective workmanship, materials, and so forth, for a period of a year. I would like to receive copies of such a form to be completed, if such a statement has been prepared; otherwise if you have any instructions in this matter for me to pass on to Mattson I would be glad to receive same.

A spare copy of this letter is attached for attention of Education Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

W.J. Johnston

Dear Sir:

In reference to a Contract entered into with me by the Department of Mines and Resources for the construction of a 4-classroom Day School and Teacherage at Hay River, N.W.T., I am writing this letter to you as you are now in charge of the completion of this School Project. As you know, this work was begun under the direction of the Department of Mines and Resources Surveys and Engineering Branch, who retained control of the Project until May 31, 1948, and since June 1st, 1948 it has been under the control of the Department of Public Works, Canada. My Contract in this connection was prepared on March 10, 1948 and the final papers therewith were signed on March 30, 1948 at Hay River, N.W.T.

The School Project has reached such a stage of completion that I do not feel I should continue as Contractor. All materials which had been received have been placed in the structure and it was considered advisable to close down the work on the evening of February 21st. It would have been expensive and unnecessary to retain carpenters and workmen and keep a cookhouse open after that date, as there were insufficient materials of all kinds on hand for the workmen to proceed.

Another factor which would make it advisable to terminate my contract now, would be the fact that some work should more properly be delayed to the summer season during warmer weather. This refers particularly to outside painting and other small cleaning up work.

Under the terms of my Contract I am not permitted to engage in other activities until the termination of this Project, and under these circumstances I am held bound to the job and unable to take other work. This will prove a hardship and hardly appears warranted with the relatively small amount of work remaining to be done.

I am agreeable to terminate my Contract as of the evening of February 21st and to waive all interest in materials which may still be required under the Contract and have not been supplied or delivered. Furthermore, I waive all interest in outstanding accounts in connection with the purchase and delivery of the generator and other items.

These other items (including delivery charges thrown to Hay River) would include -- (a) -- materials just recently received and not placed in the work and shown in Statement "A" attached; (b) miscellaneous items on order and which, through shortage of materials, have been slow in arriving (See Statement "B" attached). Both Statements are necessarily of a general nature, as I have not complete particulars at hand of all small orders, but outside of the broad statement of fact, the details are not too important.

Re: Hay River Indian Day School,
Northwest Territories.

With reference to Major Mackay's memorandum of January 18th bearing your marginal notation of the 20th instant, in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

The building was equipped with an oil fired forced warm air heating system. The oil burner selected for the job is a pressure gun type and has been arranged for fully automatic operation in accordance with regulations covering this type of system.

The control consists of a room thermostat which operates an oil burner and runs the fan between normal furnace bonnet temperatures of 120° and 150° F. A protector relay is arranged to stop the burner on ignition failure or excessive bonnet temperatures. The high limit for the bonnet temperatures has been set at 160° F. In addition a switch box and panel are provided.

It is felt that a reasonably intelligent man familiar with normal care and maintenance duties, would be suitable for the post. His duties in connection with the heating system, would involve periodic inspection and cleaning of the burner in accordance with the attached sheet of instructions regarding "Care and Maintenance of Oil Burning Equipment and Furnaces".

In connection with the electrical power supply, we outlined the situation in our memorandum to you dated June 29, 1948, and our recommendation to provide a temporary source of power until a local supply is available, was concurred in by the director of the Indian Affairs Branch by his memorandum dated August 3, 1948. The Chief Engineer of the Public Works Department was advised accordingly in our memorandum to him dated August 12, 1948.

Since the Public Works Department took over control of this project as of June 1, 1948, this Division has been out of direct contact with the job, and no information appears on our file in connection with electric power developments subsequent to the above mentioned memoranda. We have however learned through Northwest Territories files, that the Public Works Department has placed an order for a generating unit, about which we have no details, and that they have shipped a unit from Fort Smith on a temporary basis until delivery of the other set can be made. Whether or not the Public Works Department intends using the generating set on order as a permanent source of power supply for the school and principal's residence, is something we can not advise on, and we suggest that Indian Affairs contact that Department for further information in connection with the electrical supply situation.

Re: Care and Maintenance of Oil Burning Equipment and Furnaces.

The two main reasons resulting in service calls in connection with pressure gun type oil burners, are ignition failure and nozzle blockage.

Ignition spark is produced by a current sparking between two points called electrodes. After a time, these points become covered with carbon deposits and instead of a spark, arcs may be formed. When this happens, oil is not ignited and the combustion chamber of the furnace or boiler becomes saturated with oil. Consequently if an intermittent spark is produced, an explosion which can result in a fire, takes place.

To avoid this, the caretaker after having been instructed by a competent electrician, should reach in with a soft cloth and rub the carbon deposits off the points. This should be done perhaps once a month to make sure that the points are always clean. No adjustments of the spark gap should be made.

It would be advisable to have as a standby, an extra set of nozzles of the same type as supplied with the burner. Occasionally the orifice opening in the nozzle will become partially or totally plugged. Under these circumstances the nozzle should be removed and the standby nozzles installed. This operation should not take more than about 45 minutes.

The dirty nozzle can then be immersed in a 1/2 pint jar of tetra-chloride and thoroughly cleaned and set aside for replacement purposes. Under no circumstances should the orifice opening be enlarged, as it is carefully sized by the manufacturer to permit the exact amount of oil to be admitted to the combustion chamber in consideration of the burning rate required.

Filters at the oil tank and filters at the burner, should be removed and cleaned when the nozzles are replaced.

Mechanical failures apart from the above, should receive the attention of a skilled serviceman.

We see no reason why the caretaker should not be able to carry out the above normal service operations.

I hereewith beg to submit my report for the two months that I was supervising the Indian Day School project at Hay River.

I arrived at Hay River on December 24th. On going over the work the following morning, I found that a considerable amount of delay had been caused by two very important factors; first, the lack of a generating plant made it very hard for the men, especially the wood-finishing carpenters, to work through lack of light and also the extreme cold. They were obliged to use night lanterns for two hours in the morning and an hour and a half in the evening. Temporary heating arrangements were carried out by burning logs in the school furnace and also in a house stove in the teacher's residence. These arrangements, however, were not satisfactory as only the top half of the two buildings could be heated, causing considerable difficulty in carrying out painting work. The other main cause of delay was through the lack of material arriving. In some cases I understand that the shortages had been reported but evidently never ordered; such as seven doors which had not arrived when I left; and in other cases the orders were not able to be filled owing to the lack of materials in the lumber mills.

Upon my arrival, there were employed the following men:

9 carpenters, one of whom was used as a pipe fitter;
2 painters;
3 labourers, as well as the usual monthly paid camp staff of four (a women cook, women cookess, watchman and bull cook). As the work progressed and material was used up, this staff was gradually reduced until, on the 5th of February, we retained only three carpenters, two painters and one labourer. At this period I could see that all the material on hand, and which had subsequently arrived after I got there, would be used up and thereby no more work could be done. Furthermore, due to the non-arrival of a generating plant, the sanding and floor finishing could not be done, and the balance of the painting would have to wait also until warmer weather; and, also because of the request of the contractor who wished to have his contract cancelled, I considered it advisable to communicate with you and recommend that we should close down the work until a later period when it could be resumed again after the arrival of the generator. Upon receiving your approval of this, I closed down the work on the evening of February 21st, leaving a watchman-caretaker (Frank Obermuller) at an authorized salary of $150.00 plus $75.00 to defray his board bill.

Due to the fact, as advised by you, that these buildings were still considered under construction status, I assumed that we were still responsible for the heating end, therefore, I made arrangements to have logs(cut) supplied and delivered to the premises, when the school principal who was in residence by this time, considered it necessary to ask for the same. I acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 23rd with attached copy of letter of June 21st from the Director of Indian Affairs Branch in regard to a request from Mr. G.A. Strang of Hay River, N.W.T. Mr. Strang was enquiring regarding three temporary buildings on the school grounds at Hay River, N.W.T., and used by the Contractor during the construction project there.

These buildings are currently in use holding building materials remaining on hand in connection with the school project and are also being occupied by our workmen who are completing carpenter work and other installations on the school project. The buildings should not be declared surplus for some considerable time and Mr. Strang notified accordingly.

The Dominion Government is this year embarking on other construction projects at Hay River, and buildings similar to the ones above mentioned would have to be provided if the ones now existing were not made use of. Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find Requisition covering janitor supplies for the Hay River Day school. I cannot find any correspondence on this subject and presume that none of these supplies have been ordered. Please have these shipped by truck via Peace River at an early date. In the mean time we will purchase such items as are a necessity at the local store. It is regretted that no unit price has been quoted but I have no invoice or catalogue from which such prices can be obtained.

No flag is available for the opening of school and it is felt this item should be sent by parcel post being very light to ship. I believe that the flag used in the Northwest Territories is to be the new Canadian Flag.

It has been found that the cook stove supplied to the Hay River residence is a wood burning type. When the building was put up and fuel oil lines were put in, a supply line was run from the tank to the position of the kitchen stove. May I suggest that we purchase a oil burning unit to install on the back of the present cook stove. A requisition is enclosed giving the specifications of such a burner. This type bolts to rear of stove and can be installed in a matter of an hour or so without making any modifications to the present stove.

If it is decided that wood should be used in the cook stove I request authority to have ten cord of cook stove wood cut and piled in the yard ready for immediate use. At present the teacher is burning scraps from around the buildings and as soon as they are gone either wood or the oil burner must be obtained.

No supplies are on hand for the making of hot noon lunches for the children who come from the opposite side of the river and I have enclosed a Requisition covering these items for immediate shipment to Hay River. A two burner hot plate is requested for use in the school to heat water for these lunches.

As no water exists in Hay River except where brought to the buildings by tank truck it has become a necessity to provide both the school and residence with galvanized tanks. My Requisition calls for four tanks for immediate delivery via Peace River. These tanks to be used as follows: one for residence kitchen, one for engine room as extra supply for residence, one for boys wash room and one for girls wash room. Pails and wash basins are also included.

I have made up my estimates for the following year and will forward these at an early date. By so doing it is hoped that these last minute requisitions will be avoided.

Yours very truly,

Hay River Indian Day School,
September 20th, 1946.

Mr. J. W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Yellowknife, N.W.T.

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

The school is still going strong with the attendance increasing each day. You will notice in my requisition that I ordered 40 more seats, making us a total with the 30 we have here of 120, but our numbers have now exceeded that figure and I would like an additional forty, as I am inclined to believe you will need before Christmas and we will need anyway at the opening of school next September. Unless something radical happens this school will have an attendance next year of two hundred.

I would appreciate anything you could do regarding more seats.

Sincerely yours,

(signed) W.A. Bowerman.
During the past month I have been able to visit the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency as well as the Fort Resolution Residential School. As this trip was made just after the opening of the school term I believe it worth while to report on my observations at each point.

On September 21st, I visited the Hay River School and at the time there were over 130 pupils with six more to come within a few days. At this school the pupils are sitting on boxes and whatever can be scraped up. The teacher went over to the old Hay River school and picked up all the old desks that were available. Even with these the school is in urgent need of a shipment of new desks.

Mr. Bowerman has the school very well organized and the night I arrived at Hay River, a social was being put on to raise money for the Christmas concert. This social was held in the Hay River community hall.

At this school we have four teachers on full time with an average of over 30 pupils per teacher. With this attendance the teacher has no time to do any janitor work and we must hire a man full time to do this job. The Public Works are still paying the present janitor but only for this month. There are four class rooms to sweep out, two large halls and four stair-ways to the second floor. This work has to be done every evening, and with the school, the residence, and the powerhouse to look after, the man here will be kept busy. At the present time, Mr. Frank Norn is doing the work and I believe he will do this work for possibly $1500.00 although he has asked $1800.00. I do not think we can expect any man to do our janitor work for less as there is
plenty of work in Hay River and the school job is a full time one, with no time to make extra on the side if not paid enough by us.

Mr. Bowerman has been very keen to get out and do welfare work and I have found him very useful in bringing the Indians together whenever I have sent him word that I am coming over for Indian meetings. He has also volunteered to look after the registration of Family Allowances and to help in any way possible with the organization of winter fishing programs for the Indians at this settlement.

This locality offers great opportunities for the Indians if they are properly organized and a welfare teacher is needed here as much if not more than any other place in the north. If we don't take advantage of the opportunities for the Indians and get them into working, we are going to have the same set up as at Yellowknife, where the Indian sits on the outskirts of the town and does the odd little bit of work though spending most of his time gambling and drinking, and giving us one of our greatest problems in the Agency. From my several contacts with Mr. Bowerman and his cooperation on all subjects, we may find it very hard to find a man better suited as a welfare teacher.

This school has been supplied with fuel oil by Department of Public Works to cover the construction period but not beyond. The school is in need of oil immediately and I have requested an order be placed with Imperial Oil immediately. As soon as authority is received, I will have IOL Hay River fill our storage tanks.

I have seen enormous progress at all the schools since last term and I believe we can look forward with confidence to the results that will be obtained from the new type of school in the Northwest Territories.

(Sgd.) I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. Indian Agencies.

OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find Vouchers 182, 184, 186 and 187 covering expenditures for supplies and fuel oil at the Hay River Indian Day School.

When at Hay River some time ago I found that all the electrical fuses had been burned out and that in some cases it was necessary to use tin foil to make contact. As this was a definite fire hazard I sent to Bruce Robinson for a shipment. I find that I had not notified you of this move when the fuses arrived which was an oversight on my part.

Fuel oil is being delivered as required and charged to Purchase Order 48819.

On my last visit to Hay River School it was brought to my attention that there are no repair parts for any of the electrical equipment what-so-ever. As the heating and lighting are entirely dependent on the light plant it seems reasonable to expect that two spare fuel injection lines and two spare nozzle tips should be available at all times. The above two parts sometimes give out on any motor and a two or three day wait in the middle of winter could be very inconvenient.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

December 28, 1949.

Mr. I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Yellowknife, N.W.T.,

In response to your Army Signal in connection with a floor polisher and wax for the Hay River Indian Day School, we are forwarding a polisher from Ottawa, and arranging with Mr. Gooderham to forward to the school 24 2 lb. tins of paste wax.

This machine and wax is being provided the Hay River Day School to be used as a test whether cleanliness of the school can be improved by waxing the floors. It would be appreciated if you would report on this after your next visit to the school, as requests are being made by schools in the North for wax, and we are anxious to know if the cost is justifiable.

It has been found that best results in the maintenance of floors in Government buildings in Ottawa, can be had by thoroughly scrubbing the floor and allowing it to dry before the wax is applied. The wax should be allowed to set for fifteen to twenty minutes and then polished after each application as if it is not polished, there is extreme danger of children falling especially if their footwear is wet.

Two pound tins of wax are being provided as it is felt that one tin will be about sufficient for one application. An applicator that is used in the Government buildings is a sack affair filled with the paste wax and tied to a handle. This procedure has proved very satisfactory, however, should the wax ooze too freely a cloth of a finer weave should be used, or vis a versa.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

This Department (Public Works) has been engaged on construction of school at Hay River N.W.T., during the past season and our workmen have only recently been withdrawn from that location. During the time our men were there some repairs and unfinished work remaining uncompleted in 1948-49 were being attended to. However, at the same time, our workmen were engaged also on other projects at Hay River so that they were at that location for a longer period than would have been necessary for the work remaining to be done in finishing the school. After our workmen had completed work on the school, there were continual demands that our men be called back to the location for remedying of what at first appeared minor matters, but the recurrence of things to be attended to would lead one to believe that something was wrong when such demands for repairs in new construction and equipment were being asked for.

On the return to this City of Mr. G.A. Walrath, who was Engineer in charge during the past summer at Hay River, I requested a report on this situation. This report is herewith attached.

It is apparent that there is a lack of proper supervision of the school buildings, in that proper care is not being taken of same. From Mr. Walrath's report, when one reads that bolts placed in the floor have been ripped from their bearings and the accordion doors damaged, simply because someone has not taken the trouble to raise these bolts and secure same before opening the doors, it is evident that something is wrong at this place. There are other instances of misconduct bordering on vandalism, or lack of responsibility, also in Mr. Walrath's report.

In order to bring you up to date on what has arisen I mention the following:

(a) POWERHOUSE AT TEACHERAGE: The voltage regulator on the generator was found to be not working satisfactorily and Canadian Fairbanks Morse Limited, who supplied the generator, were requested to send a new voltage regulator to Hay River. Mr. Walrath arranged with Jack Purnell of Bond Construction Company to install this motor (being sent addressed care of Mr. Bowerman) on its arrival and to send the account here. This is one case, however, where a mechanism is apt to go out of kilter without any apparent reason and without any suggestion of lack of attention from any person;

(b) SCHOOL: The 1 H.P. motor of the blower which drives the fan on the furnace has been found to be acting badly and it was apparent that two bearings were likely to be burnt out at any time and require replacement. As information was incomplete, the firm of Electrical Industries in Edmonton were requested to send two sets of two bearings

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6473, file 905-5, part 3)
(total of 4 bearings) so as to be assured that the correct ones might arrive. Mr. Bowerman is being requested to return here the one set of two bearings which are not needed. We have not to date arranged for the installation of these bearings, but shall send word to Bond Construction Company to have their Mr. Jack Parnell install same. These bearings are being sent addressed to Mr. Bowerman, Hay River, via Muskeg Northern Transportation Company. The replacement of these bearings can only be attributed to lack of attention and proper oiling of the installed machinery over the past few months, and is one of the items of neglect mentioned by Mr. Laird in his report.

The above two items (a) and (b) are particularly mentioned as two instances where this office is attending to replacement of parts in order that the various machines on the school premises may be kept in first-class running condition, and the expenses of same are being paid for here. There is no complaint regarding our paying these expenses and keeping the machinery in working order while our men were at Hay River and in a position to attend to same. I am now advising you, however, that with the withdrawal of our men from Hay River, the construction work is considered fully completed for 1942-30, and any further arrangements for repairs will have to be attended to by you.

SUMMARY:

A considerable sum of money has been spent in the construction of school facilities with necessary machinery at Hay River, and as far as possible everything is being left in first-class condition. It is evident the following situation exists:

(a) Lack of discipline for the proper care of the buildings;

(b) Lack of trained personnel to observe ordinary instructions regarding the proper care and maintenance of machinery.

Unless these unsatisfactory conditions are rectified at once there is bound to be a recurrence of trouble with resulting expense in the maintenance and operation of these buildings. I thus consider it my duty at this time to point out the situation which exists at that place.

A copy of this letter is being sent to Col. H.F. Neary, Department of Education, Ottawa, for his information.

Yours truly,

W.J. Johnston

MEMORANDUM FOR W.J. JOHNSTON, DISTRICT ENGINEER, EDMONTON.

INSPECTION OF HAY RIVER SCHOOL AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MAINTENANCE

Inspection of School as of December 14, 1949:

Work was completed on the school by December 1st this year and all woodwork was left in first-class condition. As a result of the school being in use previous to this date it was found very difficult to clean the floors and woodwork before they could be varnished and left in good condition.

On inspection on December 14th several things were not in order and very disappointing to men who had worked so hard to finish a fine building.

Several of the flush bolts at the bottom of the accordion doors were broken off due to lack of care in lifting them when the doors were opened.

Boards which held coat hooks were torn off the walls from their proper place and nailed up in the main foyer. The workmanship on this work is very crude.

Mud was present on the ceiling of the main foyer.

There were football marks on the inside of the glass of the glazed doors.

On one occasion the fan on the furnace was found running dry and howling for oil. Considerable damage has been done to these bearings.

The main bearings on the 1 H.P. fan motor have become worn so badly that replacements are necessary almost immediately. This is too soon for such bearings to be worn so badly and it appears to be another case of no oil.

On another occasion the injector fan and motor had a knock in its operation which was remedied by oiling. It is hard to say what damage has been done to this motor.

On the twelfth of November mechanics took off the generator from the power plant to remedy oil leaking from the crankcase. The leaking oil was found to be coming from a sump that had not been drained. Instructions on the side of the plant require that the sump be drained daily.

Door-stops in the school have had rubber tips removed and the sharp ends uncovered, have marked the doors.

The handle on the night-latch on the front door has been twisted off.

RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MAINTENANCE ARE:

Supervision of the school children to stop vandalism.

Accordion doors should not be operated by children, and by only those having authority to do so.

(over)
A schedule for oiling and checking machinery should be maintained. If personnel cannot do this they should not be employed. Instructions in the manual with the power unit should be followed.

FURTHER RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MAINTENANCE:

No changes in the construction and finish of the buildings should be made without proper authority and by competent tradesmen.

Proper care of floors requires these to be cleaned and waxed. At present this is not being done to show up the floors to their best advantage. Perhaps the chief difficulty is the lack of a waxer and polisher and it is recommended that such a machine be provided.

Details of articles necessary to be supplied are as follows:

1 only No.13 LALONDE Floor Polisher
12" brush . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $ 135.00

200 lbs., Linx or Johnson's Traffic Wax - sufficient for six months' supply. (Paste recommended rather than liquid)
This should be used sparingly.
Floor should be washed (mopped) with a damp mop, not a wet one.

C.A. Walrath

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your wire of yesterday's date and as the native janitor has not been too satisfactory it is no doubt the best procedure to have a man brought in by the Civil Service.

At the present time we have no principal at this school and everyone is well aware of this. Mr. Kennedy has informed Mr. Bowerman that he has just as much authority as he has and consequently no one is in complete control nor is anyone responsible. I am over a hundred miles away and I do well to get into the settlement once a month. If we don't have a principal who can be shouldered with responsibilities, then it becomes extremely difficult to lay the fault at any one man's door.

I do not agree with Mr. Johnston's report in which he tries to place all the blame for faulty equipment on the school and I have discussed the report with Mr. McKinnon in Mr. Johnston's presence. I have also a report from the Head Teacher, Mr. Bowerman and a copy of this is enclosed for your information.

We do not intend to side step our responsibilities but neither do we wish to be blamed for faulty workmanship or installation that has occurred in more than one school that we have taken over from D.P.W. As Mr. Bowerman has pointed out in his letter he has personally checked the oiling of motors and fans when this was carried out by the janitor. It is also pointed out that several of these motors have never run properly from the day they were put in. I would like to point out that at both Hay River and Rocher River the circulator motors were running backwards and the change over to proper direction had to be made by our local men on the spot or freeze waiting for authority from D.P.W.

I would like to point out that at all the schools taken over so far we find that many things are left to be completed the following year or the year after that. This has been true both at Hay River and at Rocher River with the consequence that the buildings is put in operation in an unfinished state and before the proper changes have been made. In this way floors are improperly maintained and much of the equipment operates poorly, not through any fault of the man in charge, but because the building is used in a semi-complete state.

We have had furnace troubles at both Hay River and at Rocher River and in both places the floors are the next thing to impossible to heat. Mr. Bowerman's letter will bear out the heating problems and the difficulties encountered with both these schools.

The present plan of building on piles and to have all the heat above the floor with an insulated floor of
considerable thickness is, as far as I can see, a relatively new idea and unless the workmanship is perfect and insulation is done in a very careful manner it will be impossible to keep the floors at the desired temperature.

I intend to spend a few days in Hay River within the next two weeks and all the points brought out in both Mr. W.J. Johnston's letter and also Mr. Bowerman's letter will be gone into thoroughly to discover, if possible, just what is the matter with Hay River School.

With the exception of the motors and the fan bearings, which are very probably installation faults, the report has been very petty and when other things are taken into account is, I believe, made to distract one's attention from many of the construction faults we are now finding.

The offices at the rear of the school and on the second floor are used by Mr. Martin, who is the District Agent at that settlement, and much of the dirt was carried in by people going for interviews. The mud on the ceiling was kicked there by one party who told Mr. Bowerman that he had no authority over him and he would do as he liked. This is just another instance where the principal must be made responsible for the building and the janitor as well. These teachers receive more pay than I do and if they have only one building to look after or supervise as well as their school work I cannot see that they are being asked to do too much, they do not have to do any manual labour, only see that the janitor does his job.

The present Hay River Administration have several buildings of their own and we have the school and the teacherage. If the Administration are to engage a janitor and if we engage one it will put two men doing the same type of work into Hay River and it would seem to me to be only logical that we get together with the Administration of Hay River and have both janitors come under the Administrator, working these men in two shifts of eight hours each. In this way both parties would get better service and the District Administrator would be able to check up and keep the buildings maintained to the best possible degree of cleanliness. Our school is only about half a mile from the Administration Buildings and each man while on shift could make the rounds of all buildings. In Ft. Smith the janitors at the Administration Buildings look after the school and better service is obtained than by using one man separately at each building.

If you feel that the above plan would not work out it is imperative that we have a school principal who can be made responsible and also given the necessary authority to ensure that both teachers and janitors will do as they are told. As I pointed out earlier I am unable to visit these schools more than once a month and in the mean time someone must keep things operating.

At the present time many people take delight in pointing out how dirty the school is and how it is being mis-used, but though pages can be written on each little incident, they are petty and if one man, who is on the spot, can be shouldered with the responsibility and authority that he needs then these criticisms will not exist; or the man in charge will have a good excuse why they happened. I am of the opinion the principal should be this man as his authority covers the teachers, the children, the discipline of the school and should therefore cover the janitors duties.

I would be pleased to see a principal at Hay River and have the responsibility of the school placed on his shoulders as far as cleanliness and daily operation goes.

Dear Sir:

I have today returned from a complete survey of the school at Hay river and also the teachers residence. This report is intended as a true picture of what I have been able to observe to be at fault in the construction of these buildings and in the equipment that was installed. I do not intend to try and place the blame for the faulty workmanship as the buildings were up before I came to this Agency.

The report by Mr. Walruth and the subsequent report by Mr. W.J. Johnston were both received at this office and at yours and in places where we are at fault; which incidently was lack of proper maintenance of the floors due to lack of the right type of equipment has been improved. I must point out that Mr. Bowerman declares he oiled every bearing and motor himself and that from the first time fans and motors were installed they did not operate properly, thus making it necessary to keep calling back the men to check and repair. I can say with absolute certainty that the circulator fans were installed running backwards and it was only after making himself abnoxious, was Mr. Bowerman able to get these motors reversed and running correct. This did not do the motors any good and has shortened their life to some extent.

On this inspection of the school building it was found that the floors are much improved, all floors were scrubbed and now that the waxer has arrived they are beginning to look much more presentable in the rooms completed. Once all the rooms and halls are complete these floors should be a credit and the small expenditure for wax will save the floors and also the time to do the cleaning up. In appearance only we will not hesitate to take anyone on an inspection trip. My only complaint in this regard is that the polisher is too small and is one only large enough for a house or small office. At Hay River we have upwards of 7000 sq. ft. of floor surface in the school and another 1500 sq. ft. in the residence and I do not believe the polisher can stand up. It is also too light and has no applicator. Even with only one room waxed so far, I could see such an improvement from last trip into Hay River that I consider it a worth while piece of equipment.

When in Hay River the temperature was about 20 below with a wind of from four to six miles per hour. The floors of the residence were so cold that after sitting for ten minutes with outdoor footgear on my feet became cold. To touch the floors with the hand proved that they were very little if any above the freezing point. With this revealed to me on a calm day I began a thorough examination and I have the following to report.

In all the kitchen cupboards the water froze with the kitchen stove on full and the room temperature over 80 degrees. When these kitchen doors were opened up the cold air rushed in with enough force to put out a large candle light. Directly under the sink a small board was broken in the sub-floor and I cut a hole large enough to put my hand in for an examination of the insulation. I declare that there was more cold air.
being forced up through the small hole I made; due to the difference in density of cold and warm air; than one could generate with one of the standard house fans now on the market. This in itself was proof that the space between the floor joists was not a dead air space as it should have been, also it was found that there was only a single two inch batt of insulation when there should have been the full ten or twelve of the floor joists. All around the outside of the building inside walls the air was being forced into the house where the base board joins the floor and here as under the sink the circulation was enough to put out a candle.

I then went under this house and the enclosed sketch will illustrate what I found. The boards are nearly placed between the floor joists and the joints are open enough to slide ones finger in, in places. I could see no paper and the insulation was placed on top of these boards. Without any paper and wind proof cracks the insulation was worthless and all the school residence has on the floor, between the inside and outside air is a double layer of boards; the sub and top floors.

As an immediate remedy and to save much fuel for the remainder of the season I recommend that two layers of paper be stapled to the under side of the floor joists and that shiplap be nailed over the paper and to the underside of the floor joists. This will stop the air and will make a dead air space between the floor joists of the first floor. Next summer an insulation blower should be brought in and the space between the floor joists blown full of blowing wool (fiber glass) from the underside of the floor by boring a hole between each joist large enough for the nozzle of the blowing machine. If the above two jobs are not done the building will be less than useless every winter and as a building gets older it always gets colder and less efficient.

The above immediate remedy, as in attached sketch, can be done with 1200 ft. of shiplap, 4 rolls of tar paper, 4 rolls of building (kraft) paper and possibly 30 pounds of nails plus the labour cost and could be done in four or five days. The filling with insulation and the blower work would require an estimate by a man familiar with that kind of work. At the present time the D.P.W. have a supply of dry shiplap stored at the school that could be used if released for the purpose.

On examination of the cold air registers it was found that in the residence they are placed eight inches above the floor on top of the base board while in the school they are directly on the floor in the base board. This will cause a dead air space of eight inches of cold air on the floor which will not circulate. The registers must be put down to the floor and this is not too much of a job. To obtain better circulation Mr. W.J. Johnston sent me instructions to get two fans and put them above the hot air ducts and pointing downward. This I did and if the floors are fixed and the cold air inlets changed much improvement should be obtained.

On close examination of the piles on which the building rests, I found one pile had sunk from two to three inches and drawn the spikes out of the main beam. This left the one wall resting on only three instead of four piles. In this respect I request that I be given authority to have this section raised slightly with a jack and the space between beam and pile shimmed.

I do not have a plan of this building and so do not know what is called for as far as the first floor goes but I am sure that no architect would put his name to the type of insulation that is put in this building and it would appear to be the fault of the foreman in charge of building and no one else. These buildings are now up and I wish to do my best to recommend feasible repairs and to see that they are done. It is not my intention to find fault with the builder but we are now left with the job of maintenance and I do not intend that repairs that we have to make either in the near or distant future, be blamed onto lack of supervision when it was faulty construction in the first place.
The interior finish of this residence would appear to be well done and if the first floor can be made livable, then the faulty section of this house will be eliminated before more damage has been done.

With the school building we have the very same floor problem with cold first floors and from the information gained in the house it is to be presumed that the insulation in the school floors are also lacking. These school floors are not healthy for small children and the longer one sits in a desk the colder his feet and legs become. In the school insulation must be improved but presents a much greater problem than in the house.

The school is on piles and on the top of these there is a complete first floor of concrete, this makes it impossible to add more insulation from the bottom and as I see it insulation must be added from the top. To do this the first floor would have to be lifted and the space between the floor joists blown full of blowing wool, then a two by four on its side placed directly above each floor joist, the space between these filled with a two inch batt of rock wool and then a double floor re laid. This would only raise the floor two and one half inches which is little or nothing with the high ceilings now in the building.

The present furnace never stops from one day to the next and the floors were cold at 20 below, what will it be like at 50 and 60 below. If floors can be made to warm up then the furnace should cut out for up to half the time and the saving in fuel oil as well as the improvements to the teaching conditions should justify the cost of insulation.

When in the portion set aside as a wash room, and used for the past year, by Mr. Martin as his residence the frost has come through the walls in the corners just above the base board and these sections are next to impossible to heat. If it becomes impossible to warm the floors then no amount of heat in the rest of the upper air in the rooms is of much avail and we have to use far more heat than is necessary trying to do the impossible. It is from these observations that I feel I cannot too strongly recommend a complete re-insulation of both school and residence floors, and that the lessons we have learned by trial and error should be guarded against at any other school or building put up.

The present old warehouse at the front of the school is to be torn down and a small building for storage of windows etc. is to be built at the back of the lot. The front fire escape entrance still has scaffold in it and is to be completed next year. The school needs plank walks from the side door to the street, from the back door to the teachers residence and from the second side door to the toilets. These walks are a must in this town of ankle deep mud in spring and fall and after every rain. The three parts or projects outlined in this paragraph have been drawn to the attention of Mr. W.J. Johnston when he was in Yellowknife and he has made a note of them.

I understand that the lot on which the school is located is to be leveled and some other work done to it. Along this line I have no information but if we are to engage a full time janitor who has the required qualifications then the summer months can be spent in mowing lawns and doing some type of landscaping that I believe will have to be done eventually.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Mr. W.J. Johnston for his information and comments. He may possibly have some recommendations to make as to remedying some of these very urgent insulating problems. If Mr. Johnston is to be in Hay River some time during the winter and wishes to make a thorough inspection of the school and residence in my presence I will make an attempt to be there if I know well in advance when he expects to make the trip.

The attached sketches are intended to illustrate the
the floors as they are at the present time and my suggestions as to repairs that could be done to improve insulation and cut down on fuel bills as well as making the buildings comfortable to live and work in.

I received Mr. Johnston's letter in which he recommended we put an electric fan above each hot air duct; the day before I left for Hay River and I had no time to request authority from you for their purchase. As no electric equipment is available in Hay River I made an immediate purchase in Yellowknife and took them with me. When the invoices arrive I will forward to you for payment if the necessary authority will be granted. The two fans complete with extension cord and some other electric attachments amounts to $24.75.

These fans did have an effect in circulating the air but it is impossible to heat the floor itself under the present conditions.

When in Hay River I discussed the possibility of our janitor and the one doing the janitor work for the Local District Administrator be combined and instead of one man doing each establishment separately they work in two shifts and in this way the buildings will receive twenty four hour service instead of the present set-up where one man works a shift and the building is left for the school teacher to worry about the rest of the day and night. I brought this to Mr. Martin's attention and he feels that it would be a very satisfactory arrangement but he was not sure of the janitor arrangements to be put into effect by his Branch and suggested that we approach Mr. R.A. Gibson with the proposal of our combining janitors in the interest of better service and janitor supervision.

Mr. McKinnon has just returned from an inspection trip in which he has visited all schools and in order that we will be able to prevent duplication and much misunderstanding I will be taking the complete responsibility of repairs and maintenance of school buildings and the ordering of supplies and materials for these schools. With this in mind I have written this report and have pointed out the faults that must be rectified in the best interests of maintenance and economy of operation.

Yours very truly,

Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

Construction of Hay River School

You will be interested in the following report recently received from Mr. Indian Superintendent Kirkby. I know that your Engineers have been concerned over the fact that this school and teacherage have not been erected in accordance with specifications:

"When in Hay River the temperature was about 20 below with a wind of from four to six miles per hour. The floors of the residence were so cold that after sitting for ten minutes with outdoor footgear on my feet became cold. To touch the floors with the hand proved that they were very little if any above the freezing point. With this revealed to me on a calm day I began a thorough examination and I have the following to report.

In all the kitchen cupboards the water froze with the kitchen stove on full and the room temperature over 30 degrees. When these kitchen cupboard doors were opened up the cold air rushed in with enough force to put out a large candle light. Directly under the sink a small board was broken in the sub-floor and I cut a hole large enough to put my hand in for an examination of the insulation. I declare that there was more cold air being forced up..."
through the small hole I made; due to the difference in density of cold and warm air; than one could generate with one of the standard house fans now on the market. This in itself was proof that the space between the floor joists was not a dead air space as it should have been, also it was found that there was only a single two inch batt of insulation when there should have been the full ten or twelve of the floor joists. All round the outside of the building inside walls the air was being forced into the house where the base board joins the floor and here as under the sink the circulation was enough to put out a candle.

"I then went under this house and the enclosed sketch will illustrate what I found. The boards are merely placed between the floor joists and the joints are open enough to slide ones finger in, in places. I could see no paper and the insulation was placed on top of these boards. Without any paper and wind proof cracks the insulation was worthless and all the school residence has on the floor, between the inside and outside air is a double layer of boards; the sub and top floors.

"As an immediate remedy and to save much fuel for the remainder of the season I recommend that two layers of paper be stapled to the under side of the floor joists and that shiplap be nailed over the paper and to the under-side of the floor joists. This will stop the air and will make a dead air space between the floor joists of the first floor. Next summer an insulation blower should be brought in and the space between the floor joists blown full of blowing wool (fiber glass) from the underside of the floor by boring a hole between each joist large enough for the nozzle of the blowing machine. If the above two jobs are not done the building will be less than useless every winter and as a building gets older it always gets colder and less efficient.

"The above immediate remedy, as in attached sketch, can be done with 1200 ft. of shiplap, 4 rolls of tar paper, 4 rolls of building (kraft) paper and possibly 30 pounds of nails plus the labour cost and could be done in
four or five days. The filling with insulation and the blower work would require an estimate by a man familiar with that kind of work. At the present time the D.P.W. have a supply of dry shiplap stored at the school that could be used if released for the purpose.

"On examination of the cold air registers it was found that in the residence they are placed eight inches above the floor on top of the base board while in the school they are directly on the floor in the base board. This will cause a dead air space of eight inches of cold air on the floor which will not circulate. The registers must be put down to the floor and this is not too much of a job. To obtain better circulation Mr. W. J. Johnston sent me instructions to get two fans and put them above the hot air ducts and pointing downward. This I did and if the floors are fixed and the cold air inlets changed much improvement should be obtained.

"On close examination of the piles on which the building rests, I found one pile had sunk from two to three inches and drawn the spikes out of the main beam. This left the one wall resting on only three instead of four piles. In this respect I request that I be given authority to have this section raised slightly with a jack and the space between beam and pile shimmed.

"I do not have a plan of this building and so do not know what is called for as far as the first floor goes but I am sure that no architect would put his name to the type of insulation that is put in this building and it would appear to be the fault of the foreman in charge of building and no one else. These buildings are now up and I wish to do my best to recommend feasible repairs and to see that they are done. It is not my intention to find fault with the builder but we are now left with the job of maintenance and I do not intend that repairs that we have to make either in the near or distant future, be
blamed onto lack of supervision when it was faulty construction in the first place.
