Reference: Hay River School Condition

Dear Sir:

Your wire regarding dirty condition of Hay River school has been received. As I have just returned from the above school I am able to give an honest report on the condition of the floors and as I have been into Hay River when conditions were as bad as they can get I feel that I am in a position to report on both the good and the poor maintenance conditions that we hear about.

I am not in a position to know who made the report or complaint but I am reasonably sure where it came from and is intended to show how much better the Northwest Territories Administration keep their schools than what we do. It may also have been put forward with the idea that this particular school should be taken from Indian Affairs, if I am right in my guess as to where the complaint originated.

I have had both the Ft. Smith and Yellowknife schools compared to Hay River so far as cleanliness and janitor service is concerned. These two schools are both held up as shining examples and because Hay River does not measure up we are said to be lax and falling down one the job.

The Ft. Smith school is built in pure sand which does not cling to one's feet and no matter how much it rains there is still no mud. This school has a full basement with running water which can be used for cleaning if need be. This school in conjunction with the other Government buildings has three janitors and with steam heating can be kept warm enough to scrub the floors if need be. At this school they have used a large heavy duty floor washer that probably cost close to $300.00, also the attendance is half of what we have at Hay River and as the building was not used as an Administration office as well as a school the wear on the floors is possibly less than a quarter of the Hay River school.

At Yellowknife the whole town is built on either rock or gravel and mud is not known around the school or the playground. This school has a large concrete paved area in front of the entrance over which everyone must walk to enter the building. Once in the building the first floor is concrete and if dirt is carried in there is no excuse. This building has running hot and cold water and the floor polisher is a large automatic machine whereby the building can be kept spotless. Here the school is operated by the town with their own trustee board.

I would like to point out that at Hay River we have no walks, no paved expanse in front of any door and everyone who enters must step out of the mud, up half a dozen steps and directly into the school building. As we had over 140
school children attending daily as well as an undisclosed number of adults moving through the building to the local Administrator's office, the floors of the school took a lot of hard wear and the varnish was worn completely off the center of the halls and the center of each step where the traffic was heavy. Once the light coat of varnish was removed the dirt was ground right into the wood and even now after the wood work has been thoroughly washed and waxed the halls look dirty and unkept because wooden floors varnished and waxed are very unsatisfactory in localities like Hay River. If we are to close the school every time we get a thaw or a rain storm we will be able to keep the floors "clean enough to eat off" as Supt. McKinnon insists they should be.

Every bucket of water for washing must be heated on the kitchen stove in the residence and carried to the school. This is a large school and one needs a barrel of water not a bucket full to start scrubbing so that it is a major problem to get enough hot water to do the job. To start scrubbing these hardwood floors with strong soap and water every couple of days will result in the floor being completely ruined within a matter of a few months.

After freeze up last fall the floors in this building were completely scrubbed and when the waker arrived the janitor began working down the floors in each room. The waker was too late and small for such a large building with floors requiring constant maintenance for little practical purpose.

Frank Horn was found to be very unreliable and it was his lack of maintenance of the mechanical equipment and his lack of ability to learn how to do it properly that prompted me to ask for his release and to let him go. It is impossible for any one man to keep this place clean once the spring thaw comes and the floors will always be people who do not like the way we are doing things, a chance to criticize without any attempt to analyse the reasons behind any of these conditions.

The floors at this school will require a fresh varnish job at least once or twice a year and this will cover hall floors and stair treads. As stated earlier the halls and the stairs though washed and waxed look dirty and untidy right now this because the varnish has worn off from the action of the fall dirt being ground right into the wood. Invariably most of our critics are not able to visit the schools when the weather is bad or the conditions are at the worst, but do come in when everything is ideal except that our buildings are sometimes still dirty with the man in charge trying to clean up the mess that was caused by no fault of his own. If all these individuals have to do is find fault without looking for the reasons then their reports are only half truths that misrepresent the facts for their own benefit.

This school at Hay River has no washrooms, no plumbing and no facilities are available by which we can install them. A wash room has been set up in the furnace room, as this is the only place where the floor will stand water to be spilled or where it can be kept from freezing. This gives a very untidy appearance to the furnace room but it does give a wash room which we would not have otherwise. Barrels have been set up to hold fresh water and the janitor removes the waste twice a day. To any one who wished to complain, this furnace room is a very unsightly place but if we train the Indian children to keep clean then we have been well rewarded for the dirt and untidy appearance of the furnace room.

The present janitor is doing a much better job of work than the last and is making every effort to keep the place clean and tidy. All rooms are kept clean or swept out and floors are waxed and polished as well as they can be. During the Easter Holidays the halls and stairs must be thoroughly scrubbed and varnished before they are waxed. This is the only time work of this type can be done and I request the
Authority to purchase varnish, stain, brushes etc., required to do this work during the Easter holidays. The janitor will do the work of sanding rough spots, applying the varnish and we will not require any extra labour.

I wish to see this done so that I will be able to make a report on how well this wax and varnish will stand up during the mud and water of this springs break up. I do not feel that we can keep wood floors in the halls and wooden stair treads in the condition some people feel they should be. If the school continues with 120 to 150 pupils then we must have battleship linoleum on the halls and iron or heavy rubber stair treads, thus we can wash or scrub the halls every night and the stairs will not wear out or scuff. I intend to report on the school condition next spring, but I feel that the above two changes should be put into Hay River school. Each and every locality has a different problem and I feel that the type of soil we are dealing with requires special precautions as far as our floors go.

When Mr. W.J. Johnston of the Public Works was last in Yellowknife I asked him about putting board walks from the road to the main entrance, from the back door to the teacher's residence and from the second side entrance to the toilets. I will be seeing Mr. Johnston within the next week and will ask him if these walks can be put in before break up when the mud will be everywhere. I will write you after I have discussed the matter with Mr. Johnston but I feel that we must put the walks in at all cost as I do not want a repetition of last falls mud if it can be helped. I would also like to point out that last fall was the first time this school had enough pupils to call it open and though a great many complaints have been leveled at the janitor work done and the cleanliness obtained those who make the most absurd remarks, forget that the building is still being worked on by D.P.W., the yard has never been leveled nor walks put in and no gravel has been added to try and cut down the mud.

I saw some paper on the floor during the afternoon of my last visit, but the janitor had not swept up after school was out. This new janitor is much more alert than Mr. Horn and I feel he will try and keep things as clean as possible. Though the last Janitor lacked much and was far from what we desired the janitor to be, I do not believe that the building was one quarter as bad as the picture was painted and if the facts had been analyzed thoroughly, the complaint would not have been made but a recommendation sent in showing how the conditions could have been improved for those in charge of maintenance work.

Walls and ceilings were as clean as any school I have been in and the engine room and furnace room had been cleaned up since my last visit. The engine still throws some oil and the floors of these two buildings will need to be scrubbed next spring. I would like to point out that the furnace room floors and the engine room floors are concrete mats set up on posts two or three feet above the ground so that these floors are the same temperature inside as outside; 70 below when the weather is that cold. It then becomes an impossibility to wash these floors and if oil or dirt drips on them it must be left until we get a spring thaw to clean it up.

If the complaint will specify special points then if it is accurate, we can explain or deny but I do not believe the condition is as reported, or if it is so there was a very good reason behind it being this way.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

L.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Re: Hay River Indian Day School

Mr. W. J. Johnston, Department of Public Works, Edmonton, was in the office a few days ago and gave me a copy of a report dated December 20th concerning the Hay River Indian Day School. In this connection, I would comment as follows:

I read Mr. Johnston's report and informed him that I considered much of his report petty and of little or no value. I am at variance with Mr. Johnston in his view that teachers and pupils should move into schools before they have been completed by the Department of Public Works and feel that the leaving of the school buildings in an unfinished state has resulted in undesirable conditions. You will recall that the teacher and pupils moved into the Hay River School before same was completed. In fact, the main entrance (fire exit) has not been completed. I brought this matter to Mr. Johnston's attention and he said he would attend to it. In contrast, the Department of National Defense completed the Fort Resolution Territorial Day School before handing it over to the Administration. As a result, pupils will have greater respect for the building as it has been kept in first class condition. Whereas, the Hay River School was opened in an unfinished state; cleaning equipment was not provided so that the building could be kept in good condition. The pupils and teacher lived in a cold, unheated, unfurnished building for months. This condition is undesirable, yet, the Department of Public Works again have notified your Branch to move into the Fort Good Hope School in a similar unfinished condition. The opening of these schools in an unfinished condition permits officers of the Department of Public Works to try to pass the blame to our Department for their own shortcomings. For instance, C. A. Walrath has reported that several flush bolts at the bottom of the accordion doors were broken; while at Fort Good Hope, I endeavoured to open one of the accordion doors and found that I had partly jammed one of the bolts as I had not been shown how to properly open these doors. In this connection, I can readily see how several bolts could be accidentally broken. However, while at Hay River, I examined the accordion doors and failed to see any damage to them.
As for the coat hooks, these should definitely be in the halls beside each classroom as classes can be dismissed in a more orderly fashion by this arrangement. The Yellowknife School Board have found it practical to move the coat hooks into the halls beside the various rooms. Besides, Magistrate Martin was using one of the coat rooms as an entrance to his living quarters thus necessitating its change. The only mistake is that authority should not have been obtained to move the coat hooks and the change should have been made by a carpenter. This matter will receive our immediate attention as this condition may be rectified by purchasing a few boards to act as a back-stop for the hooks.

Mr. Walrath speaks of mud being present on the ceiling of the main foyer. During my inspection, I asked Mr. Bowerman how the mud got on the ceiling. Mr. Bowerman was quite upset about the blotches of mud on the ceiling and informed me that he had noticed a fisherman enter the side door with very muddy feet. He asked him to clean the mud off his boots. The fisherman replied that he didn't have to take any orders from Mr. Bowerman as he was on his way up to see Magistrate Martin on business; the fisherman in question kicked his feet and thus the mud was scattered on the ceiling. Mr. Bowerman gave me the name of this gentleman but I did not take it down as a few minutes with some soap and water would remove all signs of the mud.

As for the other complaints mentioned in Mr. Walrath's report, I have already informed you of the apparent unsuitability of the present caretaker. I was amazed to find that he could not properly close a door. It may be his lack of care in closing the doors that caused the rubber-stopped door stops to be removed. I spoke to Mr. Bowerman about this at the time of my visit and when I next visited the school, I noticed that the doors were opened and closed properly.

Mr. Bowerman will likely argue that he was not made principal of the school, therefore it was not his responsibility to attend to the care of the entire school. I reported to your office the unsuitability of Mr. Kennedy and his inability to control his class. I feel that this has helped to produce this undesirable condition. However, I am of the opinion that neither Mr. Kennedy nor Mr. Bowerman are capable of handling the Hay River School. This school is too large for them and beyond their ability. It is for this reason that I have already suggested Mr. Bowerman's transfer to the Fort Franklin Indian Day School. Mr. Bowerman has done some fine welfare work among the Indians and would be more suitable in an Indian community. In fact, he has already written to you regarding this matter. I am not trying to pass the blame to others for anything which is within my field of responsibility but, at the same time, I do not think it is fair for the Department of Public Works to turn over their buildings to the Department in an unfinished condition and then write long memorandums containing petty complaints to cover up their mistakes.
The Officer in Charge of the R.C.O.S. at Fort Good Hope informed me that he had told Mr. Johnston that he could let us have 5 K.V.A. of electricity for our school. As Mr. Johnston wanted 15 K.V.A. for the school, the new generating plant was purchased. You will realize that when the Army Signals inform us that we may have 5 K.V.A. of electricity, they are making sure that they are on the safe side. Incidentally, at Fort Good Hope I learned from discussions with the Officer in Charge of the R.C.O.S. that there was in actuality a surplus of 10 K.V.A. that might be used by the school.

When the 16 K.V.A. lighting plants were installed, I argued that they were too large for our schools. I was under the opinion that a 2½ or 3 K.V.A. plant would meet our requirements and still feel that this would have been sufficient. However, I had nothing to do with the selection of these plants as I wasn't invited to attend the meeting when this matter was decided. However, I feel that the large lighting plants are the cause of most of the trouble as they require practically a specialist to attend to them and the cost of operation is excessive. I understand this matter will be settled in the spring when a central plant is installed at Hay River. If the Department of Public Works had installed a small plant along with the large unit, this condition would not prevail as the small plant could be used most of the time -- after school hours, at night, and so forth. This would have greatly reduced the costs of operation. However, this equipment will not go to waste as the large units at Hay River and Fort Good Hope might be moved to centres like Fort Rae and Fort McPherson where they would meet the requirements of a whole settlement. Should you decide to do this, I would suggest that you have the R.C.O.S., or some such group maintain this equipment in return for free light. This would relieve you of a large responsibility.

There are various matters I might report concerning the unfinished condition of schools but I shall leave this for my individual report on each school. Sufficient to report that all the woodwork at Roche River is not completed. Fort Good Hope is quite incomplete. In spite of the report made by W. J. Johnston that the Hay River Indian Day School is complete, I wish to report that some of the steps and most of the front entrance, which is covered in large glass brick windows, is in a very incomplete state. Apparently Mr. Johnston was unaware of this until I informed him of such at the time of his visit.

It is quite a contrast between the completely finished school at Fort Resolution and that of schools built by the Department of Public Works. The Department of National Defense did some very fine work at Fort Resolution. The floors were nicely sanded and left in first-class shape. The woodwork was completely varnished and left in good state. Walls were nicely coloured and, in general, the entire school building was a credit to the Army. In contrast, the Department of Public Works have done some very fine work but same is practically ruined by leaving their buildings in an incomplete state.
I note that in the Manual of Instructions to Indian Agents, that they are held responsible for the care, upkeep and maintenance of school buildings. I have discussed this matter with Indian Agent Hunter and Indian Agent Kirkby and they are assuming this responsibility. At the first opportunity, I shall submit a letter to you covering this matter.

I have written you this confidential letter in order that you will not have any undue concern regarding the Hay River Indian Day School. Both Indian Agent Kirkby and I will do everything possible to insure the proper care of property and equipment. At the same time, I wanted you to know that our main complaint is with caretaking service and the lack of ability of the caretaker to attend to such modern equipment as the electric light plant and the heating system. We shall endeavour to rectify this situation at the earliest date.

I just wish that I could drop in for a chat. It would be an easy matter then to let you know just how slipshod some of the work by the Department of Public Works has been. The apartment where we are living is a perfect example of poor work. Upstairs porches have been set up in such a way that the rain pours into the basement and wets everything in the grocery cupboard below. Ration rooms have been installed in the basement in such a way that everything will freeze. The basement floor is rough and left in an unfinished state. Floors have been left unfinished and so forth. In view of this type of work, I resent the fact that the Department of Public Works have tried to pass the blame to the pupils by pointing out that mud has been thrown on the ceiling when in such event the pupils were not responsible. Naturally, the pupils are not perfect and we shall do everything to improve their behaviour and to retain the buildings and equipment in the very best state.

Wishing you the compliments of the season and a very successful 1950, I am,

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Residence and School,
Hay River, N.W.T.

With reference to your marginal notation of the 16th February, on a letter from the Superintendent of Education of Indian Affairs dated the 14th February, in which complaint is made of the difficulty of heating the above buildings, may we comment as follows:

Upon receipt of Mr. Neary's letter, instructions were sent to Mr. Bruce Douglas at Hay River to investigate and report by Army message. Mr. Douglas' reply was received on the 23rd February and he is quite definite that lack of adequate insulation is alone to blame.

Plans prepared by this Service call for four inches of rock wool insulation on floors, walls and ceilings. Mr. Douglas states that wool batts were split into a thickness of one inch in some cases and no thickness of insulation exceeds two inches, while in the residence shiplap is laid parallel to the joists contrary to the plans and leaving open joints and no dead air space.

The school floor was designed as a 4 inch reinforced concrete slab, 2 inches of cinder concrete and 4 inches of rock wool with a double floor fastened to 2" x 6" battens, and the insulation value is equal to that of the exterior walls.

There is no doubt in our minds that the entire responsibility for the unsatisfactory nature of the heating of these buildings, is that of those who erected the structure, with equal blame attached to those whose duty it was to see that the materials and requirements called for on the plans, were followed.

Mr. Douglas states he is forwarding a written report and upon receipt of same you will be informed in more detail of conditions at this school and residence.

We do not feel that such statements as the one that a wood pile of the residence foundation and which is frozen solid in permafrost has settled some two or three inches, should be so casually made. It is a physical impossibility for the pile to settle, as it would crush and split under load and not settle. We believe the pile was cut short and the beam forced down and then nailed. If the beam has sprung, the obvious method to adjust is to nail an adequate shim between the pile beam.
With reference to a copy of a letter dated the 22nd February from Mr. R. Blais, Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works suggesting that the plans of this school be reviewed, our Architect and Structural Engineer have done so and found absolutely nothing wrong with the design. The leaks of which complaint is made are said to be along the base of the dwarf wall and some water is said to follow went pipes into the basement toilets which would seem to indicate lack of proper flashing.

We are at a loss to understand how a sag of 3 inches could occur at this part of the roof if the plans were followed. We would suggest an inspection of the ceiling under this portion of the roof, as a sag of 3 inches in the roof joists would surely be apparent at the ceiling. In any case instructions are being issued to our Mr. Douglas to have a portion of the ceiling removed which is directly below the 4" x 12" beam supporting the dwarf wall in order to determine the direction in which the roof joists were laid, and to clear up the possibility of any faulty construction.

Salient points to amplify the foregoing will be extracted from the report to be furnished by Mr. Douglas and will be embodied in a letter drafted for your signature to the Chief Engineer, Department of Public Works.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Four Classroom Day School,
Hay River, N.W.T.

With reference to our memorandum dated the 28th of February regarding a reported sag and leak in the west portion of the roof of the above school, we are now in receipt of a telegraphed report from Mr. Bruce Douglas, who was instructed to make an inspection under date of the 3rd of March.

An analysis of this report indicates that no sag of roof joists exists, that leakage was caused by faulty installation of flashing, since corrected, and that there is no indication of substitution or faulty workmanship in the roof framing itself. From these facts, it may be taken that the design of the roof was never at fault and is definitely adequate.

In more detail the report explains that a panel of the fibre board ceiling was removed directly under the 4" x 12" beam which supports the dwarf wall at the junction of the west and main roof and everything was found to be constructed in accordance with the plans. There was a small inequality of about 3/16 of an inch in the seam of the plaster board at the beam but it was neither serious nor unsightly. Water stains on the beam and joists indicated past leakage, but Mr. Douglas informs us that new copper flashing with soldered joints was placed at the roof and wall in the autumn of 1949 and should now be watertight. This would indicate that leakage was entirely due to faulty workmanship in placing flashing in the first instance.

The inspection should put at rest any reports indicating inadequacy of the roof design for this building. In future, any reports of a like nature on structures designed by this Service will be fully investigated at once but explanation should be requested from the source of such reports so much at variance with fact.

A full report on the Hay River School is being prepared for your information.

Major MacKay

We are forwarding to you herewith a copy each of a letter from Mr. J. W. McKinnon, Superintendent of Education for the Mackenzie District, N.W.T., and a letter from Mr. W. A. Bowerman, Principal of the Hay River Indian Day School, concerning transportation of school children across the Hay River and from the West Channel to the school.

We should be pleased to have your comments concerning the suggestions contained in these letters relating to the transportation of children to and from school.

We might add, for your information, that the mouth of the Hay River is split by a large island which lies close to the southwest shore and opposite the Indian village. The channel between this island and Vale Island, on which the new town-site is located, is about 150 yards across and is open to wind and wave action from the main lake. This channel is never too rough for pontoon planes to land. However, any rough water can be avoided by travelling up water in the narrow channel near the Indian village and crossing some distance up river opposite the Game Warden's house. An ordinary skiff or 24 ft. freighter canoe would handle the school children safely.
The children on the West Channel belong to families of fishermen. The local Administrative District at Hay River is now incorporated, and is in the same situation as Yellowknife, where transportation of school children is provided at the expense of the local tax-payer. It is thought, therefore, that it is up to the Board of Trustees of the local Administrative District to provide the necessary transportation at Hay River for white children.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of January 20, 1950, I requested a report from Mr. W. A. Bowerman, Principal, Hay River Indian Day School, concerning transportation of children across the Hay River and transportation from West Channel to the school. In that connection, I have attached herewith Mr. Bowerman's letter which is self-explanatory. As either Mr. Bowerman or the caretaker will assume responsibility for bringing the children across the Hay River, I see no reason for not purchasing a boat for this purpose as the Hay River is quite treacherous and several pupils have already nearly drowned.

As for the transportation of children from the West Channel area, I discussed this matter with Stipendiary Magistrate Martin and Mr. Bowerman. One solution suggested was that the Department purchase a station wagon for transportation purposes. We did not favour this method for the reasons of high cost of maintenance, need of daily care and so forth. The second method was that the people from West Channel contract with the local taxi firms to bring the children to school on the understanding that the Department will pay a certain portion of the cost. This second method seems the better as it appears that the local taxi firms would be responsible for injury caused by accident and so forth. Mr. Bowerman states that the cost would be approximately $1,000 per school year. This amounts to $35.00 per child. On this basis, I would recommend that the Department provide 50% of the cost of transportation up to a maximum of $500.00 on the understanding that the local people at West Channel, or fish companies, provide the balance.

I see no reason for any parent not being able to pay $15.00 per child for transportation purposes, that is providing there are not more than two children of school age in the same family. Should this latter solution meet with your approval, I shall visit West Channel and endeavour to make such an arrangement with the local people. As the children at West Channel are "Whites" it appears that this item of expense is the responsibility of our Administration; whereas the matter of transportation across the Hay River is the responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

Transportation of children across the Hay River

Number of Treaty children attending school: 35
Number of Non-Treaty children from across the river attending school: 10

The Hay River is perhaps the most treacherous in the North. This is due to the fact that our prevailing wind piles huge waves into the river, and no small craft can cross. None of the Indians have a boat of sufficient size to cross every day. We almost had a triple drowning when school first began.

I hired and personally paid an Indian fisherman to use his boat to take the children back and forth every day, to and from school. Even with a large freight canoe there has been three days that the children could not cross. This cuts down our attendance and retards their work at the school.

Would it be possible to have our department obtain for the use of the school a boat of sufficient size to bring these children across? If such a craft was available either the caretaker or myself would see that the children were brought over. This seems to me to be the only solution to our problem of getting these children to school. The fact that I used my own money to pay for such service indicates whether I believe it is necessary or not.

Transportation of children from the West Channel area

Children of the fishing village of West Channel are three miles removed from the school, there is an attendance of 20 pupils from this section.

At the present time we are hiring two taxis to bring these children to the school, and paying the cost by means of dances, box socials, etc.,

I would recommend that the department either purchase a station wagon for use of the school, or as an alternate assume the cost of taxi service, which would be approximately $1000.00 a year.

Both of these problems are of utmost importance to the school if we are to maintain our attendance standing and continue to have the pupils in regular attendance. For your attention, Sir, and necessary action.

Very truly yours,

(signed) W. A. Bowerman.

W.A. Bowerman, Principal.

I would like to point out that this pile did settle and that it would have been a physical impossibility for any gang to have forced an 8" X 12" beam down to the top of the pile. The piles were sunk in permafrost and then before they were fully frozen back in, the beams were put on with the result that some piles were not to the bottom of the hole and did settle pulling away from the beam. In all the schools built on piles we can expect to have to do a certain amount of shimming and possibly jacking up for the entire life of the structure. MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Four Classroom Day School,
Hay River, N.W.T.

With reference to your memorandum dated the 6th March, respecting the unsatisfactory conditions at the above school, it is considered that faulty workmanship, lack of supervision and a complete disregard of insulation details as shown on our drawings, are to blame.

At the outset, the Indian Affairs Branch obtained authority from Council to award a contract for construction of the building to Peter Mattson, whom they understood to be the best qualified person in the area at that time. Considerable concern was felt when it was established that Mr. Mattson would be unable to finance his operations as a contractor, and arrangements were made to restrict his status to that of general foreman; responsibility for organization and supervisory control being assigned to the Department of Public Works. Mr. Mattson's documentary status as contractor nevertheless was never rescinded.

Respecting Mr. Mattson, we quote from a report dated the 22nd November, 1947, from Mr. G.R. Barnes who as an Assistant Engineer, with this Service, supervised the preliminary work. Mr. Barnes said "Mr. Mattson seems to be a competent and conscientious workman, but, as a contractor, will require considerable assistance from the Department in arranging for materials and getting things organized."

Responsibility for faults now evident in the construction of this building lies with those charged with supervision who permitted inefficient workmanship and inexcusable practices to be made use of, on a structure that was simple and straightforward.

Our memorandum dated the 26th February, based on a report from Mr. Bruce Douglas regarding the inadequate insulation, and a further memorandum dated the 7th March based on a later report from Mr. Douglas regarding leakage in the west roof, indicated that all faults are due to the aforementioned causes, and there is no fault in the design.

When this school was proposed, considerable research was made into soil and sub-soil conditions. Borings were taken and samples of soil from the site were carefully examined by our structural engineer. It was obvious that the building should be erected without a basement and several designs were investigated which would combine in a compact unit such services as
heating and electrical supply, suitable access, exits, fenestration and adequate insulation. The design decided upon was approved by Indian Affairs and considered so acceptable that a similar design of school was chosen for Fort Smith.

We do not know what more can be said than has been presented to you in this and our previous memoranda. The responsibility for leakage of the west roof has been cleared up, and roof repaired and there is no sag in the roof joists. The skimping of insulation material has been proven and the responsibility is not that of this Service.

The remedy suggested by Mr. Douglas for implementing insulation, namely by blowing in loose material is widely used, but is not what should be employed in a new building.

The vapour barrier and reinforcement against settlement provided by the treated paper backing on rockwool batts is taken into consideration when calculating heat losses.

Nevertheless without practically taking the whole interior finish apart and taking up the floors at a prohibitive cost, nothing better can be suggested.

The residence is a simple problem and easily rectified by removing present sheathing below the ground floor joists and placing four inches of insulation and masonite base as shown on plans. Wood shutters to close in the space under both buildings, are called for on the plans.

The deplorable situations being created at Hay River and other points in the North through an apparent lack of interest combined with inefficient construction supervision, and job organization, should not be allowed to recur, and it is felt that only by our own supervision of construction can repetitions be prevented.

Chief.
Yellowknife, N.W.T.
March 24th, 1950.

B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,

Dear Sir:

Re: Hay River School Floors

I have just returned from a trip into Hay River and I can report that the building is in much better condition than on any previous trip. The floors have been much improved and will be scrubbed and waxed and varnished during Easter holidays.

I ordered a quantity of varnish and painting supplies on February 22nd, and to date have not received any notification that this has been ordered or shipped. As Easter holidays start two weeks from today I feel we should have a rush order on this varnish. Easter is our only chance to varnish until next summer and with the mud of Hay River to contend with during the break-up I feel we must varnish the halls and stairs now.

Please advise whether we can expect this varnish in order that we may make the necessary arrangements for the janitor to do this maintenance work during the holidays.

Yours very truly,

If the usual cushioning material is introduced into the mounting, the vibration will be reduced. Dear Sir:

With reference to your wire of April 29th, 1950 in which you request the additional information regarding the warehouse to be used at the Hay River School I wish to report the following.

The enclosed sketch will indicate the Hay River school yard and the various buildings that are now on the lot or will be put up there. The warehouse has not been built but as an old one now exists I have been informed by Mr. Johnston that the D.P.W. are to remove the old warehouse; which is right beside the school and was only a store shed; and will be putting up a new warehouse for the school in the position indicated on the sketch. This building to be put up this summer and as far as I can gather is a part of D.P.W. program necessary to complete the school. I know nothing about Mr. Johnston's instructions but the building is to be put up.

The plan calls for a building 24' x 36' to be partitioned into three sections as indicated and it was the large section that I requested we be allowed to use this coming winter as a fish store house and weigh room. The building will not be used after the winter season for fish and will be completely cleaned so that no fish waste will be left to decay in the building.

We will be handling only frozen fish during the winter and have no intention of handling fish at other seasons of the year at any point. As it is an experiment to try and get more revenue to the Indian and at the same time give more Indians a share in this revenue it was my desire to use this building for one season to see if it was profitable and whether the Indians
can be depended upon to deliver fish and do the majority of the running of the operation themselves. If it proves out I would then propose to put up a small winter packing house of our own where it would be well away from the school, but one hesitates to put up such a building before the Indians have shown their willingness to make the venture a success. As pointed out this is only a one winter arrangement.

I would expect the Welfare teacher to take enough interest in the project to keep track of what is going on and to be able to advise the Indian as to what to do and to prod them along when ever need be. He would also have to do the actual money transactions but nothing else. I do not think we are asking too much of the teacher seeing that he is a Welfare teacher paid more than Indian Superintendents; to help the Indian out by giving advice and instruction. The present teacher Mr. Bowerman has done this but many might not want to. All weighing of fish, boxing of fish, loading on trucks and everything including all cleaning up will be done by the Indian but actual supervision must be done by the Welfare Teacher.

The Indian is, by our standards at least, lazy and if no one is handy to prod him every so often then he does nothing. It is for this reason that I wish to have the first years work done near the school so that the teacher can give it the once over every so often. Again I am sure that the Indian would be only too glad to see the Teacher do all the work while they sat around but this is not to be the case and every single bit of manual labor is to be done by the Indian.

I would like to say in closing that the success that was attained last winter in the fishing can be attributed, in no small way, to Mr Bowerman's after school efforts in working for the good of the Indians of Hay River.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

L.F. Kirkby,

Dear Major MacKey,

HAY RIVER INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

For your information we are forwarding here-with a copy of an extract from the Minutes of the twenty-eighth Meeting of the Local Board of Trustees of the Hay River Administrative District, held on May 9, 1950, which deals with the Hay River Indian Day School.

Yours very truly,

R.A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Major D. MacKey,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa.
Extracts from the Minutes of the twenty-eighth Meeting of the Local Board of Trustees of the Hay River Administrative District, held on May 9, 1950.

Letter read from Mr. W.G. Brown written on April 29th enclosing copy of letter written by Mr. R.A. Gibson on April 1st, re the Indian Day School in Hay River. It appears to have been suggested that the District take over the Indian Day School. The Board does not wish to have anything to do with the Indian School until various improvements have been made to the school. The insulation is very poor; as an example, the lower floor in winter is freezing while the upper floor is roasting. The residence is in poor condition and is not habitable in the winter time; a case was presented by Trustee Osborne whereby a Christmas tree was brought into the house with a large lump of snow on it and after having the tree in the house for two weeks the lump of snow was still on the tree. Also, the school appears to be run by the children rather than by the teachers; the teachers do not exercise discipline and the parents are objecting to the teachers and their methods of teaching the children. The grounds are in very poor condition; there has been no attempt to landscape them nor plant grass. They have not been levelled. In the spring or whenever it rains, the grounds become a sea of mud which is tracked into the school by the children. Trustee Osborne did not feel that there would be enough taxes in the District to finance the upkeep of the school, the expenses are too great, for example, since the opening of the schools, 7 months ago, there has been $5,000.00 worth of fuel oil used therein. Janitor and teacher expenses also discussed. Council feels that there is only one teacher at present in the school that is worth keeping. Feel they could hire three local teachers and with the one present good teacher, would have a satisfactory staff with more discipline and education taught. Trustee Osborne felt the government should take over the expense but the Council could form a school board and take over the management of the school. The Board members will agree to gather material to present to the Board of Inquiry when it visits Hay River.
Mr. Doucette at Hay River

Please note that the amount of $3000 has already been transferred to Office of Public Works for renovation to building above.

June 7/50
June 12th, 1950.

The Secretary,
Department of Public Works,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Hay River Indian Day School

The Northwest Territories Administration has forwarded to us a copy of an extract from the Minutes of the twenty-eighth meeting of the Local Board of Trustees of the Hay River Administrative District, held on May 9th, 1950.

With regard to the Hay River Indian Day School, the Minutes read in part as follows:

"The insulation is very poor; as an example the lower floor in winter is freezing while the upper floor is roasting. The residence is in poor condition and is not habitable in the winter time. A case was presented by Trustee Osborne whereby a Christmas tree was brought into the house with a large lump of snow on it, and after having the tree in the house for two weeks, the lump of snow was still on the tree."

I thought it advisable to bring this matter to your attention, as it is understood that repairs will be made to this building this summer under the direction of your Department. We have already transferred to your Department, an amount of $3,000.00 for repairs to the Hay River Indian Day School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,

You will recall previous correspondence concerning the sharing of caretaking expenses at Hay River. Mr. Magistrate Martin has written to the Deputy Commissioner of the Northwest Territories Administration, as follows:

"In replying to your letter of February 14th, 1950, in the above connection, I do not consider an arrangement of this kind would be satisfactory. In the first place the Hay River Indian Day School and the Administration Buildings on Lot 78, are over a mile apart and a lot of the caretaker's time would be taken up going between the establishments.

"The school is a large four room building, with a power house and teachorage and is a full time job for one man, and when they landscape the school grounds the caretaker's work will increase.

"At present there is not much work for a caretaker at the Administration Buildings, all that is required is a scrub-woman for one half day a week to scrub and polish the office and Court Room floor. Each occupant of the houses is responsible for the cleanliness and good appearance of their house and surrounding grounds.

"The heating and lighting of the Administration Buildings is no problem and does not require the services of a caretaker."

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Sirs:

During October of last year we experienced much difficulty with the Roche River Light plant and eventually the post of one cell was burned off. This cell was still good but we had no way of replacing it and when I contacted Dept. of Public Works for a replacement you advised them that the plant would work without the 31 cell and that one would be shipped this summer by water transportation to replace the burned one.

As the cost of transportation by air was very high I kept the old cell here and it was sent out to you by N.T.C.L. a few days ago and should reach you in due course. Will you kindly send in a new cell as indicated in your letters to Mr. W.J. Johnston of D.F.C. last fall. The burning off of the battery post was due to negligence and faulty installation by the party who set up the plant and is not the fault of operation by any of our staff. The plant is now operating very satisfactory and I would like to install the new cell before another winter season to insure the best results possible.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of July 19th regarding repairs to the F.E. model 640 diesel light plant I wish to advise that this plant is in need of an overhaul and I have requested that I be given authority to ship the whole plant out for repairs. With this in mind will you kindly hold the new voltage regulator until I advise you as to whether the plant is to be returned to you for overhaul or whether it will be done locally in Hay River.

The report I received on the regulator was that the large circular cover that encloses the generator itself and also the voltage regulator became loose and shook onto the regulator shorting the entire regulator and causing it to burn out. On examining the cover it had large burned areas where it had been shorted and it is presumed that this is the reason for the break.

The Dept. of Public Works advise me that they had been in touch with your office and that new voltmeters and ammeters were to be supplied to replace the originals which did not give service. Will you kindly look into this and if the plant is shipped out replace the old ones or send us new meters when the regulator is returned if I have to do the overhaul locally.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

During a recent visit into Hay River the power plant was inspected and it was found that the voltage regulator had been burned out. This was sent to Edmonton for repairs and the establishment is without any power at all. This being the summer holiday season no great difficulty is being felt.

The Hay River school light plant has been a very expensive piece of equipment and much time spent in repairs. The plant has run a full year or more without any overhaul and as it must run 24 hours every day it is now in need of a full overhaul to put in shape for next winter. There is a diesel man in Hay River who can do a thorough repair job but I feel that we should send the plant to Fairbanks Morse, Edmonton and get a good job done while at it.

The plant at Hay River is A.C. and as such must run no matter what power is needed so that we are often running with as little as one K.W. being needed and running at such a small load has resulted in the plant running away with itself and we get excessive wear. I cannot too strongly recommend that we provide a 1500 Watt standby plant at this point to be used at night when the power requirements are small and to provide for heat if a breakdown occurs.

The Hay River plant being a diesel has some vibration and in its present set up has been mounted on a floor that is supported at the corners only and acts like a diaphragm so that the entire plant, plant house and residence vibrate all the time. With the addition of a three room warehouse just back of the school I feel that the light plant, when it returns from being
overhauled should be set in one room of the warehouse on a block of concrete to prevent the vibration of the entire residence and also to increase the life of the engine. The cost of this change will be negligible and will make for better operation all round.

I have discussed these points with Mr. Ducett on his recent trip into Hay River and believe he can give you a very clear picture of the Hay River needs.

In view of the above I would request authority to take the plant out and have it sent to Edmonton by truck. I would feel that a better job can be expected there than at Hay River, and we will be money ahead in the long run.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

The Hay River light plant has been sent to Fairbanks Morse Edmonton for a good overhaul and will be out until the end of August. I have experienced so much trouble with power units at the schools during the past that I felt it would not be advisable to allow local so called mechanics to operate or work on the machine. The teacher is partly to blame in most cases by not showing much initiative or sense of responsibility.

These light plants are large complicated machines and with the AC outfit they must run 24 hours per day during cold weather and if they fail no power whatsoever is available to keep the place from freezing up. I cannot see why we are saddled with one large cumbersome plant about twice as large as we need for all but about one or two special occasions and no standbys. Each and every school would have been much easier to operate and much less bother if they had two small plants of possibly 3 KW and we would then always have a standby and the cost of both would have been no more than the one large one we now have. At these out-of-the-way places there are no mechanics and when the plant stops some of the hay wire teachers go at them with a screwdriver and we end up with a big repair bill. In most cases we cannot blame the teacher because to not get the plant going would result in everything freezing up but it does make maintenance a very difficult problem.

At Hay River we will be doing away with the light plant next summer but in the mean time we should have a small standby of possibly 3 KW. This is the only AC school in my Agency but I know that Mr. Hunter has several in his Agency (Franklin is best example) where a standby is a must. Can we not purchase
a small 3 KW or such like for Hay River with the understanding that it go to what-ever school Mr. Hunter requires it at next year when we hook onto Hay River power. The older these plants get the more grief we will get and with such large units one must get expert mechanics to run them and we do not have these in many points. The A.C. plant must run 24 hours a day and it is only reasonable that they will give out so that a standby is not a unnecessary piece of equipment but a must. One small plant of this type could be moved from any point to another at small cost and could make our work here a lot easier.

Enclosed are two wires received from W.A. Bowerman at Hay River during the present wet cold spell we are having. They are the type of wires we get and the addition of one small standby plant for use at any point where needed would more than justify the cost.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

The only comment I would make would be to recall to your attention that owing to the lack of proper insulation in this structure, and particularly under the floor, this dwelling was treated just the opposite to that for which it was designed and specified. Instead of having it left open below the floor, in order to keep from freezing Mr. Bauerma banked the walls and opened the furnace wide. How much the thermal regime under this house was disturbed could be a matter of eternal controversy."

I also enclosed a sketch showing the numbers given these pilings and the extent of shimming placed under each. A copy of this sketch is attached hereto.

3. From the files I.A. 1356-9 and Mr. W. Campbell's plan 62-17A it would appear:

Original boring for permafrost was done prior to July 30th, 1947 (date of Mr. Campbell's log).

It is difficult to determine from file I.A. 1356-9 just when the placing of piling was done, but wood lath and other building supplies had been ordered and delivered prior to June, 1948.

A contract agreement was signed with Peter Mattson dated March 10, 1948, and final Claim statement was presented under date of April 1st, 1949.

It is reasonable to assume, therefore, that the pilings were jetted down and placed about or before the spring of 1948.

4. Be that as it may seem, it is abundantly apparent that the teacherage pilings have sunk at 7 points in both greater and less degree. The question is - "what causes these to sink?" The fact that they did sink can only be explained by reasoning that there was no permafrost gripping those that sank. This could be possible if:

(a) there was no permafrost at those points originally;

(b) in jetting down with steam, the permafrost table and the thermal regime was altered and never recovered.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6473, file 905-5, part 4)

CANADA
(c) the permafrost table was altered by other causes.

5. In considering (a) we have one bore hole put down by Mr. Campbell in 1947 as a guide. This was sunk on which is now the south wall of the teacherage proper. This (#9) encountered permafrost at 8 feet. Sixty feet south east another hole (#13) encountered permafrost at 10.5 feet. Directly east and 100 feet from Hole No. 9 permafrost was encountered at 8 feet in Hole No. 8. This hole was checked by the writer. Hole No. 10 at 75 feet due south of Hole No. 9 gave permafrost at 14 feet.

6. All these holes would convey the idea that the permafrost table was constant over 75 to 100 feet, but we cannot be certain about the permafrost table between these distances. A great deal can happen in 100 or less feet in the Hay River area. Consider Hole No. 1 with permafrost (Mr. Campbell's log) at 11 feet while Hole No. 2, 75 feet south had no permafrost at 20 feet of depth. The writer checked this hole and got no permafrost at 25 feet of depth.

7. Turning to (b) and reviewing Mr. Campbell's log we find that one foot of moss and peaty loam was encountered at the surface. The removal of this would in itself tend to disturb the permafrost level to some extent, but its effect at 8 feet of depth would not be great; however, it would have some effect on the rate of restoration of the permafrost table and thermal regime after thawing. A far greater effect would occur during the steam jetting of holes, particularly if the jet was left in any hole or at any point longer than was necessary. There is no information to guide an opinion on this. Nor do we know anything concerning the time and manner in which the permafrost table and thermal regime would recover and regain former horizons. In general terms we know that recovery would depend upon:

(1) the structure and texture of the ground both above and below the thawing limit in depth;
(2) the thickness of this underlying permafrost and the behaviour of the ground above it;
(3) the temperature regime of the ground;
(4) the hydrologic regime of the ground.

8. We know also that in some areas, notably around Yellowknife, recovery of the thermal regime and permafrost table is, at the greatest time, only a matter of a few days but the texture, type of ground, and other characteristics at Yellowknife are much different from Hay River.

9. Considering (c) and (d), the hydrologic regime of the ground, we have one interesting fact. Mr. Campbell's Hole No. 1 struck permafrost at 11 feet with water at 8 feet. The writer's check on this hole gave a very wet layer at 10.5 feet. Ground below this caved badly and had to be abandoned at 16 feet with no permafrost encountered. This shows that the permafrost table had changed at least at one point. Mr. Campbell's Hole No. 2 has already been mentioned. The writer's check substantiated this boring and also that the hole was wet. Mr. Campbell's Hole No. 10 (75 feet south of No. 9) showed a wet layer at 11 feet being 3 feet above permafrost. One hole bored near the West Channel gave a wet layer within permafrost. This horizon was slightly above the water level of the West Channel. All of which would indicate that this ground at Hay River has water layers...
through it at various horizons. When one considers that the river rises as high as 10 or 11 feet above the water level at the time of boring there is ample opportunity for these water horizons to become real water channels with a complete change in the hydrologic regime. The fact that pilings 2, 3, 6, 8 and 11 were not noticed to have sunk until this spring supports very strongly this belief that an alteration in the hydrologic regime had a marked affect.

10. The writer tends to the belief that all (a) (b) and (c) contributed to the sinking. In other words it is possible that the permafrost table even fairly close to Hole No. 9 was not at the horizon that hole indicated; that the thawing completely upset the thermal regime and recovery did not take place in the degree necessary to hold the piling. Finally, this thawing had formed a "slud" which permitted entrance to a water horizon which in the spring became a channel.

I. M. Marshall.

Dear Sir:

Hay River Light Plant Operation.

With reference to your wire of September 1st, I wish to advise that I have taken this matter of plant maintenance up while in Hay River and the services of one good reliable plant operator to service this plant once every week and who will be available at any time to go and check on the plant if it fails has been obtained. This man will be entirely responsible for the plant and no one will be allowed to put a wrench on it.

This man has offered to do this for the sum of $30.00 per month. The plant will be fuelled up every day by the janitor and will be kept clean and attended by him but he will not be allowed to make any alterations but will report all faults he sees to the mechanic.

The only terms on which this mechanic would consider the plant was if it were entirely his responsibility in so far as any repairs or adjustment went and he will also set it in operation when it arrives back from Edmonton. I believe this a good arrangement and one that should save us money and breakdowns in the long run. I also consider the wages asked by him to be reasonable even though this work will be done in his after hours spare time.

I trust that the above will meet with your approval.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.
Dear Sir;

The Hay River School teacherage was gone over with a carpenter and will be divided into two apartments with a kitchen, combined living room and dining room and a bedroom each. There is very little way to provide two bathrooms so it will be necessary for the two couples to use the one bathroom.

The work is to be started next week and should be done within two weeks or less from that. This will include the building of a kitchen cupboard and putting in a sink, this to be painted and all other new wood work varnished. As it was a necessity to have the kitchen cupboard put in and I did not have time to wire for authority to purchase plywood for the job while at Hay River I instructed the carpenter to purchase the materials needed and the labour for this work will come out of the advance being sent to me.

As it is impossible to put in an oil or wood stove as we have no second chimney it is necessary to provide an electric range and put in a stove outlet. An Edmonton electrician, who is doing Government work on contract has enough material and time to put this in. As all the insulation is out of the floor this is the only time to put it in and this will be carried out.

I believe that the arrangement of two apartments should be satisfactory and although the building does not lend itself to making two perfect apartments the present arrangement is the best possible without building another house.

Yours very truly,

L.F. Kirkby, Supt. of Indian Affairs

PREVIOUS ER 379
Yellowknife, N.W.T.,
Sept. 18th, 1950.

B.F. Neary, Esq.,
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

During the past few days I have been in Hay River and several visits were paid to the school. The new term has been going for one and a half weeks and I wish to advise that the school both from the point of cleanliness and also discipline has improved many times over last year.

It was a pleasure to go through the school, the floors were clean and shiny and all rooms were free from dirt and paper. The present janitor has made a wonderful job and though he is not a mechanic who could run the light plant, has done a better job than anyone we have had so far and will be of much more value to the school than any other man in Hay River.

The class rooms were clean, desks were clean, the children had made a thorough clean-up for the week end and at the end of the day each room marched out instead of a mad scramble as last year. I am very pleased with the appearance of the new teacher and can only say that I wish the rest of our teachers at the other schools were half as good. Hay River, has, I believe, become a credit to the district and to Indian Affairs. If the DPW would complete their work and hand over the completed job and leave the maintenance to us the entire school set-up would be much easier to administer.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

26/9/50

Dear Sir:

Re: Hay River Indian Day School, Hay River, N.W.T.

On June 19th and 20th, I inspected the Hay River Indian Day School and report as follows:

1. The school opened officially on February 28, 1949.

2. Buildings

The school is a very fine building, but it is not complete. The grounds around the school are very swampy and should be filled in in some places and levelled off in others. As Mr. W. J. Johnson, D.P.W., had told us that the school would be ready by the end of February, we moved in. This was a sad mistake as there was no heat, light or water in the building and the children had to remain in school during the months of March, April and May with their parkas on to keep warm.

The teachers' residence is also incomplete. There is no light, heat or water and there is insufficient furniture. As a result of the lack of these facilities, Mr. Bellevance, Superintendent Martin and the pupils have suffered a great deal from the cold. This made a very poor beginning for the school and has hindered its progress.

A 10 kilowatt generator is being installed. As it will cost about $100 per month to operate the machine, I discussed this matter with Superintendent Martin who told me that he would have no difficulty in getting some of the local families to connect with the supply and thus reduce the overhead cost.

3. Attendance

When the school opened in February, there were 51 pupils in attendance; 21 Indian children, 30 Whites and Half-Breeds. At the time of my visit, there were 30 pupils present, consisting of 19 boys and 11 girls. I found that this attendance of 30 had been approximately 100% from the commencement of school with the exception of the period from April 27th to May 9th when the river was breaking up and it was impossible for them to get across. The group that were there consisted only of Whites and Half-Breeds.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6473, file 905-6, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
I questioned the fact that no Indians were present. Mr. Bellevance told me that he had found it necessary to scold the Indian children and to use corporal punishment. As a result, the Indian children refused to attend. Again, one of the Indian girls had been reprimanded for chewing gum and thus replied, "No gum, no school!" The Indian children went home about the beginning of March and did not return.

In this regard, I asked Mr. Bellevance if he had visited any of the Indian homes or discussed the matter with the parents. He admitted that he had not visited any of the homes nor done anything to bring them back. He said that the Indians should be in a separate school by themselves. In a discussion shortly following this, the local Priest brought forth the same view that he thought that the Indian children should be in a separate school on the island and that the new school should be used for Whites and Half-Breeds.

During the conversation with the Priest, he informed me that there were some 25 children of school age in the area but they were out in the bush. When I questioned him more closely, he admitted that they were on the island all the time.

Mr. Todd, a local resident, visited the school towards the beginning of March and asked the Principal to take his sixteen-year-old boy into Grade VIII. Mr. Bellevance told him that he did not have to enroll anyone over sixteen years of age. Shortly after Mr. Bellevance told me this, the local Priest informed me that the Principal of the school did not have to take anyone into school sixteen years of age or over. I informed him that his statement was incorrect as anyone, immaterial of age, may attend school and that it is compulsory for Indian children to attend up to and including the age of sixteen years.

I am inclined to believe that both the local Priest and Mr. Bellevance have done nothing to assure regular attendance and, if anything, have tried to drive the children out.

In order to assure proper attendance, I would recommend that compulsory attendance be enforced for children up to the age of sixteen years, as laid down by the Indian Act, and that this compulsory attendance commence September 1, 1949. I understand that an Indian Agent is being appointed to the Hay River area and, if this is correct, he could quite easily attend to this as one of his duties, or, if this is not the case, a Truant Officer should be appointed to visit the homes of delinquents and strictly enforce compulsory attendance measures. If it is our wish to keep the Hay River School operating on a proper basis similar to the provinces, compulsory attendance must be enforced at the earliest possible date.

4. Classroom Work.

On examination of the children in their studies, I found them to be intelligent, clean and co-operative. The age range is from seven to fourteen years. I found that the children in Grade I had not been taught reading

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6473, file 905-6, part 1)
and that Mr. Bellevance had been emphasizing phonetics, which is a most unprogressive method of teaching. He also had the Grade I pupils attempting to write without first having taught them to print, which method has been found the most satisfactory. He had not taken the trouble to wire Ottawa for Grade I readers nor had he bothered to borrow Grade I readers from the residents who had Grade I readers in their possession, so the Grade I lacked this equipment. You will agree that it must have been a very difficult task for the pupils in Grade I to sit for three months without any reading industry and proper supervision.

At the time of the visit, he told me that he had requested that Grades I, II and III stay home the following day as he was going to give Grades IV, V and VI a test.

Mr. Bellevance had no text books for Grade I and had made out no requisitions for books or supplies to be sent in.

There has been no hot noon lunch served at all.

The Priest gave religious instruction in the school from 3:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. every day.

There was a holiday on June 13th although the reason for such a holiday is not clear.

5. Sports and Community Life

Mr. Bellevance has organized no sports in the school and the school has not been used as a Community Centre. In conversation with both Roman Catholic and Protestant residents at Hay River, I was informed that Mr. Bellevance had not visited their homes nor taken any interest in the Community. When questioned, Mr. Bellevance admitted that he liked living to himself and did not trouble to visit anyone. He said that he did not like Hay River and that the people of Hay River did not like him. He further stated that the Indians of Rocher River were a very hard people to manage and felt that he would like to have an Indian school somewhere else.

6. Qualifications.

Mr. Bellevance holds a Second Class Manitoba and Saskatchewan Teaching Certificate and has 24 years of experience, 15 years of which has been spent in Indian schools. He has spent 11 years with the Indian Affairs Branch and is a permanent Civil Servant. Mr. Bellevance is married; 52 years of age.

7. General

Superintendent Martin informed me that there were some 210 families who took part in the local election. This consisted of about 50 Indian and 160 White and Half-Breed families. About 100 residential lots have been granted in Hay River and, according to the local people, the Hay River School will be filled to capacity within the next year or so. However, there is no need of a separate school on the island as there is adequate accommodation for all the families in the new school for time to come.
It is recommended that every effort should be made to have Mr. W. J. Johnson, D.P.W., finish the Hay River school before the fall term starts.

I note that a local Administrative District Unit has been organized in the Hay River area, similar to the one at Yellowknife. This Administrative Unit goes out two miles in all directions from the northwest corner of Lot 71.

I was informed by Superintendent Martin that a local Trustee Board had been formed. Superintendent Martin said that he was of the opinion that the people of Hay River can afford to pay their share of the cost of education. I am of the opinion that the only satisfactory solution to the Hay River School problem would be the formation of an elected School Board, similar to the one at Yellowknife and that the new school be turned over to the local residents on the understanding that they would pay their share of the cost of operating same.

Some of the local people resent the fact that the Indian children are permitted to go to the same school as the Whites and Half-Breeds because of the danger of Tuberculosis. Therefore, every precaution should be taken to ensure that the children are medically examined. Right now, there is an X-Ray Clinic here in Yellowknife which has been sent in by the Charles Camsel Hospital. It is suggested that the same procedure be followed at Hay River.

I discussed the idea of operating the Hay River Indian Day School during the summer vacation with practically all of the local residents and found that they were opposed to this idea as they felt that their children needed a rest. I would concur with them in the view that the school not be operated during the summer holidays as the local people remain in the district throughout the year.

I note that the services of two Protestant teachers, Mr. Bowerman and his wife, have been obtained. I would be very pleased to receive information as to the qualifications and past experience of both teachers. It is vital that teachers appointed to the Hay River Indian Day School fall in the category of Welfare Teacher as there is much welfare work to be done in this area.

Also, I would recommend that all teachers for the Northwest Territories schools be selected from the Province of Alberta. I make this statement as both Roman Catholic and Protestant teachers in the Province of Alberta take the same Normal School training and, also, it is a very difficult task for outside teachers to adapt the Alberta Curriculum to northern areas. Alberta teachers have a thorough knowledge of the Alberta Curriculum and are qualified to teach all subjects as authorized for Elementary, Intermediate and High School courses. They are also familiar with departmental procedures as laid down by the Alberta Department of Education.

I have discussed with Dr. Lazerte, Dean of the Faculty of Education of the Province of Alberta,

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6473, file 905-6, part 1)
the type of teacher required for Northwest Territories schools and qualifications necessary. He assured me that he would be willing to select, at our request, the very best type of Roman Catholic and Protestant teachers for Northwest Territories schools. I would be quite willing to go to Edmonton to interview the prospective teachers which had been screened by Dr. Lazerte, should the Department of Mines and Resources wish to follow this procedure.

Schools in the Northwest Territories demand a higher type of teacher than is required anywhere else in the Dominion. This is due to the fact that there is such a great need for welfare work, the number of grades that it is necessary for one teacher to teach, and the general conditions under which the teacher must work.

In the Hay River Indian Day School it is likely that some pupils will be requiring Grade XII education next September. In this connection, we should bear in mind that a Second Class Teacher from any of the provinces would not be able to teach Grade XII subjects as authorized by the Alberta Curriculum. Teachers from provinces foreign to Alberta also have difficulty in teaching Grade XI and XII subjects as laid down by the Alberta Curriculum. It is for this reason, also, that I recommend the employment of Alberta teachers in the Northwest Territories schools.

I would suggest that the Roman Catholic principal selected for the Hay River Indian Day School have at least a First Class Alberta Certificate and a University Degree. Under regulations set up by the Alberta Department of Education, pupils may not be granted credit for Grade X, XI and XII subjects unless they are taught by a principal who is the holder of a University Degree.

I visited Roche River on July 19th and found the new school well on the way to completion. The Department of Public Works have constructed an excellent school. The carpenter in charge told me that he was waiting for some Ten-Test to finish up some of the rooms. With the necessary materials, it should take about ten days to complete. It will be one of the finest schools in Canada.

They will burn wood in the furnace. This can be obtained locally. They will use a direct current generator which will be run by batteries. I think that the idea of a direct current generator with batteries is very sound in view of the fact that the over-head cost will be kept at a minimum.

Seeing that we have an excellent school at Roche River, it is essential that a well-qualified First Class Welfare Teacher be employed. Again, I would recommend that a First Class Alberta Teacher be employed. A married male teacher would add stability to the education set-up. I cannot emphasize too strongly the importance of the Roche River School commencing operation at the earliest possible date, otherwise, children will leave the area and go to Fort Resolution. If possible, this school should begin operation this month. The local people were very disappointed that the school did not operate last September.
If it is possible to engage a First Class Alberta Teacher, married man, at this date, I would recommend that he should be employed for Roche River. However, if it is impossible to do this, there is no alternative but to send Mr. Bellevance there.

In order to get the best type of teacher, it is most important that transportation be paid to destination and that they be supplied with the very best accommodation. One of the severest criticisms of the teachers in the northern schools is that they are from France and do not speak the English language. In this connection, I might say that Mr. Bellevance speaks a broken English and is not competent to teach non-English children to read and write.

Respectfully submitted,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.

Health

There should be a medical check-up at this school each year and the school should be provided with vitamin pills.

Hot Noon Lunch

Two large electric hot-plates should be provided for the heating of soup, etc., for the hot noon lunch at this school. These hot-plates should be kept in the classrooms in order that the teachers do not have to leave their classrooms to attend to the preparation of this lunch. At the present time, the teacher has to leave her classroom to heat the soup on the stove in the teachers' residence. This situation is not satisfactory.

Fishing Industry

Mr. Bowerman is handling the fishing industry for Indian Agent Kirby and is attending to nets, equipment, and so forth. During my visit, he was showing the Indians how to line-up nets and get them ready for the commencement of the fishing season. He will visit the fishing grounds periodically and the homes of the Indians who are out fishing in order to take mail back and forth and supervise them in their work.

Mr. Bowerman will also help the Indians in the handling of their money. About 50% of their earnings will be given to the wives for food, clothing, etc., and the other 50% will be banked in order to defray cost of equipment, and so forth, and also to encourage the Indians to save for the future.
