Mr. John Vincent Kennedy

Mr. Kennedy has no aptitude for teaching. He is unhappy at Hey River and stated that the climate disagreed with him and that he would like to return to Nova Scotia. I would advise his transfer at an early date, January 1, if possible.

I have received criticism from the parents in that he has not been correcting the pupils' work.

Mr. Kennedy has no control whatsoever over the children in his classroom. I am of the opinion that his eyesight is so bad that he is unable to see all of the pupils in the classroom. I have been informed that he is partly deaf.

Mr. Kennedy gave 90 corporal punishments in October, and, during the past month, he found it necessary to administer 40 more. However, this is just making a mockery out of education and I am of the opinion that he does not hurt any of the children as I was told that he is not very strong. Mr. Bowerman pointed out to him that, during his twenty years of teaching, he found it necessary to use the strap only three times.

In appearance, Mr. Kennedy is dirty, untidy, and not well-groomed. He lacks the ability to care for equipment.
The pupils cannot read well. I feel that Mr. Kennedy has no idea of the techniques to be used in reading. This not only applies to reading but to all other subjects of the curriculum. Teaching is just a hit-and-miss process as far as Mr. Kennedy is concerned.

I visited this school on two occasions and both times I discussed with Mr. Kennedy the proper methods of teaching all subjects of the curriculum. During my last visit I spent some three or four hours discussing educational matters with him in order to improve the work of his room. However, as Mr. Kennedy has no control over his class, I am sure that this time was wasted and thus I would advocate his transfer at an early date.

Mr. Kennedy taught Health by putting notes on the blackboard and having the children copy them. I pointed out to him that Health was something to be lived, not learned from blackboard notes—to see that the room was clean, that the children were washed and wore clean clothes, that the children kept their books clean and that the children were taught the value of sleep. The pupils of this room were untidy, dirty and tired.

During my visit to Mr. Kennedy's room, no fewer than 25 children went to the toilet in ten minutes.

If the Department is interested in the welfare of this school, they will remove Mr. Kennedy as soon as possible. I would recommend that Mrs. Wilson, who has submitted her application, be taken on temporarily.

Mathematics

I tested the pupils in the field of mathematics and found them quite efficient and well up to standard in both the Public and High School grades.

Music

Excellent training is being given in Music. The children of this school, under Mr. Bowerman's leadership, presented a programme of one hour's duration over the local Broadcasting Station. This programme was...
greatly enjoyed by the people of Bay River and the surrounding district.

Social Studies

I feel that the pupils are obtaining fine instruction in the field of Social Studies, under Mr. Bowerman's supervision. He correlates History, Mathematics, Art, and other subjects, which is commendable. In teaching the constitutional history of Canada, he has prepared an excellent chart which simplifies this subject for the pupils. By this means, the children may be well prepared for the final examination in this subject.

Art

The Art work in this room is well up to standard. The children are being trained to use their own initiative and imagination. The subject is correlated with Social Studies and other subjects of the curriculum. I was pleased with the way this subject was being handled in this room.

General

I found the discipline and general tone of the classroom good; the children were very alert and eager to learn.

Mr. Bowerman is neat in appearance; he is most energetic and puts a lot of "pep" into his work. Mr. Bowerman is very free with his time and is carrying a tremendous load. The welfare work alone which he is doing is a full-time job.

General

During my visit, I found certain conditions about the school which had a great deal to be desired. Firstly, as both Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Bowerman were receiving the same salary, each felt that he did not have to meet the wishes of the other. I found that the lack of a principal for this school has resulted in certain undesirable conditions and, in order to preserve the buildings and further the welfare of the school, I appointed Mr. Bowerman Acting-Principal.

In order to bring about better discipline in the school as a whole, I suggested to Mr. Bowerman that he have a morning and evening assembly of all the children at which time there could be group singing, a discussion of pertinent matters, daily announcements, etc., and thus foster better discipline in the school.

I also suggested that teachers be present at each corridor during the assembly and dismissal periods. I further pointed out that the children were arriving at the school too early in the morning and, without supervision...
at this time, they ran all over the school and thus caused a great deal of confusion and in some cases, damage of property. During my last visit, I noted that this matter had been rectified; Mr. Bowerman had requested that the teachers arrive at 8:30 a.m. They were free to leave at 3:30 p.m.

Magistrate Martin informed me that the above suggestions had improved the school a great deal.

I found Mr. Bowerman to be very open-minded and very open to suggestions as, when I made recommendations, he put them into effect immediately. This is a healthy condition. However, to preserve the school and further education at this centre, I would recommend Magistrate Martin be appointed immediately as Official Trustee with authority to dismiss the present caretaker if he is unsuitable to do the required work. This school should be cleaned from top to bottom. Two hundred pounds of wax should be provided and an electric polisher provided to ensure that the building may be put in first class shape. The Government has made a tremendous investment in this school and I see no other way in which it may be preserved for many years.

I would like to emphasize the importance of making Magistrate Martin Official Trustee with the powers of a School Board in order that the Hay River School be streamlined. As there are approximately one hundred white children attending this school, it is vital that it be made one of the best in Canada. The parents of these children come from good schools in the Provinces and thus they will demand the best.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Sir:

In company with Indian Agent Kirkby, I inspected educational facilities at Hay River on May 29th and would report as follows:

Teachers' Residence

The teachers' residence at Hay River is large and oversize. It is too large for one couple with the result that it costs twice as much to heat as it should.

I can not see the necessity of a seven-room house being needed for one teacher, but, without making it into a duplex I do not consider it at all satisfactory for two couples. I would suggest that some competent builder be asked to make an estimate of the change and that it be proceeded with this summer in time to take care of the new teacher who will be replacing Mr. Kennedy.

I feel that a small, compact residence has a tendency to make people more thrifty and to divide this house will give each party adequate room. We will continue to have many complaints if teachers are expected to live in one common house.

I have discussed the above matter with Indian Agent Kirkby. In view of the fact that the physical plant comes under his jurisdiction, he has submitted to Colonel B.F. Neary, sketch plans indicating the manner in which the teachers' residence might be made into a duplex at little additional cost. It would be possible to put the Principal into the lower suite and to put one couple or, if we had two single teachers, they could both occupy the upstairs suite as it would have two large bedrooms as well as kitchen and bathroom.

Attendance

The Indians at Hay River have received every assistance. Attendance last fall was kept up by Mr. Bowerman paying a man to bring the children across the river. As Mr. Bowerman is not assisting them this spring, the Indian children are not attending school. Yet, the Indian children do come across the river to visit the soda fountain as soon as school is out.
If the Indian took any responsibility on his own shoulders, he would take his own children and his neighbours' children over in their large canoes, but, they are looking for us to do it all. I believe the Indian feels that by staying away and not providing any assistance, he is forcing our hand and we must either provide a boat, cancel the Family Allowance or build a school on his side of the river which would divide Hay River with the result that the Indian and White would drift more apart instead of being assimilated as we are trying to do.

Under the present regulations, White and Half-Breed children can stay away from school under any pretext they like because we have no organized school districts. In most cases, the Indian and Half-Breed are educated but one is exempt from school regulations with the result that forcing one without the other causes nothing but ill-will for everyone. In this regard, we are badly in need of some unified policy.

Instruction

During my short time at Hay River, I observed lessons in all rooms and tested the senior classes. I consider the type of instruction to be fair as there is much room for improvement. Greater care should be given to the selection of our teaching personnel -- particularly to teachers selected by the Indian Affairs Branch.

Health

As Indian Agent Kirkby is responsible for the physical plant, I shall not report in detail in this regard. However, much improvement is required as to the general cleanliness and sanitation of this school. This poor condition may be due in part to the fact that the Caretaker had resigned and that there was no one available at the time of my visit to do caretaking services.

On January 4, 1950, I reported to Colonel Neary the unsuitability of Mr. Kennedy, and requested a transfer for Mr. Bowerman as he likes working with Indian children and has not the required experience to handle in a satisfactory manner the principalship of the Hay River school. My recent visit confirms these previous recommendations.

Electric Light Plant

I have discussed with Indian Agent Kirkby plans whereby the lighting plant may be operated only a few hours a day, thus creating a considerably saving during the spring and summer period.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd.) J.W. McKinnon

Dear Sir:

Sometime last fall a request was forwarded to Mr. D.J. Martin, Magistrate at Hay River to check on the school residence furniture and forward a complete list of all the equipment needed. Mr. Martin and Mr. Bowerman made up a list between them and I understood from them that it had been forwarded direct to you with the result that I did not receive a copy nor did I include any furniture on my requisitions for Hay River.

The residence at Hay River is very poorly furnished and is in need of the addition of many items that I have been informed, were included in Mr. Martin's list. As the shipping season is about to begin I would like to know whether any of this furniture can be expected so that certain plans can be made for the following summer and to be guided in my future requisitions.

One also receives enquiries from the teachers as to what they can expect for the following year so that they can make purchases of some items themselves if we are not going to supply. In this respect it would be of some value to be able to advise them what, if anything could be expected.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.
Dear Sir:

Re: Teacher's Residence Hay River

During the past term the school Residence at Hay River has been occupied by the Principal and part of the upstairs by the second man teacher. In this residence there is one kitchen and one bathroom while the second teacher has set up a small electric range in his bedroom and being a single man has managed to get along with a very unsatisfactory arrangement. We have also had the continual complaining by the Principal that this man did nothing towards cleaning the stairs and other items which brings us to the point that two parties cannot live in the same residence and have any type of satisfactory arrangement where they have to use the same kitchen, bathroom, living room, stairs etc. and there will always be a continual complaining by one or both parties that the other man is getting too much.

The residence at Hay River is a large oversize place that is much too large for one couple with the result that it costs twice as much to heat as it should and we have but one residence where we need two. The size of this house is such that it could be made into two suites with very little work or expense and we would then have quarters for two couples while each would have his own private portion of the house.

There are two alternatives to making this house into a satisfactory duplex, one is to divide the house into two halves giving each couple two large rooms downstairs and two bedrooms upstairs with both using the same stairway which would possibly result in some friction as to who should do the cleaning. The other alternative is to put an outside
stairway up the back to the first landing of the present stairs and put in an outside door with the result that the principal would have a four roomed suite downstairs and the second teacher would have a four roomed suite upstairs. In this way no cutting of the building is necessary and all that is required is to put on an outside stairway, put in one outside doorway and one doorway leading downstairs to make the upstairs private. Downstairs one of the large rooms or two for that matter would have to have closets put into them to make bedroom storage with a bathroom off one of these rooms and we could then accommodate two teachers without increasing the cost of heating or maintenance with a small expenditure for minor changes.

I cannot see the necessity of a seven roomed house plus bath, plus halls and with food storage space available in the furnace room being needed for one teacher, but without making it into a duplex I do not consider it at all satisfactory for two couples. When the second teacher is through the day he, or she, should be free to prepare for the next day and not be bothered by trying to please the Principal nor should he have to please the teacher. I would suggest that the DPW or some competent builder be asked to make an estimate of the change and that it be proceeded with this summer in time to take care of the new teacher who will be replacing Mr. Kennedy.

I have enclosed a sketch of the present residence and though I do not know the exact size of the building all the rooms are large with the result that the suites will each have more floor space than most cottages have and each teacher will still have more room than he would get in a large percentage of the teacherages at many schools in the provinces.

The present power house and furnace room are very good size and once the Hay River central power are put in the light plant can be taken out of that section of the building and shelves and storage space for rations for both teachers will be available. As it is a room off the furnace room it will be heated with no freezing danger. The building is joined to the main residence so that no hardship will be encountered by having to go into this building for rations at meal time.

I feel that a small compact residence has a tendency to make people more thrifty and to divide this house will give each party adequate room that they can look after instead of too much room that is not used nor kept looking neat and clean at all times. During the past year the complaints about two parties living in one common house have been heard but have not been pressed but this spring they are heard more often and we will have much discontent at Hay River among the teachers in our residence if they are all expected to live in one common
house that is plenty large enough for two small families but which has one common kitchen, bathroom etc. and leaves no one with any privacy at all.

The sketches are herewith enclosed for your consideration and I feel justified in recommending that this residence be made into a duplex for the teaching staff. With the change it would be possible to put the principal into the lower suite and to put one couple upstairs or if we had two single women teachers they could both occupy the upstairs suite as it would have two large bedrooms as well as kitchen and bathroom.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I was in Hay River upon receipt of your wire and it was found that all carpenters of any account at all were either working for the D.P.W. or they were steadily employed and not in town. It was therefore impossible to get anyone to make an estimate or put in a tender to do the complete job of putting in an outside stairway for the residence and putting in cupboards for the upstairs kitchen and a clothes closet for the bedroom downstairs.

I was able to inspect the building in company with the D.P.W. foreman and the enclosed list of materials was made out to cover the work required. These materials would have to be provided in any case and as they are not available in Hay River they might just as well be ordered by us direct from one of the Edmonton lumber yards.

As the job is of such short duration one cannot bring in an outside carpenter and the D.P.W. foreman has informed me that he will put one of his men on the job provided we pay his wages so that it does not come out of the money he has available for his own work. At the present time they are not too busy and could spare the man.

If the materials could be ordered immediately for shipment by truck from Edmonton to Hay River it should be possible to complete the work by the time school starts or very shortly after.

If by the time the materials arrive it is possible to get a carpenter to put in a bid on the job I will wire, but the materials must be provided at once if we are to get the work.
done in time to install the new teacher.

The whole change including stairs, clothes closet and cupboards should not run to more than $300.00 and will provide for two small families instead of the one as it now stands.

Yours very truly,

Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Resolution, N.W.T.,
September 24, 1928.

Sir,

From Resolution we proceeded to Rae and the treaty was paid as soon as we recovered sufficiently on the 6th.

The main topic was the closing of beavers. The second question was a demand for a day school, idea that some half breed had put in the heads of the Indians, unpracticable, on account of so few Indians staying near the fort, and the high fuel, fish etc., but the idea had been launched with the Indians and they do not realize the difference between day and boarding school, so this will hurt the recruiting of children, and the Mission does not see the utility of a day school more than we do.

C. Bourget, M.D.,
Indian Agent.
I was asked last summer by some of these Indians of Rae to give them a day school, which is at present quite a proposition due to the expenses of a building, fuel at excessive costs and the monotony of the life there, but I presume if they do insist, with time it may be a solution that must be found, and then one school teacher could then be engaged to do the two duties. Of course, I am against this day school as it would provide school for a few children only, the majority of Indians being far in the woods part of the year, and it would end the recruiting for the boarding school, but I am afraid the Indians will become more and more insistant on that question, being encouraged by a half breed who is on treaty and put the idea in their heads, and as they do not see the difference between a day school and boarding school they think it is the same thing on a smaller scale than the boarding school.
Ft. Resolution, N.W.T.,
July 31, 1935.

Sir,

I beg to report on the Treaty Trip and payment of Annuities to the Indians of the Great Slave Lake Agency for 1935.

The Indians of Rae do not like to place their children in any residential school for the simple reason that they would like to visit their children occasionally and cannot afford to come to Resolution. They would rather like a day school. I have had enough experience so far with the Indians, to recommend this, and leave it to your discretion.

Dr. J. E. Amyot,
Indian Agent.

Dear Doctor Amyot:

The Department received your telegram of April 18th, with the greatest regret. I think there is a fair prospect of being able to station a nurse at Fort Rae, and to build accommodation for her as soon as such action can be taken in the summer. The present hope is to build a day school there with accommodation for a teacher and a nurse. In the meantime, if mail conditions will at all permit, I wish you would forward any suggestions you have as to the best method of building at Fort Rae, and any other recommendations you may wish to make in regard to the proposal.

Dear Sirs:

As requested we are returning herewith the blue prints of an Indian Day School and Staff Residence for Fort Rae N.W.T.

In revising these plans we have kept very close to the original drawings in arrangement altho in the Staff Residence there may be more rooms arranged for than will be required.

The rooms on the ground floor of the Staff Residence can be heated from the furnace and be made into comfortable living quarters.

In our opinion especial bath room accommodation is not necessary but inside toilets are very convenient. Our experience with chemical toilets has been that there is no odor except when emptying if properly vented to the chimney. We have arranged exit doors from the toilets for quick access to the outside for emptying purposes.

The construction of the buildings is similar to all others that we have erected in the North West Territories and seems to be best suited for their requirements.

The Pupils desks, Teachers desk and chair and visitors chair, blackboards, chalk rail and mouldings we consider as fixtures. The additional school supplies enumerated in the specifications which we consider necessary, amounts to $90.05. There are of course other supplies that will be necessary such as kitchen stoves, cooking utensils, household furniture, etc.

We regret that on account of other urgent work in hand there was a slight delay in completing the plans and estimates but on account of the short season the work should be started as soon as possible.

If the work is entrusted to us we will lose no time in getting the material ordered and will arrange to start the work as soon as the material can be transported to the site.

Yours truly

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, Ont., August 23, 1944.

Dr. H. W. McGill, Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Attached is a copy of a letter dated August 17, in which our Agent and Superintendent of Wood Buffalo Park draws attention to the need of a day school at Rae, N.W.T.

Before writing Bishop Trocellier I would appreciate an expression of your views and to what extent your Branch would be prepared to support a day school at Rae. As you are probably aware, this Administration pays annual grants of $200.00 to day schools operated in the southern or Indian sectors of the N.W.T. provided the average daily attendance is five or more. I do not know whether there are sufficient white and half-breed children in the Rae area to justify payment of a school grant as it is noted from the 1941 census that of the total population of 767 there are 686 Indians.

Encl.

R. A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner of the Northwest Territories.

Memorandum:

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Deputy Commissioner,
Northwest Territories.

Re: Establishment of Day School, Rae, N.W.T.

I have for acknowledgment your memorandum of August 23, in which you seek an expression of opinion from this Branch with respect to the establishment and operation of a day school at Rae, North West Territories.

The officials of the Welfare and Training Division inform me that there is very little on file here relating to educational facilities at Rae. If, however, there are five or more Indians of school age at this point, we shall be glad to co-operate with you to the fullest extent possible in the establishment of a school. Would it be possible to establish this school on the understanding that the cost of maintenance would be borne on a pro rata basis by the two Branches? You might communicate with me again after you have discussed the matter with Bishop Trocellier?

Dear Sir,

Owing to my prolonged absence from Fort Smith, I have not had the opportunity of replying sooner to your letter of August 31, relative to the opening of a day school at Fort Rae.

Actually it is too late for supplies to be sent to Fort Rae this year. While there are five Sisters resident in the hospital there, it would be difficult to spare one of them for teaching, for they already have sufficient work to keep them busily occupied each day.

Although one of the buildings purchased by the mission from the R.C.M.P. detachment would be suitable for class-room purposes, I am of the opinion that very few children could be found to attend. For the greater part of the year, entire families are obliged to live in the bush, in order to live. Those who would necessarily remain in the Fort while their children are going to school, would have no means of sustenance whatsoever. Perhaps half a dozen children might be found, to come to the school, but judging from the means of livelihood of these people, I feel certain that the number of children who could actually attend regularly, would hardly warrant the opening of a school.

Bernard Neary, Esq.,
Supervisor of Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Booth Building, Sparks Street,

Re Day-school at Fort Rae.

On August 19th I made a survey of educational conditions at Fort Rae with a view to determining the possibility of opening a day school there.

I inspected the building purchased by the Roman Catholic Mission from the R.C.M.P. for possible use as a day-school. I also interviewed Chief J. Bruno and local residents with regard to the proposal. At Bruno's invitation, I visited the Indians in their tents, and saw for myself the urgent need for the provision of school facilities.

Dr. Riopel of Fort Resolution advised me that there were about 150 children of school age in the locality, and that they were badly in need of a school. The general opinion appeared to be that ultimately there should be a residential school erected at this point. I discussed this matter with Bishop Trocellier who confirmed this view.

As a temporary and immediate solution to the problem, I would recommend the following procedure:

(1) That the mission day-school be opened for the remainder of the current school year.

(2) Since the services of a properly qualified teacher are available locally, that the cost of salary, school supplies and a fair rent for the building be borne on a pro rata basis by the Bureau of Northwest Territories and the Indian Affairs Branch.
With respect to the building itself, I would add that it is divided into two rooms, one 14 feet by 11 feet, and the other 21 feet by 15 feet, and it has an 8-foot ceiling. I would suggest that a beginning be made with small classes, due to the entire illiteracy of the children.

Although I was told by the local priest that not two percent of the Indians in the area could read or write, I saw for myself the possibilities for improving this condition when I inspected the Dog Rib Indian children under Sister MacQuillan at Fort Providence. This sister had such children as young as six years of age reading and speaking English after only a few weeks of schooling.

J. W. McKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

We have an opportunity to purchase the Buffum Property at Fort Rae for educational purposes. This property consists of a dwelling house thirty-six feet by twenty-two feet. It has on the ground floor, two bedrooms, dining room, and a kitchen and washroom. The upstairs consists of one large finished room. This residence is completely furnished except for linen and bedding. It contains a radio, two stoves, eight dining room chairs, two large beds, two cots, one Winnipeg couch, ice box, washing machine, twelve volt wind charger, storm doors and windows, and a full line of dishes and kitchen utensils. The floors are covered with linoleum and rugs. The building is in an excellent state of repair. It is well insulated and sided and would make an ideal residence for a teacher. About a year ago Mr. George Buffum refused an offer from the I. A. B. to purchase only the house for five thousand dollars. This did not include any of the land or surrounding buildings.

There is also on this land a store, forty feet by twenty-eight feet. It is of frame construction, well insulated, and in an excellent state of repair. It has a fir flooring and ceiling and was erected at an initial cost of six thousand dollars. It contains two stoves, a large teacher's desk, and some smaller furniture. The upstairs would make a play room. This building would make an excellent classroom which would accommodate about thirty pupils.

Besides the above, the property contains several log shacks of little value, an oil and ice house, and a frame building twenty-four feet by sixteen feet which would make a suitable storehouse.

I have discussed the advisability of purchasing this property with Mr. J. O. McNiven who concurs in the view that we should take advantage of this opportunity, as it would cost considerable more than ten thousand dollars to erect one of the buildings at present cost.
This property is free from mortgage and consists of three and one half acres of land on the water front. It is centrally located and is the only suitable site in Rae for a school. There would be plenty of room on this property for a playground, an Indian Agent and Doctor's residence. It would be advisable for the Government to have their own school on Government property, and personally I see such as the only sound educational policy. I was informed that there were about one hundred and fifty children of school age and that about twenty-five would attend school the first year. We could open a day school at this point in the hope that all the residents would gradually become educated to leave their wives and children in the Fort while out trapping. By doing such education would have an elevating effect on the local inhabitants and develop initiative. As Fort Rae is the largest Indian Settlement in the N.W.T., there is great need of an Indian Agent at this point. An ideal combination at this centre would be a man as Agent, whose wife was teacher. By such an arrangement it would be easier to hold and obtain the best type of Government employees.

I suggest that we take advantage of Mr. Buffum's offer and purchase the above property for ten thousand dollars. We should also purchase the fifty-five cords of wood on the said property at twelve dollars a cord as it will be impossible to obtain fuel oil this year. The Hudson's Bay Post Manager informed me that their carpenter will be at Rae for several weeks so we might take advantage of this opportunity to have the store renovated into a class room.

By purchasing the above property we are taking advantage of the one and only opportunity to attack education from a sound basis at this centre. Kindly advise Mr. George Buffum at Fort Rae as soon as possible of your decision, as he will be leaving soon for his home at 11136 - 67th Street, in Edmonton. Also there are several interested parties desiring this property.

Respectfully submitted,

J. W. McKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Meikle
Res. Fort Rae

I visited Fort Rae on June 26th and examined the need for a school at this point. In this connection my letter of July 1st addressed to Mr. R. A. Gibson concerning the purchase of the Buffum property should be consulted.

While at Fort Rae I discussed the local situation with Cst. Combs of the RCMP, the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company, the independent trader, and the local residents. They all requested that a government-operated day school be opened, together with accommodation for a teacher, in order that education might be placed on a firm foundation at this settlement. I was informed that there would be a minimum of 15 children who would attend school the first year. Since there are over 150 children of school age at Fort Rae, and since it is the largest Indian settlement in the Northwest Territories, there is great need for an Indian Agent and Doctor to be located here.

All with whom I spoke approved of the purchase of the Buffum property, as they were of the opinion that it was the only suitable site. Should the Indian Affairs Branch make an agreement to purchase this property, I would suggest that within the next few weeks the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company be contacted in order to secure the services of a carpenter for converting the store into a suitable classroom.

I suggest that a well-qualified practical man be appointed Indian Agent at this settlement, and that if possible he be a married man whose wife is a qualified teacher. I would like to emphasize the need for establishing a school and providing a properly furnished modern home. A ration allowance of $360 per person should be granted to the teacher, together with yearly transportation in and out of the Territories. These provisions, coupled with an adequate salary, will attract the desired type of employee, and they are in line with those enjoyed by employees of other government services stationed in the north.

J. W. McKinnon

Dear Sir:

On receipt of your wire re an Indian Day School at Fort Rae, I contacted the Police at that settlement and found that at present there are 12 Indian children of school age residing in the Fort. The Police stated that there were 30 desks and a sufficient quantity of text books, scribblers, pencils, blackboard material and so on, on hand to commence teaching.

I must state that I cannot see how a Day School would function to any advantage in Fort Rae. In the first place, these Indians are constantly leaving the settlement for trapping and hunting and if the school were a Day School it would be necessary that they take their children with them. Even in Fort Resolution there is great difficulty in assuring attendance of Day School pupils and I believe that the difficulties at Rae would be much greater; the attendance of the pupils would be so irregular that very little benefit would be derived from their attending classes.

While paying Annuities it is true that one of the complaints of the Indians at Rae was that they did not have a school and wanted one immediately but that is no guarantee that if there is a school available the children will attend.

The living conditions at Fort Rae could not be considered the best, due mainly to the isolation of the post. You mention that the girl is crippled - if her incapacity is marked she will have a very difficult time. However, I would not like to state that she could not handle the job, she may have the type of personality that could overcome such a handicap and possibly may render her more suitable and valuable as a teacher but she would undoubtedly be hindered trying to move around, particularly in the winter. At the present time there is only one other white woman at Fort Rae, excluding the Sisters, so her social activities would be limited.

In conclusion, I can only repeat that I do not recommend the opening of a Day School at Fort Rae at this time. It may be possible to run a Day School for two or three months in the summer when most of the Indians of the Band congregate at the settlement but even then I believe that the attendance figures would be disappointing. In my opinion Fort Rae requires a Residential School.

Yours very truly,

Proposed Indian Day School at Fort Rae

I have received your army signal and airmail letter concerning the above Indian Day School.

It was decided last Spring to open a day school at Rae on a temporary basis. Mr. J. W. McKinnon, Inspector of Schools for the Northwest Territories, had recommended this procedure because of the delays which will occur before we can consider the opening of a residential school there. At the present time the Department has many requests before it for residential schools and we realize that due to building and other conditions, we can only build a few of those required.

Therefore it was decided to open a day school at Rae, in order to educate at least a few of these children, and to accustom them to going to school, even if only during the summer months. Director.
Fort Rae:

There are 708 Indians in the Fort Rae Band; of these, 660 were present for annuity payment last summer. Others had wandered into the Bear Lake regions where they probably will remain.

The Fort Rae Indians are the most primitive in the agency. They have absolutely no conception of the state of affairs anywhere except in their own small area. Very few have any education, very few speak English. The Indians live by hunting and trapping, there is very little opportunity for employment in other lines. The Hudson's Bay Post Manager figures the average income to be $300.00 a year. Fishing is satisfactory and the caribou are plentiful in season.

When the white fox was valuable these people trapped far out in the Barrens and were quite wealthy. But now they are poor, dressed in ragged clothing and at times, particularly in summer, are really hungry. They no longer dry considerable quantities of fish and caribou and for the most part, wear store-bought clothing and live in tents.

Since this is the largest band of Indians in the Territories I think that plans for the betterment of the Indians should include the immediate construction of a Residential school at Fort Rae.
R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Booth Building, Ottawa.

This will acknowledge receipt of your memoranda dated June 24th and June 28th requesting that the Inspector of Schools, Mr. J. W. McKinnon, submit recommendations regarding the seasonal school now in operation at Fort Rae, Northwest Territories.

Mr. McKinnon recommends that the seasonal school be extended to cover the full 1948-49 school year, and that Mr. Allard's sister be engaged to proceed to Fort Rae and assist her brother with the conduct of this school. Both teachers should be informed that this step is of an experimental nature, and that subsequent decisions will depend upon the enrolment and progress of the school.

Mr. McKinnon recommends that the present seasonal school be continued for the months of July and August, and that the school cease to function on a seasonal basis at the end of August. This will assist in making a division of the teaching load when a second teacher arrives, because one of the teachers can take the children who have already received some instruction.

Dr. Pett of the Nutrition Services, Department of National Health and Welfare, is now making some revisions in a ration list which he prepared several years ago for use in the Northwest Territories. We expect to receive this revised ration list within the next day or so, at which time a copy will be forwarded to your office. It is suggested that this ration list be mimeographed and forwarded to all teaching personnel who will require to order rations for the coming school year. In a recent
conversation, Mr. Cheshire of the Hudson's Bay Company suggested that copies of the ration list be forwarded to the teachers who will indicate therein the articles they desire to purchase, and will return same to your office. The ration list should then be forwarded to the Wholesale Department of the Hudson's Bay Company at Edmonton; where it will be filled on a wholesale price basis and forwarded to the destination. In order that the teacher may enjoy the wholesale price for commodities, payment will have to be made within thirty days. This means that the Government should pay for the rations and deduct same from whatever living allowance may be made.

The time factor may make this arrangement regarding rations unsuitable in the case of Mr. Allard. He might be advised by wire to submit his ration order without delay to your office for transmission to the Hudson's Bay Company.

R. A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re: purchasing of electricity from R.C. Mission. The mission would have been pleased to help us out but unfortunately they are not getting their new battery back which I counter when I wrote to you. So that leaves us with an available talkie projector and no juice. But I still don't give it up as a bad job included as a suggestion which I think should force service to us and saving to your Department.

Suggested by the mission that you provide a new battery back for their plant in exchange of electricity for both school and house for the life of the battery. For your information their plant is well equipped with both diesel motor and wind charger providing us with constant light. The Fathers are quite capable of taking good care of the batteries, their past
set is going on its eight year of continuous service. To my knowledge this is cheap electricity for our north. Keep in mind that we use lights all day for at least four full months and part time for two.

Our present setup depends on the wind and according to Mr. Biffin the lamps are used most of the time for both house and school. If you accept this deal it will cut off all lamp equipment, batteries for our plant, repairs and last but not least danger of fire.

Much to the contrary of needless talk against the R.C. mission I find them all for the school and its success. That is why I suggest such a transaction which is for the good of the school.

The good attendance of the pupils has kept up in July and all is progressing slow but sure as expected. I am sending under separate cover samples of our needle craft which is an all Doxie product made by young native girls. Would it be possible for you to arrange outside sale of such products. I have previously mentioned a few words to Mr. Neary regarding the janitor salary I am to get. I have paid out of my own funds for washing of school and attended to other duties myself. I wouldn't like to insist too much with Mr. Neary as I have been corresponding steady for other requisitions. I therefore leave it to you to re-introduce it in a diplomatic way.

The boarding school question is proving itself of utmost importance if any success is to be expected. On the other hand a successful schooling for other young and old would be by far more fruitful than the latter. I hope I make myself clear, so far from what I can see of the pupils coming back from Resolution. The odd will keep up the healthy routine but as a whole they go back to the same habits. While if both young and old benefited of the teachings there would be greater possibilities of improvement. I don't know but it sure sounds like a loss of time to me to educate them and cure them of disease if any, and then send them back to sick and uneducated parents.

What about our school remodeling program? If we are to be two teachers would you send material and permission for partitioning in two? The Fathers are willing to give a hand sometimes this fall. I presume you have plans for the sliding partitions and could supply us the needed material. Or would the carpenters working on the Hay River contract come to remodel our school? We haven't as yet received windows and remodeling supplies, but there is still time if you transfer the woodson the H.B.C. - M.R.T. boat seeing that the N. T.
We have already made their one and only trip to Rae. The school dimensions are roughly 24 x 9 x 40 ft. It would also be advisable to build a porch for wood supplies and wind break if we are to make two classrooms out of the building.

Your silence has greatly disappointed me with regards to our requisitions. Although I still expect more material by the H.B.C. boat. Received last year's stationery and various small articles plus some equipment and the books you promised me. I haven't as yet received the Look and See book. I got one from Yellowknife and my pupils are doing alright with it. The progress is as I expected it but I am not too disappointed with their work. Hoping that all will turn for a successful schooling for our little natives,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) Leon A. Allard
Teacher Rae Indian Day School.

P. S. Would appreciate knowing what my future salary is to be? Special allowance? Transportation???

Correspondence Course for Teacher at Fort Rae (Mr. L.A. Allard):

During the past month I have been able to visit the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency as well as the Fort Resolution Residential School. As this trip was made just after the opening of the schools, I believe it worthwhile to report on my observations at each point.

On September 22nd, I proceeded to Fort Rae to check on progress of repairs to this building. This work is nearing completion and a very good job has been obtained. The entire building has been insulated and the second story as well. This gives a manual training room for future use. The first floor has been divided into two with all old partitions removed, giving two good class rooms. The dividing partition is movable and the school will now make a good hall. All walls of first floor have been lined with gypsum wallboard and painted. Part of the second story has been lined as well, but there was a shortage of material and this will be obtained next year when the work can be completed. This gives a very good fireproof interior and very durable.

The whole interior has been painted including the ceiling. The windows, which just arrived by last boat of the season, are being put in and when the teacher returns from his holidays, the building should be complete ready for school.

The two new oil stoves have arrived as well as fuel oil, all noon lunch materials and the teachers' ration have been put into Fort Rae on the last boat.

I expect to pick up the carpenter by plane before the middle of October and will then pay all wages and incidentals and send an accounting to your office.

I have seen enormous progress at all the schools since last term and I believe we can look forward with confidence to the results that will be obtained from the new type of school in the Northwest Territories.

(Sgd.) T.E.Kirby,
Sup't Indian Agencies.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have given some thought to the type of teacher required at Fort Rae and would recommend that Mr. Leon Allard be replaced by his sister, who is a qualified teacher.

Mr. Allard has done some fine work in getting the school established but it is regretted that he has not the ability to organize this school. He has no teacher training and thus he is not in a position to give this community the type of education required. About two weeks ago, he called at the office and inquired of the possibility of placing his sister, Miss Terry Allard, in charge of the school and having her father live with her; the father would attend to the fires and do caretaking services. Mr. Leon Allard inquired of this possibility on the understanding that he would be appointed to one of the schools operated by the Department elsewhere.

Miss Allard is a qualified teacher. She has a fine personality and a knowledge of the techniques of teaching; this is vital as far as teaching Indian children is concerned. Her ability as a teacher is reflected in her work. The children like her and learn quite well under her supervision. The parents are aware of this difference as they prefer their children to be taught by Miss Allard in preference to her brother.

I have had various complaints to the effect that Mr. Allard is becoming "bushed". I know that he is not liked as well as his sister. The Indians are of the opinion that their children learned far better under Miss Allard's supervision. I am also of the opinion that Mr. Allard might be more interested in organizing a trading company than a school as he inquired from me when I last visited Fort Rae of the possibility of his sister teaching in the school on the understanding that he be permitted to trade on the side and then teach during the seasonal periods. I squelched this idea by informing him that the Department would not grant him a trading license and that we were not interested...
in having our teachers act as traders and teachers as the two professions did not go together.

I would recommend that Miss Allard be appointed teacher in charge of this school in June and that her father be engaged as Caretaker. Mr. Leon Allard might complete his High School course and obtain teacher training on the understanding that he would receive every consideration at that time. As no action will be necessary regarding the appointment of a teacher to this school until June, I shall give Mr. Allard every opportunity to measure up to our expectations in the meantime. I shall submit a report on his work sometime in June as he may show considerable improvement in the intervening time.

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Superintendent of Education,
Mackenzie District, N.W.T.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

RAE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

You will recall that at a meeting of the Subcommittee on Education in the Northwest Territories we discussed the proposal to purchase a trading post to be established as a day school at Rae. It has been recommended, both by Inspector of Schools McKinnon and by the Chief of our Reserves Division, Mr. McCrimmon, that we purchase this property. Both of these officials have inspected the property and in fact Mr. McCrimmon has stayed at the trader's house. The property consists of the following:

(a) Store (40 x 28)
(b) Dwelling house (36 x 22)
(c) Oil and ice house
(d) Store-house (24 x 16)
(e) The log shacks located in the property
(f) 4.44 acres of land on the water front upon which the above buildings are located, Lot 3, Settlement of Rae, N.W.T.

The house is furnished with a radio, two stoves, an ice box, a washing machine, 8 dining room chairs, 2 large beds, 2 cots, a Winnipeg couch, a 12 volt wind charger, storm doors and windows and a full line of dishes and kitchen utensils.

Therefore it is felt that the purchase of this
property for $10,000.00 is a good investment, especially in view of the fact that we could not build a day school there for less than $40,000.00. At the present time we propose to rent this property from Mr. Buffum so that we can operate a school in it during the winter months. Our Superintendent of Education is now making final negotiations with a teacher who is willing to go in to Rae for this purpose.

We do not have the funds available in our present estimates for the purchase of this building and therefore the Departmental Solicitor has prepared a draft option or purchase agreement, as attached. I would recommend that this be approved by the Minister as a submission for an Order-in-Council.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Rae Indian Day School, N.W.T. -

We have recently entered into an option agreement with Mr. George Buffum, who owns a trading post at Fort Rae which he is selling to us for use as a day school.

He has a quantity of paint on hand in the buildings which we are interested in purchasing. In his letter of January 5 Mr. Buffum describes this paint as follows:

"There is twenty gallons of roof paint made up of ten gallons shingle paint and ten gallons rubberoid paint. The price of this is two per gallon. There also is eight gallons of outside white paint inside paint, floor paint and varnish. The price of this is four dollars per gallon."

In a previous letter Mr. Buffum assured us that this paint was purchased several years ago and is of good quality. Would you please advise whether these prices are fair and just, and, if so, issue the necessary purchase order to George Buffum, 11136 - 67th Street, Edmonton, Alberta. The coding is as follows:

516 - 10-691 - 906.

That there are some 740 Indians living at Rae in the Northwest Territories of whom some 143 are of school age;

That the said George C. Buffum is willing to sell the said property for ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00);

That the property consists of four and forty-four hundredths acres of land, one store which would be suitable for classrooms, one fully furnished dwelling house which would be suitable for a teachersage, one oil and ice house and one storehouse, all in good condition;

That the Minister has agreed and decided that due to present conditions, it is expedient to acquire the property above mentioned at the price offered rather than to erect a new school building;

The Committee, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise:

1. That authority be granted to enter now into an option agreement with George C. Buffum and to pay for the said property a sum not to exceed $10,000.00 together with all costs necessarily incurred to make title thereto, the moneys to be provided from the Education Vote of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources for the fiscal year 1948-49; and

Dear Sir:

Re: School - Fort Rae, Northwest Territories.

Enclosed herewith are three copies of a requisition given to me by Mr. Allard, teacher at Fort Rae school.

As this school is mostly Indian, the provision of these supplies is the responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch, so I would be very pleased if the additional copy of this requisition were forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch, for their attention. Indian agent, Hunter, I understand, is submitting a similar requisition, so it will be necessary to check both requisitions in order to avoid any duplication of supplies.

As the school at Rae has just been opened, you will note that the amount of supplies needed will be considerably more than will be required next year. Mr. Lamberton and Colonel Neary will be in a position to add to this requisition, all the necessary supplies which will be needed during the coming year.

When school opened, there were seventeen children in attendance, and information available at Rae indicates that the pupilage will begin to increase about June 15th, and that there will be from fifty to one hundred and thirty children of school age in the settlement during a seasonal period of from four to five months depending upon fur conditions.

Mr. Allard, the teacher, is very anxious to receive a full line of hand tools and sufficient soft wood for manual training purposes. After seeing the fine woodwork produced by the grade 1 Eskimo children at Port Erbant, I am convinced that there is great value in this type of training and would recommend the purchase of all necessary supplies in this connection.

As the children at Rae have had no schooling, I suggest that all children be X-rayed at the earliest possible date. There is a hospital in this settlement, with equipment available, so I am of the opinion that this can be attended to quite easily.

As there is a regular monthly mail service between Yellowknife and Rae, and as Rae is the largest Indian Settlement in the Northwest Territories, I recommend that a delco plant and projector be provided for this school in order that the educational films may be shown to the child and adult population of this community.

All in the north country with whom I have conversed are of the opinion that visual education - particularly the showing of health films - is one of the greatest elevating factors in bettering the conditions of the people. So if one large delco
plant were installed, it could be used to meet the needs of the Hudson's Bay Company, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and the school; and at the same time, by avoiding a duplication of this service, a greater measure of economy would be secured and the fire hazard would be reduced. It is most important that the fire extinguishers requisitioned for, be provided at the earliest possible date, as none are available at the present time.

Should the government purchase the Buffum property this way, it will be necessary to have a carpenter recut a full length of windows on one side of the class-rooms, as there is need of more light. One of the Brothers in the Roman Catholic Mission is trained in carpentry, and I understand he would be willing to remodel the class-room, installing windows and blackboards.

Mr. Allard appears to be a very capable young man, and informed me he would be willing to remain in the settlement for several years, provided he was given all necessary assistance and equipment. I assured him that the Government of Canada is vitally interested in the welfare of its people; and in this connection I plan to interview his sister, a qualified teacher, in order to determine her suitability as an additional teacher for the Fort Rae community.

While at Rae, Mr. Allard said that it was going to cost him a great deal to live at Rae, and wondered if the Indian Affairs Branch would allow him $50.00 a month for caretaking services, in connection with the school. As such, he would be responsible for sweeping, attending to the fires, and the bringing in of water, and any other incidental activities in connection with the care of the school property. I suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch grant him this allowance in view of the high cost of living, and in the interests of fire prevention, as I do not think that children should be entrusted with attending of school fires. At Fort Macpherson, where the children had been attending to the fires, I noticed the floors splattered with oil, which doubtless creates a fire hazard.

Kindly consider this in the nature of an interim report, as I will be submitting at a later date, a complete report concerning each school.

Yours very truly,

J.W. McKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

I understand that Indian Agent, L.C. Hunter, is placing a Requisition with your Branch for school supplies at Fort Rae, thus it will be necessary to check this requisition along with that presented by him in order to avoid a duplication of supplies.

Fort Rae:

There are 706 Indians in the Fort Rae Band; of these, 660 were present for annuity payment last summer. Others had wandered into the Bear Lake regions where they probably will remain.

The Fort Rae Indians are the most primitive in the agency. They have absolutely no conception of the state of affairs anywhere except in their own small area. Very few have any education, very few speak English. The Indians live by hunting and trapping; there is very little opportunity for employment in other lines. The Hudson's Bay Post Manager figures the average income to be $300.00 a year. Fishing is satisfactory and the caribou are plentiful in season.

When the white fox was valuable these people trapped far out in the Barrens and were quite wealthy. But now they are poor, dressed in ragged clothing and at times, particularly in summer, are really hungry. They no longer dry considerable quantities of fish and caribou and for the most part, wear store-bought clothing and live in tents.

Since this is the largest band of Indians in the Territories I think that plans for the betterment of the Indians should include the immediate construction of a Residential school at Fort Rae.

July 19, 1948.

Dear Sir:

I have received a copy of your letter of June 22nd addressed to Mr. R.A. Gibson, Deputy Commissioner, Northwest Territories Administration, concerning the provision of food supplies for our school teachers in the North.

I have written to two of our teachers concerning the provision of these supplies and now wish to place an order for the attached list of rations for:

Mr. L. Allard,
Indian Day School,
Rae, Northwest Territories.

Would you please supply this list of rations to Mr. Allard and forward the account here. We will make arrangements to deduct an amount each month from Mr. Allard's living allowance in order to recover the cost of providing these food supplies.

The second teacher mentioned above is Miss Hinds at Fort McPherson. I understand that she has made arrangements with your store in Edmonton to provide her with the rations which she will be requiring. It would be appreciated if you could make every effort to have Mr. Allard's supplies forwarded to him on the last boat north.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

R.H. Chesshire, Esq.,
General Manager,
Fur Trade Department,
Hudson Bay Company,
Hudson Bay House,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

BFN/HM.
Rae Indian Day School,
Rae N.W.T.
July 12th 1948

Mr. B. F. Neary,
Dept./Indian Education,
Ottawa Ontario.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Enclosed is a list which I have completed to the best of my ability. I would suggest your purchasing these and some for other articles in acquisition and sending them through the M.R.T.'s H.B.C. boat no later than the beginning of August. However you are in a better position to find by contacting the H.B.C. Co. for more accurate details.

I am sorry to inform you that your said letter has not as yet reached me and I don't suppose it will until the second week in August as we get mail once a month. It will then be too late to send my list. According to your last wire I was to wait the arrival of your letter but in view of circumstances I am unable to follow orders. I will however contact you by radiogram if
by chance we do get our mail before the
2nd week in August.

I most thankfully congrat-
ulate you on behalf of your wise decision
with regards to Rae Indian Day School.
Trusting that all will turn out for the
best I remain

Yours very truly,
Leon A. Allard,
Teacher Rae Indian Day School.

Rae Indian Day School.

Re; Fort Rae, School Supplies.

Referring to your wireless message of July 9th, regarding supplies for the Fort Rae, Indian Day school, I am forwarding herewith the requisitions as suggested.

In your wireless message it is noted that the Department are prepared to supply Condensed milk. It will be noted that this has been included on the requisition but I may suggest that I believe that Dry milk would be more suitable for this purpose. Should you concur with my opinion I would ask that the requisition be changed to 10 (ten) drums of Trumilk instead of the Condensed milk.

At the present time the teacher of the Ft. Rae School is of the opinion that there will be an average attendance of fifty pupils for the coming 12 months.

September 15, 1948.

Colonel E. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Fort Rae Indian Day School.

I have recently returned from visiting the Fort Rae Indian Day School and have found the majority of the supplies, as ordered for this school, have not yet arrived. As the navigation season to this point has expired for this season arrangements will necessarily have to be made for the transportation of these supplies from Yellowknife to Fort Rae.

While in Yellowknife I checked with the transportation companies and found that these supplies were in storage at Yellowknife. I was assured that transportation of these supplies would be made should any boat be going within the vicinity of Fort Rae, and further, if this can not be done I will be notified by these companies, which will necessitate the hiring of aircraft by this department.

The supplies which have not arrived at Fort Rae include food for the teachers and rations for the pupils mid-day meal. As can be seen these supplies are definitely necessary for the carrying on of this school, therefore I would request your authority to make arrangements for the hire of aircraft to transport these supplies should they not arrive by boat this season. It may further be stated the Northwest Territories Administration have aircraft at their disposal in this locality and it may be possible to use same for this purpose.

I have checked the other supplies and am vouchering the accounts immediately.

L. C. Hunter, Indian Superintendent.

Mr. L.C. Hunter,

Bernard F. Heary

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Rae Indian Day School,
Rae, N.W.T.
Nov. 27th, 1948.

Mr. L.G. Hunter,
Fort Norman.

Dear Mr. Hunter,

I am sending under separate cover signed waybill for freight received at Yellowknife. I presume these will be forwarded to you for payment. You will notice one article, #36/25 has been checked short. As I haven't received invoices from the H.R.C. I am not able to describe the contents. I am fairly sure that these must be cheese and honey the only articles that I didn't get. Are you in a position to claim these parcels? I have marked it short and signed it thus on the waybill.

You will also receive bills from Mr. Wilson H.R.C. Ras, for transportation of freight from Yellowknife. The high rate is due to the shortage of freight to make it a worthwhile trip. However it is cheaper than airfreight and the possibility of freezing the supplies has been avoided. In view of the high rate through no fault of mine but that of a Departmental delay I suggest that the overcharge be paid by the Department.

Included is a description of the school. By doing this I aim at furnishing all the necessary details so that you can decide for yourself or let Ottawa decide what the construction programme is to be. I would like to point out the necessity of a ventilation system, windows and complete reconstruction of the interior. I now have two stoves in the classroom and it isn't any too warm.

Here is my suggestions:

(1) That at least twelve windows be added.
(2) That ten Test or other similar material be used inside.
(3) That a proper ventilation system be introduced.
(4) That some heating system or material be added to keep the floor warm.
(5) That a heated porch be added large enough to be used as a cloak room.
(6) That a sliding partition be built to separate the two classrooms.
(7) That the upstairs be finished and rebuilt into a convenient kitchenette, washroom, lunchroom and library.

Although I don't recommend such high expenditures for two such small classrooms which would never accommodate the summer attendance I would like to bring to your attention then importance of this question. Besides being too small for two classrooms it is also in a poor location being in the midst of the summer sidewalks and the winter dog trails. The playground...
LAYGROUND problem "unless we clear, bulldoze and level a ground at the back of Father's garden" is also to be considered.

Please advise on what arrangements I'm to make for the payment of (1) Floor washing, (2) general clean-up of School, (3) Putting up ice for summer use, (4) Building of a slide. The charges suggested are $4.00 for washing the floor, $8.00 for walls and ceiling about $25.00 for the slide and $15.00 for the ice. Items 1-2 and 3 need no explanation, regarding the slide it has been my desire to build a slide similar to that of Resolution school. I intend building it entirely of poles, snow and water. It will prove itself very useful for recreational activities.

In order to avoid such side charges I would suggest your increasing the handy man's salary. It would all turn out even as there is a lot of work such as painting, wood cutting, nailing of wood, keeping the buildings repaired, interpreting, cleaning of school and a thousand other jobs. At $25.00 a month one can't expect much. By the way my handyman Mr. Bouvier was very disappointed, he hasn't received a penny yet?

Requested that library books be furnished for teacher As you already know the important role books play in Northern Life I need not explain this requisition.

Included is a list of Handy craft material. If Ottawa won't pay the air rate kindly cancel last items. The delay in answering your last wire was that I wired N.T.C.L. for information, their office being closed it was forwarded to Edmonton which all took time. The three pupils for Grade III, IV and V are from Yellowknife and are now regular pupils of Rae. As stated their former school is Resolution. They are now permanent citizens of Fort Rae. Wishing you a Merry Xmas and Happy New Year I remain,

Yours truly
L.A. Allard.
Fort Norman, N.W.T.
December 28th, 1948.

Col. B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Sir:

Re; Fort Rae, Indian Day School,
Fort Rae N.W.T.

I am attaching herewith a copy of a letter recently received from the teacher of the Fort Rae Indian Day School. I will attempt to deal with each point as raised by the teacher, separately, for your information.

It will be noted that the school supplies and teachers provisions arrived at Fort Rae. I do not consider the charge for the carrying of these supplies from Yellowknife to Ft. Rae exorbitant and am therefore passing the account for payment this date. As for the parcel that was short shipped, I await the waybills of the transportation Company at which time a claim will be submitted for the shortage.

As you will note from the attached letter, Mr. Allard has put forth suggestions for the remodeling the present school building. I concur with the suggestions that this work should be done during the coming summer, as the attendance at this school should warrant such an expenditure. Should the Department agree that this work be done may I please be advised so that the necessary material may be ordered. I am of the opinion that the work as described by Mr. Allard could be done by the R.C. Mission Church Brothers, if the material were supplied. I do not agree with Mr. Allard that the location of the school is wrong, as the property is owned by our Department it would only be necessary to have a fence placed around the grounds to stop people from using it as a main thoroughfare.

The present system that we have for paying janitors in the schools in the N.W.T. will necessarily have to
HAVE TO be changed. The fact that other Departments are paying from one hundred dollars to one hundred and fifty dollars per month for the services of a janitor and handy man, is causing considerable dissension. I would suggest that for a school such as Ft. Rae that a position be established for a casual laborer at a salary of one hundred dollars per month and that the person employed do all cleaning and repair jobs. This salary would include all tasks connected with the school, except for jobs that would require a tradesman. I am also covering this matter under separate letter on the Fort McPherson Indian Day school, and I would request that I be advised on your opinion. I have vouchered for the salary of the handyman of the Fort Rae School for the period Sept. 1st, 1946 to Nov. 30th, 1948.

I am advising the teacher of the Fort Rae school to withhold any charges or work for general cleaning of the school. Should the handyman or janitor be given an increase in salary such cleaning would be his responsibility. I may further mention that if the school is to be remodeled that the cleaning of the walls etc. would not be necessary at the present time.

I am instructing Mr. Allard to submit to me the entire requirements of the Ft. Rae School for the school year 1946/50, so that requisitions may be submitted to the Department in sufficient time to avoid any trouble in having our freight carried by the Transportation Companies.

The handy-craft material as mentioned in the letter of Mr. Allard, has been ordered from Eaton's with the request that they prepay the Air Express and submit same with their invoice. The Air Express on these articles should be very small amount.

It would be appreciated if I could be advised at the earliest, regarding the remodeling of this school and the increase of the salary for a casual laborer.

[Signature]
I.O. Hunter,
Superintendent,
Ft. Norman Agency.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

Fort Rae Indian Day School -
Alteration of Classroom.

We have received a letter from Mr. Indian Superintendent Hunter with regard to suggested changes in the classroom and teachersage at the above school. Mr. Allard has made the following recommendations:-

"Included is a description of the school. By doing this I aim at furnishing all the necessary details so that you can decide for yourself or let Ottawa decide what the construction programme is to be. I would like to point out the necessity of a ventilation system, windows and complete reconstruction of the interior. I now have two stoves in the classroom and it isn't any too warm.

Here is my suggestions: -

(1) That at least twelve windows be added.

(2) That ten Test or other similar material be used inside.

(3) That a proper ventilation system be introduced.

(4) That some heating system or material be added to keep the floor warm.

(5) That a heated porch be added large enough to be used as a cloak room.

(6) That a sliding partition be built to separate the two classrooms.

..... (7)

(7) That the upstairs be finished and rebuilt into a convenient kitchenet, washroom lunchroom and library.

"Although I don't recommend such high expenditures for two such small classrooms which would never accommodate the summer attendance I would like to bring to your attention the importance of this question. Besides being too small for two classrooms it is also in a poor location being in the midst of the summer sidewalks and the winter dog trails. The playground problem 'unless we clear, bulldoze and level a ground at the back of Father's garden' is also to be considered.

"Please advise on what arrangements I'm to make for the payment of (1) Floor washing, (2) general clean-up of School, (3) Putting up ice for summer use, (4) Building of a slide. The charges suggested are $4.00 for washing the floor, $8.00 for walls and ceiling about $25.00 for the slide and $15.00 for the ice. Items 1-2 and 3 need no explanation, regarding the slide it has been my desire to build a slide similar to that of Resolution School. I intend building it entirely of poles snow and water. It will prove itself very useful for recreational activities.

"In order to avoid such side charges I would suggest your increasing the handy man's salary. It would all turn out even as there is a lot of work such as painting, wood cutting, piling of wood, keeping the buildings repaired, interpreting, cleaning of school and a thousand other jobs. At $25.00 a month one can't expect much. By the way my handyman Mr. Bouvier was very disappointed, he hasn't received a penny yet."

In forwarding Mr. Allard's letter Mr. Hunter has the following comments to make:

"As you will note from the attached letter, Mr. Allard has put forth suggestions for the remodelling of the present school building. I concur with the suggestions that this work should be done during the coming summer, as...
attendance at this school should warrant such an expenditure. Should the Department agree that this work be done may I please be advised so that the necessary material may be ordered. I am of the opinion that the work as described by Mr. Allard could be done by the R.C. Mission Church Brothers, if the material were supplied. I do not agree with Mr. Allard that the location of the school is wrong, as the property is owned by our Department it would only be necessary to have a fence placed around the grounds to stop people from using it as a main thoroughfare.

"The present system that we have for paying janitors in the schools in the N.W.T. will necessarily have to be changed. The fact that other Departments are paying from one hundred dollars to one hundred and fifty dollars per month for the services of a janitor and handy man, is causing considerable dissension. I would suggest that for a school such as Ft. Rae that a position be established for a casual labourer at a salary of one hundred dollars per month and that the person employed do all cleaning and repair jobs. This salary would include all tasks connected with the school, except for jobs that would require a tradesman. I am also covering this matter under separate letter on the Fort McPherson Indian Day School, and I would request that I be advised on your opinion. I have vouchered for the salary of the handyman of the Fort Rae School for the period Sept. 1st, 1948, to Nov. 30th, 1948.

"I am advising the teacher of the Fort Rae School to withhold any charges or work for general cleaning of the school. Should the handyman or janitor be given an increase in salary such cleaning would be his responsibility. I may further mention that if the school is to be remodeled that the cleaning of the walls, etc. would not be necessary at the present time."

I would like to receive from Mr. McKinnon an expression of his views concerning the proposed changes which Mr. Allard has recommended for the Rae Indian Day School.

I would suggest also that the question of janitor's or caretaker's salary be placed on the agenda for discussion at the next meeting of the Sub-committee on Education of the North-west Territories Council.

Director.
