Mr. L. A. Allard,
Res Indian Day School,
Res, Northwest Territories.

Dear Mr. Allard:

You will recall that I wrote to you previously concerning the employment of your sister as a second teacher at your school during the summer holidays. We have now received a letter from her indicating that she will be free from April 25 to September 30. I am writing to her today indicating that we are prepared to engage her services during this period. Mr. McKinnon and I discussed this matter recently and we realize that you will have a very large enrolment of Indian children during the summer months. Her salary would be at the rate of $200.00 per month as a seasonal school teacher.

You will recall my letter to you of November 30 concerning your Northern Living Allowance. At that time I told you that you would be advised further in detail with regard to deductions from your Northern Living Allowance.

By Order-in-Council 5912 of December 21, 1948, new regulations were brought into effect dealing with Northern Living Allowances. The rate for single employees is still $900.00 per annum but we are required to make the following deductions:

(a) House, fuel and light - 10% of the maximum of the class range.

The highest salary for a Grade One welfare teacher is $1,560.00 per year; therefore the monthly deduction for house, fuel and light will be $13.00.

(b) For furniture the deduction shall be at the rate of $60.00 per annum. Therefore $5.00 per month will be deducted from your allowance for this purpose.
The total of your bill with the Hudson's Bay Company for rations came to $544.17. I presume that you are anxious to get this paid off as fast as possible and therefore I have advised Treasury that a deduction at the rate of $57.00 per month should be made from your Northern Living Allowance so that this account can be met.

Therefore, until your grocery bill has been paid off in entirety, your Northern Living Allowance will be used up as follows:

$13.00 for house, fuel and light,
$5.00 for furniture,
$57.00 for rations.

I hope that the above explains clearly to you how we are handling your Northern Living Allowance payment at the present time.

We have received your ration requisition for 1949-50 and will take the necessary action to forward these supplies.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard V. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
March 29, 1949.

Mr. L. C. Hunter,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Fort Norman, Northwest Territories.

Rae Indian Day School.

Your letter of December 28 has been the subject of several discussions between Mr. McKinnon and myself. Please find attached a copy of plan 888 which is our standard one-room school with attached teacher's residence. If you alter the classroom to conform generally to the classroom in this plan, I feel you should have a satisfactory school. I note that if the Department provides the materials, we can have the work done locally by Mr. Allard and the Roman Catholic Brothers. Would you please therefore submit, by airmail, the requisition for the windows, doors, etc., required to convert this building to a proper classroom or classrooms.

We are not prepared to move the school and agree with your comments about its location. With regard to the payment of janitor services, we certainly cannot pay $100 to $150.00 per month. Any position over $400.00 must be established by the Civil Service Commission. We cannot permit the cost of operating day schools to rise by hiring caretakers and janitors for each individual school. At the present time we are prepared to pay an amount of approximately $20.00 per classroom for caretaking duties. The sweeping and dusting should be done by the pupils. This is standard practice at all our Indian day schools and also in most provincial rural schools. The children can be rewarded by candies or similar prizes. The Department is prepared to allow an amount of $5.00 per month for the purchase of these items. We are prepared to pay for the putting up of ice at the standard rate in the neighbourhood.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Enclosed please find my 1948/50 ratings. These will be deducted from northern allowance as last year. I expected an answer to my last letter giving me further explanation to the 47/50 school year in Rae. I am willing to stay in Rae but it is at all possible to transfer me to another school in the territories I would appreciate it. I don't know if your department permits it but the Manitoba Department of Education permitted such exchange of schools. It is only a suggestion of course but a change in locality would do a lot of good to the teachers.

I have lately heard of raise in pay for all social welfare workers? Those that include me?

Yours very truly,

Alterations - Indian Day School, Fort Rae, N.W.T.

Unfortunately, we have a very heavy building programme this year and it has been difficult to have an engineer prepare the bill of materials felt to be necessary for alterations to the Fort Rae School.

Please find attached a copy of the requisition sent to the Departmental Purchasing Agent, covering the windows, lumber, nails and paint thought to be necessary. It has been a real problem to draft this bill of materials and we can only hope that it will be sufficient for your needs. As I visualize it, your main problems are:

(a) To improve the insulation in the schoolroom,

(b) To provide more windows.

Therefore, we have ordered mineral wool insulation, plywood, and plaster board. The plaster board can be used above the blackboard level and the plywood below blackboard level.

We have also ordered 10 windows which I think, with the present ones, should prove more than adequate.

I would suggest that we plan on making any other alterations next summer and that you then submit a requisition
during the winter, based on the supplies being sent to you this summer.

Please advise me as to the size of the accountable advance which you will require to have this work carried out by local labour. I presume that Mr. Allard will be available to supervise and help with this work.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

On July 15th I inspected the school building at Ft. Rae, N.W.T., with a view to improving insulation, providing more windows, and general improvement of the interior.

If this building is to be insulated with the rock wool batts that are being supplied it will be necessary to remove the entire inside sheathing of the building first. This sheathing is shiplap, old and brittle, and by the time it has been removed will be of little value to put back on the walls. No extra shiplap has been provided for this work.

I request that I be given permission to insulate this building with shavings that can be procured from saw mills in the Resolution area. These shavings can be poured damp between the wall studs without cutting or removing any sheathing since the studs are open above the ceiling. It would then be possible to completely insulate this building in no more than one week whereas the installation of rock wool will require at least one month with the help available.

It has been proposed to insulate the ceiling of the second story with rock wool and sheath with shiplap. This will give a good manual training room at some later date.

The second story floor is constructed of flooring and the ceiling of the downstairs is also constructed of flooring. Either would invariably be ruined if it is decided to insulate the ceiling of the downstairs instead of the ceiling of the second floor. Consequently I believe it is best to insulate the second story ceiling.

Extra windows are to be installed in both ends of the building, and existing partitions should be removed giving added space for class rooms.

One movable sectional partition should be erected to divide the floor space into two sections if there are enough pupils for two rooms; or to cut down the size of the class room when fewer pupils are attending classes during the winter, when the smaller room will be easier to heat.

Dear Sir:

Repairs to Indian Day School, Ft. Rae, N.W.T.

Further to my letter of July 18th, and your wire of July 22nd, it would appear that I had made my letter a little ambiguous as to insulating the second story of this school. The first story up to level of top plate will be insulated with shavings to save time and expense. I had then proposed to insulate between the rafters and the second story ceiling with the rock wool bats supplied. This portion of the building had never been sheathed so no need to do any extra dismantling. The rockwool for this section would give a much better finished job than shavings.

On checking with Northern Transportation Co., I find that all materials ordered for Ft. Rae with the exception of shiplap and paint had been held at Ft. Smith on orders from Hayward Lumber Co. From this I presume that no additional windows are to be put in; walls insulated with shavings, ceiling insulated with rock wool and sheathed, sectional partition constructed and building painted, will be only repairs completed.

Material had been en-route to finish entire classrooms with wallboard but this was also held at Ft. Smith so will not be doing any interior improvement except as outlined in your wire.

I do believe that this building should have been covered inside with wallboard as it is very dingy but if it is the policy of the Department to build a new modern school; a building which must be considered soon at this point; then there is little point in spending more than just enough to make this old building comfortable for the present time.

As soon as I can get a cost of shavings from Wynn's Mill will advise you as requested in wire.
I have just received the file on Ft. Rae School from Supt. Hunter of Ft. Norman and while checking over the requisition he sent in find that quantities of nails sent in or ordered are very inadequate for the work. Will it be in order for me to make local purchase of such items as are necessary to complete the repairs as set out in your wire.

I regret that these shortages appear but I have had little time to check back correspondence and only find them at the last minute. I do not believe the quantities will be excessive in any instance but as it is now too late to receive shipments from Edmonton require authority to make small local purchases. If you require I will wire each time a local purchase becomes necessary.

The shipments have not gone forward to Ft. Rae from here so believe it will be the end of second week in August at the very earliest before we can start work on this school.

Yours very truly

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Repairs to Indian Day School, Ft. Rae, N.W.T.

I have been advised by the teacher at Ft. Rae that all the materials on order have been delivered and with the exception of the shavings all necessary material is at the school. These shavings are to be delivered to Mr. Wynn to me at Yellowknife next week and I will then send them to Ft. Rae.

I intend to take in one carpenter foreman to Ft. Rae on August 15th and will start him to work repairing the school as indicated. We will be engaging two native laborers at that point to assist in completing the work.

With the material available there is at least three weeks repair work to be done before there is need to insulate with the shavings so I intend to start whether the shavings have been delivered or not.

Mr. Wynn has notified me that his shavings will be priced at $2.50 per bale delivered at Yellowknife. We will need sixty bales which will indicate we need an expenditure of $150.00 for this purpose. I am of the opinion that a small quantity of slaked lime should be put in with the shavings to prevent vermin from entering the building. Three sacks purchased locally will be all that is required.

It is quite obvious after I made a second check of the requisition, that we will need a small quantity of 2 x 4 inch nails extra. We will be using some heavy material where it is possible and the extra nails will be needed for this.

The accountable advance for the labour costs of this school has not been deposited at the bank in Yellowknife. If this has not gone forward could I receive same at an early date as all help in this country expect their pay at the end of every week.

This is an Indian Day School, will the Treaty Indians whom I engage as helpers be subjected to Income Tax? These people are not eligible for the Northern Allowance and I do not feel they should have to pay tax. I request this information for making up my pay list and for making deductions where necessary.

The following work will be completed at this school:

1. All exterior walls insulated with shavings.
2. Ceiling between rafters to be insulated with rockwool and sheathed with shiplap.
3. Existing partitions to be removed and a movable partition constructed to divide the building into two rooms.
4. Bottom four feet of walls to be sheathed with plywood. Top section of walls sheathed with Gyprock wallboard.
5. Interior of downstairs; or class room section, to be painted.
6. Exterior of building to be painted.
7. Doors and windows to be weatherproofed and position of windows changed to provide more light as indicated in your letter of May 27, 1949.

After I have been to Ft. Rae and have started the crew I will further indicate to you what is being done and progress made.
The present supply of wood at Ft. Rae is no more than enough to do this winter and if the fuel oil on special requisition of May 1st. is not delivered we will be short of wood. At the present time native labour is available and we can get wood cut without any difficulty. During the winter and spring all the natives will be able to get fur and will not want to cut wood. I therefore request authority to have Thirty-two cords of wood cut and piled in the school yard this fall. If this wood is not needed this winter it will be needed next and we will need to have it cut next spring at the latest.

As stated earlier, now is the best time to get native labour to cut wood when they are in need of money and desire some work. Transportation is always a problem at Ft. Rae and at this time of year wood can be brought in by boat.

If this wood can be cut I will instruct that those natives who desire work will be engaged and I will then submit the vouchers for payment in the usual way.

Yours very truly,

I.F. Kirkby,
Supt. of Indian Agencies.
